Laboratory Methods.text: Fixation of sample to slide: Methanol or heat
Primary stain: Crystal violet
Mordant: Gram iodine
Decolorization: Acid alcohol
Counterstain: Safranin

Limitations.text: Cannot identify intracellular bacteria (e.g.,Chlamydophilaspp), bacteria that lack cell wall (e.g.,Mycoplasmaspp), or bacteria that are of insufficient dimension to be resolved by light microscopy (e.g., spirochetes)
Over-decolorization may give false gram-negative results
Smears that are too thick or viscous may retain too much primary stain, making identification of proper Gram stain reactions difficult; gram-negative organisms may not decolorize properly
Cultures > 16-18 hours old will contain living and dead cells; cells that are dead will be deteriorating and will not retain the stain properly
Stain may form precipitate with aging; filtering through gauze will remove excess crystals

Importance of Gram Stain.text: Principal stain used for microscopic examination of bacteriaOne of most important bacteriologic techniques within microbiology laboratory
sub_points: One of most important bacteriologic techniques within microbiology laboratory

Importance of Gram Stain.text: Provides mechanism for rapid presumptive identification of pathogens
Gives clues related to quality of specimen

Principle.text: Gram-positive cell walls, which contain thick peptidoglycan with numerous teichoic acid cross-linkages, differ from gram-negative cell walls, which consist of thinner layer of peptidoglycan and have outer lipid bilayer that is dehydrated during decolorization, accounting for Gram staining differences
Extensive teichoic acid cross-links presumably contribute to ability of gram-positive organisms to resist alcohol decolorization, leading to their purple color

Clinical Limitations.text: Gram-positive organisms that have lost cell wall integrity because of antibiotic treatment, dead or dying cells, or action of autolytic enzymes may allow crystal violet to wash out with decolorizing step and may appear gram-variable, with some cells staining pink and others staining purpleFor identification purposes, these organisms are considered to be truly gram-positive
sub_points: For identification purposes, these organisms are considered to be truly gram-positive

Clinical Limitations.text: Occasionally, pneumococci identified in lower respiratory tract on direct smear will not grow in cultureSome strains are obligate anaerobes
sub_points: Some strains are obligate anaerobes

Clinical Limitations.text: Toxin-producing organisms such as clostridia, staphylococci, and streptococci may destroy WBCs within purulent specimen
Faintly staining gram-negative organisms, such asCampylobacterandBrucellamay require alternative counterstain (e.g., basic fuchsin) for visualization

Specimens.text: BSL-1 organisms: Agents with no known potential for infecting healthy people
BSL-2 organisms: Most commonly evaluated organisms in clinical microbiology laboratory
BSL-3 organisms: Organisms unlikely to be encountered in routine clinical laboratory and select organisms such asM. tuberculosis
BSL-4 organisms: Highly infectious organisms for which no treatment exists

Safety.text: Primary risk factors that determine BSL of organism are infectivity, severity of disease, transmissibility, and nature of work being conducted (including risk of aerosol generation)

Importance.text: Different BSLs are assigned based on danger to personnel
Identified BSL determines required safety equipment and techniques used to handle pathogen

Abbreviations.text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

Synonyms.text: Class II BSC: Vertical laminar flow BSC

Definitions.text: BSC: Device that encloses work space to protect workers from aerosol exposure to infectious agents
PPE: Gloves, eyeglasses or face shields, protective clothing, and other equipment designed to protect laboratory personnel from hazards

Limitations of Protection.text: Cause for most laboratory-acquired infections is unknown

Common Biochemical Tests Used in Microbi.name: Common Biochemical Tests Used in Microbiology

Overview.text: Determining nutritional and metabolic capabilities of bacterial isolates is most common method of identification in clinical microbiology laboratory

Laboratory Methods.text: Catalase testPresence of catalase determined by direct analysis of bacterial culture; rapid production of bubbles (effervescence) occurs when bacterial growth is mixed with hydrogen peroxide
sub_points: Presence of catalase determined by direct analysis of bacterial culture; rapid production of bubbles (effervescence) occurs when bacterial growth is mixed with hydrogen peroxide

sub_points: Testing performed by flooding bacterial colonies on agar surface with 1% tetramethyl-p-phenylenediamine dihydrochloride or by rubbing bacteria onto filter paper impregnated with reagent
Positive test results in purple color

sub_points: Degradation of tryptophan into pyruvic acid, ammonia, and indole using enzyme tryptophanase

sub_points: Enzyme L-pyrrolidonyl arylamidase hydrolyzes L-pyrrolidonyl-β-naphthylamide to produce β-naphthylamine, which can be detected in presence of N,N-methylaminocinnamaldehyde by production of bright red precipitate

Importance of Biochemical Tests.text: Determining nutritional and metabolic capabilities of bacterial isolates is most common method of identification in clinical microbiology laboratory

Catalase Test.text: Enzyme catalase releases water and oxygen from hydrogen peroxide (2 H2O2 + catalase => 2H2O + O2)
Presence of catalase determined by direct analysis of bacterial culture; rapid production of bubbles (effervescence) occurs when bacterial growth is mixed with hydrogen peroxide
Failure to produce effervescence (or producing weak effervescence) is considered negative
Differentiates staphylococci and streptococci (staphylococci are catalase positive)
DifferentiatesListeria monocytogenesand corynebacteria (catalase positive) from other gram-positive, non-spore-forming bacilli (catalase negative)
LimitationsContamination of inoculum with red blood cells may result in weak effervescence
sub_points: Contamination of inoculum with red blood cells may result in weak effervescence

sub_points: Slide testDrop of coagulase plasma mixed with isolated colonyPositive result is clumping of plasma in ≤ 10 secondsLimitationsClumping in both test and control drops indicates autoagglutination and should not be considered positive
Drop of coagulase plasma mixed with isolated colony
Positive result is clumping of plasma in ≤ 10 seconds
LimitationsClumping in both test and control drops indicates autoagglutination and should not be considered positive
Clumping in both test and control drops indicates autoagglutination and should not be considered positive

Several colonies emulsified in 0.5 mL of rabbit plasma with EDTA and incubated at 35-37ºC
Clot formation assessed at 4 and 24 hours

Oxidase Test.text: Testing performed by flooding bacterial colonies on agar surface with 1% tetramethyl-p-phenylenediamine dihydrochloride or by rubbing bacteria onto filter paper impregnated with reagentPositive test results in purple colorDifferentiates ﻿Enterobacteriaceae, Stenotrophomonas maltophiliaandAcinetobacterspp. (oxidase negative) fromPseudomonasspp. andAeromonasspp. (oxidase positive)LimitationsTransfer of bacteria using iron loop may result in false-positivesResults must be read within 10 seconds
sub_points: Positive test results in purple color
Differentiates ﻿Enterobacteriaceae, Stenotrophomonas maltophiliaandAcinetobacterspp. (oxidase negative) fromPseudomonasspp. andAeromonasspp. (oxidase positive)
LimitationsTransfer of bacteria using iron loop may result in false-positivesResults must be read within 10 seconds
Transfer of bacteria using iron loop may result in false-positives
Results must be read within 10 seconds

Indole Test.text: Degradation of tryptophan into pyruvic acid, ammonia, and indole using enzyme tryptophanase
Indole detected by combining with indicator (aldehyde), resulting in blue color
LimitationsBacterial inoculum should not be chosen from MacConkey agar, because color of lactose-fermenting colonies can interfere with test interpretation
sub_points: Bacterial inoculum should not be chosen from MacConkey agar, because color of lactose-fermenting colonies can interfere with test interpretation

Urease Test.text: Urease splits urea into ammonia and CO₂
Ammonia production detected by pH shift of media, causing color change from light orange at pH 6.8 to magenta at pH 8.1

LimitationsRapid urease-positive organisms turn entire media pink in 24 hours; weakly positive organisms may take several daysAlkaline reactions may appear after prolonged incubation due to peptone or other protein utilization
sub_points: Rapid urease-positive organisms turn entire media pink in 24 hours; weakly positive organisms may take several days
Alkaline reactions may appear after prolonged incubation due to peptone or other protein utilization

PYR Test.text: Enzyme L-pyrrolidonyl arylamidase hydrolyzes L-pyrrolidonyl-β-naphthylamide to produce β-naphthylamine, which can be detected in presence of N,N-methylaminocinnamaldehyde by production of bright red precipitate
Used to presumptively identify group A streptococci and enterococci
LimitationsResults should be read within 5 minutes
sub_points: Results should be read within 5 minutes

Hippurate Hydrolysis Test.text: Hippuricase hydrolyzes hippurate to glycine, which is detected by oxidation with triketohydrindene hydrate (Ninhydrin) reagent, resulting in deep purple color
Most frequently used in identification ofGardnerella vaginalis,Streptococcus agalactiae,Campylobacter jejuni, andListeria monocytogenes
LimitationsFalse-positives may occur if Ninhydrin incubation exceeds 30 minutes
sub_points: False-positives may occur if Ninhydrin incubation exceeds 30 minutes

Bile Esculin Test.text: Organisms are grown in media that contain bile salt and esculin; positive organisms can grow in these media and hydrolyze esculin to esculetin, causing dark-brown precipitate
Used for presumptive identification of group D streptococci (Streptococcus bovisgroup) and enterococci
LimitationsNot all positive organisms can grow on these nutrient-poor media
sub_points: Not all positive organisms can grow on these nutrient-poor media

MRVP Test.text: Used to determine organism's ability to produce and maintain stable acid end products from glucose fermentation
Methyl red (MR) detects mixed acid fermentation (red at pH 4.4 and yellow at pH 6.2); positive result is red color

Voges-Proskauer (VP) detects organism's ability to convert acid products of acetoin and 2,3-butanediol; alpha-naphthol and potassium hydroxide added to methyl red negative (yellow) samples; positive result is red color
Organisms should either be positive for methyl red or Voges-Proskauer, but not both
Used to differentiate members of Enterobacteriaceae family
LimitationsTest should not be read before 48 hours (some organisms will not have produced enough products from fermentation of glucose)
sub_points: Test should not be read before 48 hours (some organisms will not have produced enough products from fermentation of glucose)

TSI Test.text: 10 parts lactose:10 parts sucrose:1 part glucose plus peptone
Phenol red and ferrous sulfate serve as indicators of acidification and H₂S formation, respectively
Glucose fermenters turn entire media acidic (yellow) in 8-12 hours, but slant will revert to alkaline (red) state after recommended 18-24 hour incubation period (K/A)
Lactose or sucrose fermenters will turn entire media acidic (yellow) even after 18-24 hours (A/A)
Formation of CO₂ and hydrogen gas is indicated by cracks in the agar or separation of agar from bottom of tube (+ gas)
Production of H₂S requires acidic environment, and reaction with ferric ammonium citrate produces blackening of agar butt (+ H₂S)
Used to differentiate members of Enterobacteriaceae family from other gram-negative rods
LimitationsReading after 24 hours may produce falsely alkaline slant due to aerobic oxidation of fermentation products of lactose &/or sucrose
sub_points: Reading after 24 hours may produce falsely alkaline slant due to aerobic oxidation of fermentation products of lactose &/or sucrose

Oxidation and Fermentation Tests.text: Media with selected nutrient (e.g., glucose) prepared with and without mineral oil overlay
Color change in uncovered tube only = oxidizer
Color change in both tubes = fermenter
Used to separate organisms into major groups (e.g., ﻿Enterobacteriaceae are fermentative,Pseudomonasspp. are oxidative)
LimitationsSlow-growing organisms may not produce results for daysMultiple reactions with multiple selected nutrients may be required for identification of organism
sub_points: Slow-growing organisms may not produce results for days
Multiple reactions with multiple selected nutrients may be required for identification of organism

Terminology.text: Selective media: Media containing one or more agents that are inhibitory to all except those selected by specific growth condition or chemical

Differential media: Media containing one or more factors that allow colonies of one bacterial species or type to exhibit certain metabolic or culture characteristics that distinguish it from other bacteria growing on same agar plate

Laboratory Methods.text: Sheep blood agar: Medium used most commonly
Mueller-Hinton agar: Medium most often used for antibiotic susceptibility testing
Sabouraud dextrose agar: Medium most often used to grow fungi
MacConkey agar: Selective and differential medium used most frequently

General Concepts of Culture Media.text: Nutrients are incorporated into culture media on or in which bacteria grow
If media meets organism's nutritional requirements, then it multiplies until it can be seen by unaided eye
Different pathogenic organisms have different nutritional needs, necessitating different media types
Bacteria with complex nutritional needs are considered fastidious; those without such needs are considered nonfastidious

Definitions.text: Liquid (broth) media: Media in which nutrients are dissolved in water; bacterial growth is indicated by change in turbidity
Solid (agar) media: Media in which nutrients are dissolved into agar and then solidified; bacterial growth is indicated by formation of colonies on agar surface
Enrichment media: Media containing specific nutrients for growth of particular pathogen
Nutritive media: Media containing nutrients to support growth of most nonfastidious organisms
Selective media: Media containing one or more agents that are inhibitory to all except those selected by specific growth condition or chemical

Differential media: Media containing one or more factors that allow colonies of one bacterial species or type to exhibit certain metabolic or culture characteristics that distinguish it from other bacteria growing on same agar plate

Overview.text: Molecular techniques have advantages of sensitivity, specificity, and safety compared with live culture techniques
Organisms can be detected when unable to replicate in vitro

Limitations.text: Most molecular test cannot perform all tests necessary for identification and treatment of pathogen (e.g., techniques that identify pathogen may be unable to identify resistance profiles)
Molecular tests do not discriminate between live, replicating organisms and dead organisms

Advantages of Molecular Techniques for B.text: Molecular techniques have advantages of sensitivity, specificity, and safety compared with live culture techniques
Organisms can be detected when unable to replicate in vitro
No live organism is necessary for testing, preventing laboratory-associated infection
Newer testing platforms combine organism identification with identification of antibiotic-resistant markers (VRE, ESBL, and CRE)

Branched-Chain DNA Assay.text: Uses branched-chain DNA to amplify signal from single sample-probe reaction
Does not require PCR-based amplification of DNA or RNA

Isothermal Amplification.text: Includes LAMP or helicase-dependent amplification for DNA and NABS and transcription-mediated amplification for RNA
Has advantage of not requiring multiple temperatures to complete amplification

Microarray.text: Oligonucleotide probes synthesized at precise locations on glass or "chip"
Specimen DNA can be washed over chip, binding to complementary sequences
Pattern of binding determines pathogen present

Southern Blot and Reverse Hybridization.text: Southern blotSpecific nucleic acid sequences from clinical sample can be transferred to nitrocellulose filter and hybridized to complementary gene probe (DNA:DNA probe hybridization)
sub_points: Specific nucleic acid sequences from clinical sample can be transferred to nitrocellulose filter and hybridized to complementary gene probe (DNA:DNA probe hybridization)

Southern Blot and Reverse Hybridization.text: Reverse hybridizationGene probes are hybridized to nitrocellulose filterDNA from clinical sample is washed over probesIf complementary probe is on filter, clinical DNA will bind
sub_points: Gene probes are hybridized to nitrocellulose filter
DNA from clinical sample is washed over probes
If complementary probe is on filter, clinical DNA will bind

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR).text: 16S rDNA PCR is often used to identify bacterial sequences
In some organisms, 16S rDNA is too homogeneous to separate species
Other loci useful to identify bacterial specieshsp65(for mycobacteria)rpoB(for mycobacteria)
sub_points: hsp65(for mycobacteria)
rpoB(for mycobacteria)

Nested PCR.text: PCR involving sequential use of 2 primer sets to increase sensitivity and specificity for specific organisms

Multiplex PCR.text: Single PCR reaction with multiple primers
May be used to provide internal control for amplification or to identify multiple, clinically relevant species in 1 reaction

Digital PCR.text: Real-time PCR method in which each reaction is carried out in separate droplet or region, allowing for direct quantitation of specimens based on counting number of positive droplets/regions
Very sensitive; can detect pathogens present at very low concentrations

Melting Curve Analysis.text: Analyzes sequence of PCR product by measuring melting temperature
PCR product is combined with probes and heated gradually
When probes dissociate, fluorescence is generated

Temperature at which probes dissociate (Tm) depends on nucleotide composition of PCR productMore mismatches mean lower TmFewer mismatches mean higher TmMore A:T base pairs mean lower TmMore G:C base pairs mean higher TmUsed to verify specificity of PCR reaction
sub_points: More mismatches mean lower Tm
Fewer mismatches mean higher Tm
More A:T base pairs mean lower Tm
More G:C base pairs mean higher Tm
Used to verify specificity of PCR reaction

Sanger Sequencing.text: Method of DNA sequencing based on selective incorporation of chain terminating dideoxynucleotides by DNA polymerase during in vitro DNA replication

Next Generation Sequencing.text: Massively multiplexed sequencing that can sequence millions of individual molecules simultaneously

MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry.text: Organisms are inserted into instrument, ionized, and fragmented
Fragments travel through flight tube at speeds specific to their mass/charge ratio
Each fragment is graphically represented by its mass/charge ratio compared with all other fragments generated from that sample
Pattern of fragments can be compared with database of known organisms to generate match to specific species

Strain Typing Methods.text: All used to type bacterial strains for epidemiologic purposes
e.g.,spatyping, wherein single locus typing ofspagene is used to identify differentStaphylococcus aureusisolates

Direct Hybridization.text: Multiple commercially available kits exist to identify bacteria from clinical samples
e.g., detection of clinically relevantMycobacteriumspp. from direct patient samples

Microarrays.text: Can be used to identify numerous bacterial species in single reaction
Can be designed to detect specific polymorphisms or mutations

Southern Blot and Reverse Hybridization.text: Can be used to differentiate species within genus or to subtype species of bacteria or viruses (e.g., hepatitis C virus)

PCR.text: Used to identify organisms directly from patient samples
Used to speciate organisms from difficult to identify cultures

Nested PCR.text: Useful to identify organisms present at very low titer (e.g.,Histoplasmaspp.)

Multiplex PCR.text: Useful to detect multiple organisms in single reaction from direct patient samples (e.g., FilmArray)
Useful to detect presence of specific genes within organism (e.g.,mecAinS. aureusisolates)

Digital PCR.text: Can be used to identify organisms present at very low concentrations in patient samples

Melting Curve Analysis.text: Can be used to identify specific species (e.g., separateMycobacterium tuberculosisfrom otherMycobacteriumspp.) or specific mutations

Sanger Sequencing.text: Used to specifically speciate bacterial isolates by sequence

NGS.text: Used to identify multiple bacterial species in single specimen

MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry.text: Quickly becoming most commonly used technique for bacterial identification in many clinical microbiology laboratories

Morphokinetic Cellular Analysis.text: Tracks phenotypic features, including size, shape, and division rate of individual live cells growing into micro-colonies while being challenged by antibiotics to provide antibiotic susceptibility results

Overall Limitations of Molecular Approac.text: Most molecular test cannot perform all tests necessary for identification and treatment of pathogen (e.g., techniques that identify pathogen may be unable to identify resistance profiles)
Molecular tests do not discriminate between live, replicating organisms and dead organisms
High specificity of many molecular methods means that only a few potential organisms can be evaluated at one timeNot necessarily true of more "universal" techniques, such as microarray or NGS
sub_points: Not necessarily true of more "universal" techniques, such as microarray or NGS

Overall Limitations of Molecular Approac.text: Molecular tests requiring amplification are often easy to contaminate
Small changes in organism can result in loss of primer or probe binding and false-negative results
Various substances in patient samples can interfere with reagents and conditions required for optimal hybridization and amplification

Strain Typing Methods.text: Many techniques are labor-intensive and time-consuming

Direct Hybridization.text: Cost-prohibitive to look for all possible organismsAt least general idea of which organism is sought must be known
sub_points: At least general idea of which organism is sought must be known

PCR.text: May amplify multiple bacterial sequences if general primers used

Nested PCR.text: May produce false-negative results if DNA used for 1st PCR reaction has mismatch in primer binding sequence

Multiplex PCR.text: Difficult to design primers and probes such that PCR efficiency is approximately equal for all possible combinations

Sanger Sequencing.text: Cannot be performed on mixed specimens

NGS.text: May identify bacterial sequence contaminants present in reagents
Identifications are only as sensitive as databases queriedIf organism is not in database, it will not be identified
sub_points: If organism is not in database, it will not be identified

MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry.text: Requires cultivated organism, as testing is most commonly done on colonies

Morphokinetic Cellular Analysis.text: Susceptibility results are limited to select number of antibiotics

Quality in Clinical Microbiology Laborat.text: Quality: Production of accurate reports in minimum required time with minimum required work so as to maximize patient value and improve patient outcomes
Basic tenets of quality in clinical microbiology laboratoryTotal quality managementContinuous quality improvementProcess improvementQuality assurance
sub_points: Total quality management
Continuous quality improvement
Process improvement
Quality assurance

Definitions.text: Continuous quality improvement (CQI): System that seeks to improve service delivery with emphasis on future results
LEAN: Methodology that concentrates on identifying what creates value for client, eliminating redundant motion, and recognizing waste
Quality assurance (QA): Planned and systematic activities designed to maintain quality requirements for product or service
Quality control (QC): Activities designed to ensure diagnostic test accuracy and precision
Six Sigma: Methodology that reduces defects by minimizing variation in processes through metric measurement
Total quality management (TQM): Activity to improve patient care by monitoring work of laboratory to detect and correct deficiencies

Patient Outcomes Associated with Quality.text: Decreased time to initiation of appropriate antibiotics

Regulatory Agencies.text: US federal government implements and monitors laboratory conformance to CLIA of 1988, US federal regulatory standards that apply to clinical laboratory testing performed on humansCMS: Agency that administers Medicare and is responsible for certification and survey of clinical laboratoriesFDA: Agency that classifies all medical devices and is responsible for classification of in vitro diagnostics methods and instruments, and determines whether test is classified as waived, moderate complexity, or high complexityOSHA: Agency that determines measures necessary to ensure employee health and safety in laboratoryEPA: Agency that determines regulation of chemical hazardous waste in laboratories
sub_points: CMS: Agency that administers Medicare and is responsible for certification and survey of clinical laboratories

Maintenance of Reference QC Stocks.text: Nonfastidious, aerobic bacterial organisms: Saved up to 1 year on trypticase soy agar slants

Long-term storage of bacteria: Accomplished by lyophilization (freeze-drying) or by freezing at -70ºCThese organisms should be thawed, reisolated, and refrozen every 5 years if nonfastidious and every 3 years if fastidious
sub_points: These organisms should be thawed, reisolated, and refrozen every 5 years if nonfastidious and every 3 years if fastidious

Maintenance of Reference QC Stocks.text: Molds: Stock on potato dextrose agar slants for up to 1 year, or longer if overlaid with mineral oil
Acid-fast bacilli: Store on Löwenstein-Jensen agar slants at 4ºC for up to 1 year or frozen in 7H9 broth at -70ºC for longer storage
Viruses: Store indefinitely at -70ºC in a solution containing cryoprotectant, such as 10% dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) or fetal bovine serum
Parasite slides: Preserve indefinitely by adding drop of Permount and coverslip

LEAN.text: Major feature of LEAN is organizing laboratory such that unnecessary movements are eliminated during completion of task

Proficiency Testing.text: Laboratories are required to participate in PT for every analyte for which program is available
Laboratories must maintain average score of at least 80% on PT to maintain licensure in subspecialty area

QA Audits.text: Performed to evaluate the preanalytic, analytic, and postanalytic aspects of testing in laboratory
Can be performed by outside agency (such as CAP) or may be initiated internally

Patient Reports.text: “Panic values” should be reported to clinicians immediatelyInclude positive CSF gram stains or positive blood cultures
sub_points: Include positive CSF gram stains or positive blood cultures

Patient Reports.text: Reports require supervisory review to ensure that conclusions are correct and no clerical errors are made
Reports should only be issued by individuals legally permitted to receive them (physicians and various midlevel providers)
Reference ranges should be included where appropriate
All patient records required to be maintained for at least 2 yearsIn reality, at least 10 years is required to support practices in event of postpayment billing audit
sub_points: In reality, at least 10 years is required to support practices in event of postpayment billing audit

Overview.text: Most microbiological work-ups include stepwise testing of organisms using biochemical or phenotypic tests
Result of each test determines next test performed, until satisfactory diagnosis is made

Laboratory Methods.text: Results of Gram stain determine which media is chosen for cultivation and which test is chosen as initial step in identification

Identification by Algorithm.text: Most microbiological work-ups include stepwise testing of organisms using biochemical or phenotypic tests
Result of each test determines the next test performed, until satisfactory diagnosis is made

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Staphylococcusspecies found widely on skin and mucous membranes of humans and animals; divided into coagulase-positive (S.aureus) and coagulase-negative (major species:S.epidermidis)
S.aureus:Skin and soft tissue infections, bloodstream infection, endocarditis, pneumonia, osteomyelitis, toxin-mediated diseases include TSS, SSSS, and food poisoning
Coagulase-negativeStaphylococcus(CoNS): Intravascular catheter and device-/material-related infections and endocarditis
With routine use of MALDI in diagnostic laboratories, many species will be diagnosed, which were formerly called CoNS
Rapid molecular platforms are available to detect presence ofS. aureusand CoNS directly from primary specimens and positive blood bottles (as well as to identify methicillin-resistantS. aureus)

Microscopic.text: Gram and silver stains highlight gram-positive cocci
SSSS: Sloughed stratum corneum, regular, smooth keratinocytes, absence of inflammation
TSS: Spongiotic reaction with neutrophils, scattered necrotic keratinocytes, edematous dermis
Impetigo: Subcorneal pustules with neutrophils and acantholytic cells
Endocarditis: Defective/mechanical and native valves; large (> 1-cm) vegetations; septic emboli and mycotic aneurysms
Pneumonia: Necrotic lesions with abscess formation
Osteomyelitis: Neutrophils adjacent to bony trabeculae with erosive changes

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Toxic epidermal necrolysis: Effects entire epidermis vs. SSSS, which only involves stratum corneum
Pemphigus foliaceus: Lacks organisms, which differentiates from impetigo

Endocarditis, pneumonia, osteomyelitis, cellulitis, and necrotizing fasciitis can be caused by organisms other thanS. aureus(or as copathogens); specific organisms identified by Gram and silver stains, culture, PCR

Definitions.text: Greek: "Staphyle" (grape) + "kokkus" (grain, seed)

Infectious Agents.text: Staphylococcusspecies found widely on skin and mucous membranes of humans and animals; hardy in multiple environments and can survive on surfaces for months
Split into coagulase-positive and coagulase-negative species

Coagulase-positive staphylococciS. aureusis major pathogen; often colonizes naresVirulence factors: Coagulase, hyaluronidase, lipase, enterotoxin type B, TSST-1, exfoliative toxins, alpha toxin, beta toxin, delta toxin, Panton-Valentine leukocidinEnterotoxin type B (gastroenteritis) and TSST-1 [toxic shock syndrome (TSS)] are both superantigens, producing symptoms via induction of severe immune responseExfoliative toxins A (chromosomal) and B (plasmid-borne) are responsible for staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)They are serine proteases, which assume active conformation upon contact with their substrate, desmogelin-1Panton-Valentine leukocidin is associated with increased virulence in community strains of MRSA and development of necrotic lesions of skin and mucous membranes as well as necrotizing pneumoniaComposed of 2 proteins encoded by prophage and causes pore formation in neutrophils, resulting in release of inflammatory mediators, degradative enzymes, and superoxide radicals
sub_points: S. aureusis major pathogen; often colonizes nares

Infectious Agents.text: Majority of methicillin resistance mediated by PBP2a, penicillin-binding protein with reduced affinity for most β-lactam antibiotics; PBP2a is encoded by gene mecA (rarely, MecC)

Epidemiology.text: S.aureusis one of most common pathogens in both nosocomial and community-acquired infectionsRisk factors include male sex, extremes of age, dialysis, diabetes, cancer, rheumatoid arthritis, HIV infection, IV drug use and alcohol abuse, defects in phagocytosis and chemotaxisHighly clonal (particularly MRSA) with most pandemic strains linking back to 3 clonal complexes (CC5, CC8, and CC30)MRSA is common in both hospital and community (59% in ICU patients, 55% in non-ICU patients, 48% in outpatients)Carriage is most important predisposing factor for infection; large percentage of population (> 50%) either persistently or intermittentlyCommunity-acquired (CA-MRSA) and healthcare-acquired (HCA-MRSA)S. aureusstrains are responsible for distinct clinical syndromes

Highly clonal (particularly MRSA) with most pandemic strains linking back to 3 clonal complexes (CC5, CC8, and CC30)
MRSA is common in both hospital and community (59% in ICU patients, 55% in non-ICU patients, 48% in outpatients)
Carriage is most important predisposing factor for infection; large percentage of population (> 50%) either persistently or intermittently
Community-acquired (CA-MRSA) and healthcare-acquired (HCA-MRSA)S. aureusstrains are responsible for distinct clinical syndromes

bright red skin on head, which then spreads downward toward extremities (with constitutional symptoms)Gastroenteritis: Improperly stored prepared food, particularly dairy; toxin can remain active under conditions that kill organism; Folliculitis: Nodule centered on hair follicle, which may have apparent pus, may evolve into large furuncles
Carbuncles: Collections of furuncles and may demonstrate several openings to discharge pus
Impetigo: Pustules or bullae with honey-colored crusting and negative Nikolsky sign; often occurs as complication of other dermatoses, typically on face
Cellulitis: Painful, bright red macules or plaques, which can demonstrate scaling and ulceration over time

Necrotizing fasciitis: Typically presents subsequent to trauma with pain out of proportion to clinical findings; fever, malaise, and myalgias follow, and pain can eventually progress to anesthesia, considered surgical emergency

Laboratory Tests.text: Serologic testing for antistaphylococcal antibodies does not play role in diagnosis due to lack of specificity
PCR/sequencing of 16S rRNA andrpoBgenes for speciation of culture isolates and frozen or formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue

Treatment.text: Necrotizing fasciitis requires emergent drainage and debridement
Removal of infected hardware &/or devices
MRSA can account for 50-60% of staphylococci in USA hospitals; vancomycin and linezolid are often used to treat infections in these settings
CA-MRSA tends to carry fewer resistance determinants to other drugs than HCA-MRSA does
CoNS antibiotic susceptibility varies by species (many are resistant to multiple drugs)

Prognosis.text: Variable by species and site of infection
S. aureus:Toxin-mediated disease mortality ranges from very low in food poisoning to quite high in adult SSSS (> 50%) or CA-MRSA necrotizing pneumonia (60%)
CoNS: Mortality is highest withS. lugdunensisendocarditis (50-70%) and is generally low with most other manifestations

Morphologic/Biochemical.text: Catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters
All are facultative anaerobes, except for anaerobic speciesS. saccharolyticusandS. aureussubspeciesanaerobius
Grows in temperature range from 18-40 °C; tolerates 10% NaCl

Culture.text: Staphylococci are usually isolated on blood agar platesS. aureusappears as smooth, creamy, yellowish to orange colonies, while CoNS are often nonpigmentedS. aureususually demonstrates β-hemolysis, while CoNS are generally nonhemolytic (except forS. hemolyticusandS. lugdunensis)
sub_points: S. aureusappears as smooth, creamy, yellowish to orange colonies, while CoNS are often nonpigmented
S. aureususually demonstrates β-hemolysis, while CoNS are generally nonhemolytic (except forS. hemolyticusandS. lugdunensis)

Culture.text: Selective agars forS. aureusinclude mannitol salt agar, egg yolk-tellurite pyruvate containing Baird-Parker medium, Columbia colistin-nalidixic acid agar, lipase-salt-mannitol agar, and phenylethyl alcohol agar
Also several chromogenic agars available (including those that can differentiate MRSA)

Microbiological Identification.text: Organisms presumptively identified as staphylococci if catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci
Coagulase production differentiatesS. aureusfrom most CoNS (exceptS. lugdunensis: Coagulase positive, clumping factor negative)
Within CoNS, pathogenicS. saprophyticusis differentiated by resistance to novobiocin
With routine use of MALDI-TOF MS in diagnostic laboratories, many species will be diagnosed, which were formerly called "CoNS"
Rapid molecular platforms are available to detect presence ofS. aureusand CoNS directly from primary specimens and positive blood bottles (as well as to identify MRSA)
S. aureus, as well as many species of CoNS, can be identified by gram-positive card on Vitek 2 (BioMérieux) automated platform
API Staph strip (BioMérieux), consisting of 19 reactions, is also used within clinical laboratories to differentiate staphylococcal species (can distinguish 20)

Histologic Features.text: S. aureusSSSS: Sloughed stratum corneum, keratinocytes regular and smooth with occasional acantholytic cells, inflammation is not present; mediated by toxin, thus, organisms are not presentTSS: Spongiotic reaction with neutrophils and scattered necrotic keratinocytes over edematous dermis, superficial perivascular and mixed cell infiltrate with neutrophils and possibly eosinophils; pustular or necrotic vasculitis and neutrophilic abscesses may be present; mediated by toxin, thus, no organisms presentImpetigo: Subcorneal pustules with variable numbers of neutrophils and acantholytic cells; cocci may be presentFolliculitis, furuncles, and carbuncles: Inflammatory cells, predominantly neutrophils, centered on 1 or several hair folliclesCellulitis: Edema in dermis and subcuticular regions and dilated blood vessels and lymphatics, diffuse infiltrate of neutrophils; organisms are very rarely observedChronic cellulitis: Spongiosis of epidermis with vesicles, pustules, ulceration, and necrosis ± fibrosisNecrotizing fasciitis: Fascia and deep soft tissue necrosis, hemorrhage, thrombosis, and secondary vasculitisEndocarditis:S. aureuscan colonize both defective/mechanical and native valves (often damaging them); relatively large (> 1-cm) vegetations; often results in septic emboli and mycotic aneurysmsPneumonia: Primary pneumonia or as sequelae of influenza; necrotic lesions with abscess formation, which may metastasize to distant organs or rupture into pleural space, causing empyema; clusters of organisms may be seenOsteomyelitis: Neutrophils adjacent to bony trabeculae with erosive changes; organisms may be seen
sub_points: SSSS: Sloughed stratum corneum, keratinocytes regular and smooth with occasional acantholytic cells, inflammation is not present; mediated by toxin, thus, organisms are not present

TSS: Spongiotic reaction with neutrophils and scattered necrotic keratinocytes over edematous dermis, superficial perivascular and mixed cell infiltrate with neutrophils and possibly eosinophils; pustular or necrotic vasculitis and neutrophilic abscesses may be present; mediated by toxin, thus, no organisms present
Impetigo: Subcorneal pustules with variable numbers of neutrophils and acantholytic cells; cocci may be present
Folliculitis, furuncles, and carbuncles: Inflammatory cells, predominantly neutrophils, centered on 1 or several hair follicles
Cellulitis: Edema in dermis and subcuticular regions and dilated blood vessels and lymphatics, diffuse infiltrate of neutrophils; organisms are very rarely observed
Chronic cellulitis: Spongiosis of epidermis with vesicles, pustules, ulceration, and necrosis ± fibrosis
Necrotizing fasciitis: Fascia and deep soft tissue necrosis, hemorrhage, thrombosis, and secondary vasculitis
Endocarditis:S. aureuscan colonize both defective/mechanical and native valves (often damaging them); relatively large (> 1-cm) vegetations; often results in septic emboli and mycotic aneurysms

Pneumonia: Primary pneumonia or as sequelae of influenza; necrotic lesions with abscess formation, which may metastasize to distant organs or rupture into pleural space, causing empyema; clusters of organisms may be seen
Osteomyelitis: Neutrophils adjacent to bony trabeculae with erosive changes; organisms may be seen

Histologic Features.text: CoNSLesser degree of pus and necrosis compares toS. aureusinfectionsColonized devices and catheters usually appear to be coated with tan, fibrinous material and microscopically demonstrate clusters of cocci with acute inflammatory infiltrates
sub_points: Lesser degree of pus and necrosis compares toS. aureusinfections
Colonized devices and catheters usually appear to be coated with tan, fibrinous material and microscopically demonstrate clusters of cocci with acute inflammatory infiltrates

Immunohistochemistry.text: Not widely used due to cross reactivity between species; may be available at reference laboratories

Special Stains.text: Tissue Gram stain highlights gram-positive cocci in pairs or clusters; gram positivity may be weak or absent due to staining quality or antibiotic treatment effects
Methenamine silver stains can highlight cocci with negative Gram staining; may be difficult to interpret if high background is present

Other Causes of Endocarditis.text: Streptococcal and enterococcal endocarditis: Less severe course, less suppurative reaction; causative organism identified by culture or PCR
Noninfectious endocarditis: Lack of inflammatory reaction, no visible organisms, and negative cultures

Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis.text: Effects entire epidermis vs. SSSS, which only involves stratum corneum

Pemphigus Foliaceus.text: Lacks organisms, which differentiates from impetigo

Other Bacterial Skin and Soft Tissue Inf.text: Cellulitis and necrotizing fasciitis can be caused by organisms other thanS. aureus(or as copathogens); specific organisms identified by Gram and silver stains, culture, PCR

Clinical Correlates.text: Clinical diseases caused byS. pyogenes: Localized infections of respiratory system and skin; systemic infections; toxin-mediated diseases; poststreptococcal diseases including rheumatic fever, Sydenham chorea, PANDAS, acute glomerulonephritis

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Point-of-care antigen detection tests only 60-95% sensitive forS. pyogenesinfection; negative results should be confirmed with culture
Bacitracin sensitivity, TMP-SMX resistance, and PYR positivity sufficient for identification ofS. pyogenesamong catalase-negative streptococci

Spectrum of Disease.text: Localized infectionRespiratory infectionsPharyngitis (a.k.a. strep throat)PneumoniaSkin infectionsImpetigo (a.k.a. pyoderma)ErysipelasCellulitisNecrotizing fasciitis and myositis

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infection withBacillusspp., gram-positive bacilli widely present in environment; spores are extremely resistant and have been found in virtually every habitat

Clinical Issues.text: B.anthracis(anthrax) has 3 clinical types: Cutaneous (95%), pulmonary (5%), and gastrointestinal (1%)
B.cereus: Opportunistic pathogen and causative agent of food-borne illness and occasional nosocomial outbreaks
B.thuringiensis: Predominantly insect pathogen, uncommon cause of gastroenteritis and wound and burn infections

Microbiology.text: Culture is gold standard for diagnosis; medium, gray, flat, irregular (Medusa head), nonhemolytic colonies

Microscopic.text: Gram-positive bacilli (1.2 μm wide) highlighted by Gram, Silver, and IHC stains
Pulmonary anthrax: Pleural effusions, pulmonary edema, and hyaline membrane formation
Lymphatics anthrax: Hemorrhagic mediastinitis
Cutaneous anthrax: Epidermal necrosis, hemorrhage, acantholysis, and ulceration; dermal edema, coagulation necrosis, hemorrhage, and vasculitis
CNS anthrax: Low- and high-pressure hemorrhages along with vasculitis composed of fibrinoid necrosis and neutrophils in meninges and parenchyma

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Skin lesions mimicking cutaneous anthrax: Brown recluse spider bite, ulceroglandular tularemia, plague, ecthyma gangrenosum, spotted fever rickettsial infection, scrub typhus (differentiated by culture and IHC)
Gastrointestinal Infections:Clostridioides difficileinfection, inflammatory bowel disease, ischemia
Respiratory Infections: Pneumonia, transfusion-associated acute lung injury

Synonyms.text: Charbon, Siberian plague, splenic fever, Cumberland disease, malignant edema, woolsorter's disease, la maladie de Bradford

Definitions.text: Bacillus anthracisderived from Latin "bacillum" (walking stick due to rod-shaped organism) and Greek "anthrakos" (coal, referring to black eschars from cutaneous Anthrax)

Infectious Agents.text: Infection withBacillusspecies, gram-positive bacilli widely present in environment; spores are extremely resistant and have been found in virtually every habitat
Spore contamination can underlie both true outbreaks and pseudooutbreaks (i.e., contaminated blood culture bottles)
Bacillus anthracis,Bacilluscereus, andBacillusthuringiensisare most clinically relevant species, collectively as "B. cereusgroup"

B. anthracisinfection occurs naturally by contact with infected animals and animal products (e.g., hides) as well as through laboratory accidents, biological warfare, and contaminated heroin; contains 2 large plasmids (pXO1 and pXO2) that encode virulence factors (lethal toxin, edema toxin) and polyglutamate capsule

B. cereusassociated with food-borne illness and transmitted by contaminated laundry and disinfectant wipes can occur within hospital environment; produces plasmid-encoded emetic toxin and enterotoxin; virulent strains may carry plasmids similar toB. anthracis
B. thuringiensisused as biopesticides, which can result in occupational exposure; produces insecticidal toxins (Cry and Cyt) that form parasporal crystals

Species less commonly associated with clinical syndrome includeBacilluscirculans,Bacillus licheniformis,Bacillus megaterium,Bacillus pumilus,Bacillus sphaericus, andBacillussubtilis; may represent blood culture contaminants

Laboratory Tests.text: Serology: Antibodies to anthrax toxin proteins, protective antigen (PA) lethal factor (LF), and edema factor (EF) are commercially available and have been used for ELISA testing of patient serum and direct fluorescent-antibody (DFA) assays

Treatment.text: B.anthracis: Usually susceptible to penicillin (other useful drugs include tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, and chloramphenicol)

B. cereusandB. thuringiensisProduce β-lactamases, resistant to all β-lactams except carbapenemsOptions include vancomycin, clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, and carbapenemsSusceptibilities should be performed onBacillusspp. (nonanthracis) isolated from sterile body sites or in serious infection; not performed when thought to be contaminant

Prognosis.text: B. cereusmortality varies widely with immunocompetency of patient

Characteristics.text: Gram-positive (though some may appear gram variable or even gram negative), large rod-shaped organism (~ 1.2 μm wide), frequently present in chains
Forms endospores (usually elliptical and subterminal, not associated with swollen sporangium inB. anthracis,B. cereus, orB. thuringiensis); highlighted by spore stains (e.g., malachite green)

Capsule (not produced by majority ofB. cereusandB. thuringiensisisolates) identified by India ink exclusion, McFadyean reaction (polychrome methylene blue), and DFA stains with antibodies specific for polyglutamate capsule
B. thuringiensisalso characteristically produces parasporal crystals
Catalase positive, often motile (exceptB. anthracisandB. mycoides); any nonmotile, nonhemolytic, catalase-positive, gram-positive rods presumedB. anthracisuntil ruled out

Culture.text: Culture identification is gold standard for diagnosis
Bacillusspp. grow on routine blood and chocolate agar
Spores can be generated by heat treatment

B. anthracisForms medium, gray, flat, irregular (Medusa head), nonhemolytic colonies on blood agar that are susceptible to gamma phageMay be incorrectly or not identified by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI)Categorized as tier 1 select agent: Once identified, must be transferred to laboratory registered by CDC or Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS); remaining material must be destroyed within 7 daysPLET agar can be used for selective media (not routinely available in diagnostic laboratories)
sub_points: Forms medium, gray, flat, irregular (Medusa head), nonhemolytic colonies on blood agar that are susceptible to gamma phage
May be incorrectly or not identified by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI)

Categorized as tier 1 select agent: Once identified, must be transferred to laboratory registered by CDC or Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS); remaining material must be destroyed within 7 days
PLET agar can be used for selective media (not routinely available in diagnostic laboratories)

Culture.text: B. cereusandB. thuringiensisForm variety of colony morphologies on blood agar, generally motileOften demonstrate some β-hemolysis (differentiates fromB. anthracis)MALDI may identify to species level if validated (varies by institution)
sub_points: Form variety of colony morphologies on blood agar, generally motile
Often demonstrate some β-hemolysis (differentiates fromB. anthracis)
MALDI may identify to species level if validated (varies by institution)

Gross Features.text: Diffuse hemorrhagic meninges is pathognomic of anthrax
DisseminatedB. cereusshows small to large focal hemorrhages
Pleural effusions (most characteristic feature of anthrax) and pulmonary edema
Lymphatogenous spread from lungs results in hemorrhagic mediastinitis in anthrax ("shotgun thorax")

Histologic Features.text: Cutaneous anthrax: Epidermal necrosis, hemorrhage, acantholysis, and ulceration with polymorphonuclear infiltrates; dermis shows edema, coagulation necrosis, hemorrhage, and vasculitis with marked perivascular inflammatory infiltrate
Pulmonary anthrax has hyaline membrane formation more so than true pneumonia with limited neutrophilic reaction
Gastrointestinal anthrax has 2 main forms: Hemorrhagic ulcers confined to oropharyngeal region and concentrated in terminal ileum and cecum with mesenteric hemorrhagic lymphadenitis and peritonitis
B. cereusinfection shows liver abscesses, pancolitis, typhlitis
Central nervous system anthrax with low- and high-pressure hemorrhages along with vasculitis composed of fibrinoid necrosis and neutrophils in meninges and parenchyma
Central nervous systemB. cereusinfection in immunosuppressed patients (usually in setting of malignancy) with meningitis, meningoencephalitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and brain abscesses

Special Stains.text: Gram stain highlights bacilli (may appear gram negative after antibiotic treatment)
Silver stains (Warthin-Starry, Steiner), GMS, and PAS with diastase may better highlight organisms in tissue

Immunohistochemistry.text: Antibodies forB. anthraciscell wall antigen and capsule highlight bacilli, bacillary fragments, and granular antigen staining

Skin Lesions Mimicking Cutaneous Anthrax.text: Brown recluse spider bite, ulceroglandular tularemia, plague, ecthyma gangrenosum, spotted fever rickettsial infection, scrub typhus (differentiated by culture and IHC)

Gastrointestinal Infections.text: Clostridioides difficileinfection, inflammatory bowel disease, ischemia

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Corynebacteria are practically split betweenCorynebacteriumdiphtheriaeand all other species, collectively known as diphtheroids
C. diphtheriae: Respiratory disease, cardiac involvement, muscle paralysis, and ulcerative skin lesions; caused by toxin encoded byTOXgene
Diphtheroids: Pharyngitis, endocarditis, genitourinary tract infections, prostatitis, periodontal infections, and line-associated, device-related, and surgical site infections

Microbiology.text: Grow on 5% sheep blood agar; speciated by API CORYNE system (bioMérieux), MALDI-TOF MS, and 16S rRNA sequencing
Since (nondiphtheria group) corynebacteria are prevalent as skin commensals, it is important to differentiate pathogens from contaminants

Microscopic.text: Diphtheria (C. diphtheriae): Respiratory pseudomembrane on tonsils and pharynx; cutaneous ulcer with dense cap
Erythrasma (C. minutissimum): Organisms often visible in stratum corneum; minimal host response
Cystic granulomatous neutrophilic mastitis with diphtheroids demonstrable in cystic spaces
Gram stain demonstrates gram-positive rods with slight curve and club shape

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Anthrax and noninfectious ulcers: Epidermal necrosis, hemorrhage, acantholysis, and ulceration with polymorphonuclear infiltrates; cutaneous diphtheria differentiated by identification of corynebacteria
Yeast and fungal infections: Dermal inflammation with fungal elements in stratum corneum highlighted by PAS or GMS stains; erythrasma differentiated by identification of corynebacteria

Definitions.text: Greek: "Korune" (club, club-shaped morphology)
Greek: "Diphthera" (pair of leather scrolls, for pseudomembrane appearance)

Infectious Agents.text: Infection with corynebacteria, gram-positive bacilli split intoCorynebacterium diphtheriaegroup and diphtheroids (all other species), via respiratory droplets or contact with skin lesions

C. diphtheriae3 subtypes:C. d. gravis,C. d. intermedius, andC. d. mitis, in decreasing order of pathogenicityManifestations of disease are caused by toxin, encoded byTOXgene, encoded by lysogenic phageTOXgene is regulated by DtxR, transcriptional regulator that inhibits toxin production in presence of ferrous iron; toxin is produced in low-iron environmentsUpon adherence of bacteria to epithelial cells (particularly, but not limited to, respiratory epithelium), toxin gains access to host cell cytoplasm and inactivates EF-2, causing cell deathWidespread toxin-mediated necrosis leads to characteristic thick, adherent, leathery "membrane" of diphtheria, composed of bacteria, necrotic epithelium, fibrin, and inflammatory cellsOther systemic aspects of disease (e.g., myocarditis) result from dissemination of toxin rather than hematogenous spread of bacteriaStrains ofC. diphtheriaethat do not produce toxin (but may encode it) are increasingly associated with disease; mechanisms of their pathogenicity are poorly understoodC. ulceransandC. pseudotuberculosisare part ofC. diphtheriaegroup (zoonotic, possibly toxigenic)
sub_points: 3 subtypes:C. d. gravis,C. d. intermedius, andC. d. mitis, in decreasing order of pathogenicity
Manifestations of disease are caused by toxin, encoded byTOXgene, encoded by lysogenic phage
TOXgene is regulated by DtxR, transcriptional regulator that inhibits toxin production in presence of ferrous iron; toxin is produced in low-iron environments
Upon adherence of bacteria to epithelial cells (particularly, but not limited to, respiratory epithelium), toxin gains access to host cell cytoplasm and inactivates EF-2, causing cell death
Widespread toxin-mediated necrosis leads to characteristic thick, adherent, leathery "membrane" of diphtheria, composed of bacteria, necrotic epithelium, fibrin, and inflammatory cells
Other systemic aspects of disease (e.g., myocarditis) result from dissemination of toxin rather than hematogenous spread of bacteria
Strains ofC. diphtheriaethat do not produce toxin (but may encode it) are increasingly associated with disease; mechanisms of their pathogenicity are poorly understood
C. ulceransandC. pseudotuberculosisare part ofC. diphtheriaegroup (zoonotic, possibly toxigenic)

Infectious Agents.text: Diphtheroids: Many species colonize skin; clinically relevant species includeC. jeikeium,C. glucuronolyticum,C. minutissimum,C. pseudodiphtheriticum,C. striatum, andC. urealyticum

Epidemiology.text: C. diphtheriaeis extremely uncommon in USAIncreasing use of matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) in diagnostic laboratories may identifyC. diphtheriaand other potentially toxigenic species, which would not have been speciated/identified using traditional methods and algorithmsRisk factors include extremes of age, nonvaccinated status, migrant from endemic area (e.g., India)Route of infection is by airborne respiratory droplets or contact with respiratory excretions or skin lesions (humans are sole reservoir)

Risk factors include extremes of age, nonvaccinated status, migrant from endemic area (e.g., India)
Route of infection is by airborne respiratory droplets or contact with respiratory excretions or skin lesions (humans are sole reservoir)

Epidemiology.text: Diphtheroids: Risk factors include extremes of age, compromised immune system, residence in hospital; growing recognition as agents of device-associated infection

Presentation.text: C. diphtheriae(causative agent of diphtheria)Respiratory disease often occurs 2-4 days after exposure (cough, hoarseness, sore throat, dyspnea, odynophagia); tonsils may be enlarged and associated with grayish-white membranesCardiac involvement (due to toxin) manifests 1-2 weeks after infection with arrhythmias and symptoms of congestive heart failureNeurologic involvement can occur at any time and typically begins with bulbar symptoms; may progress to proximal then distal muscle paralysisCutaneous infections present as vesicles that progress to nonhealing ulcers (mm to cm in size)
sub_points: Respiratory disease often occurs 2-4 days after exposure (cough, hoarseness, sore throat, dyspnea, odynophagia); tonsils may be enlarged and associated with grayish-white membranes
Cardiac involvement (due to toxin) manifests 1-2 weeks after infection with arrhythmias and symptoms of congestive heart failure
Neurologic involvement can occur at any time and typically begins with bulbar symptoms; may progress to proximal then distal muscle paralysis
Cutaneous infections present as vesicles that progress to nonhealing ulcers (mm to cm in size)

Presentation.text: DiphtheroidsCommunity-acquired infections include pharyngitis, native valve endocarditis, genitourinary tract infections, acute and chronic prostatitis, mastitis, and periodontal infectionsNosocomial infections include line-associated infections, native and prosthetic valve endocarditis, device-related infections, and surgical site infectionsC. striatum: Emerging multidrug-resistant organism implicated in pneumonia, sepsis, etc.; usually in immunocompromised patientsC. minutissimum: Associated with erythrasma and, rarely, septicemia and endocarditis in vulnerable patientsC.amycolatum: Historically confused with several other species; rarely associated with wide variety of infections in vulnerable patientsC. glucuronolyticum: Normal genitourinary flora; associated with chronic prostatitisC. pseudodiphtheriticum: Normal upper respiratory flora; associated with endocarditis, respiratory infections, and othersC. jeikeium: Associated with nosocomial infections (can be severe), such as septicemia, endocarditis, CSF shunt infections, meningitis, skin and soft tissue infections, prosthetic joint infections, etc.C. urealyticum: Chronic and recurrent urinary tract infections in vulnerable populationsC. kroppenstedtii: Granulomatous mastitis associated with recurrent abscesses

C. kroppenstedtii: Granulomatous mastitis associated with recurrent abscesses

Treatment.text: Diphtheroids: Preferred antibiotics differ by species; some are highly resistant to multiple classes

Prognosis.text: C.diphtheriae: Mortality ranges from 3.5-12.0%; highest at extremes of age and in unvaccinated individuals

Morphologic and Biochemical Characterist.text: Cells are aerobic, nonspore forming, catalase positive, and nonmotile
With 50 medically relevant species, there is great deal of diversity in biochemical profile of corynebacteria
Cell wall is distinct, containing mesodiaminopimelic acid and short-chain mycolic acids 22-36 carbons in length in many, but not all, species
Gram stain demonstrates gram-positive rods with slight curve and club shape
Arrangement is in "V"s or palisades with what has been termed pile of matchsticks appearance

Culture.text: Grow on 5% sheep blood agar
Selective media: Cysteine-tellurite blood agar (CTBA) and Tinsdale media (differentiates diphtheria group from diphtheroids by formation of brown-black halos from tellurite reduction)

Microbiological Identification.text: MALDI (may not be present in standard libraries)
Gas chromatography of medium-length fatty acids with Sherlock system (MIDI) can assist with genus and possible species-level identifications
Sequencing of 16S rRNA gene can differentiate most species

Interpretation Guidelines.text: Since (nondiphtheria group) corynebacteria are prevalent as skin commensals, it is important to differentiate pathogens from contaminants

Guidelines have been proposed to indicate true disease association: Isolation from normally sterile sites (if blood, from > 1 bottle of multiple bottles), predominant organism from adequately collected clinical material, or from urine if > 10⁴/mL and only organism isolated or predominant organism and > 10⁵/mL

Clinical significance is strengthened by isolate recovered from > 1 specimen, organisms seen in direct Gram stains of tissue with inflammatory response, and no other pathogenic organisms observed in lesion

With cardiac involvement, heart appears dilated and pale

Darier Disease.text: Greasy hyperkeratotic papules in seborrheic regions with acantholysis and dyskeratosis; not associated with bacteria

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infection withListeria monocytogenesandListeria ivanovii, gram-positive bacilli widely present in environment as saprophytic organisms
Most infections are foodborne, associated with fruits and vegetables, deli meats, smoked meats, and unpasteurized milk and cheese; can multiply at refrigeration temperatures

Clinical Issues.text: Disease is most severe at extremes of age, in immunosuppressed patients, and in pregnant women
Febrile gastroenteritis, maternal-fetal/neonatal listeriosis, or bacteremia ± CNS involvement
Causes 1,600 illnesses and 260 deaths annually in USA; 83 outbreaks reported to CDC from 2012-2021

Microbiology.text: Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, facultative anaerobe shaped as short rods arranged as singles or short chains
Nonfastidious organisms that grow in wide temperature range (0-50 °C), typically isolated on blood agar, with small zone of β-hemolysis
Classified to species level by automated platforms, MALDI TOF MS, and 16S rRNA sequencing

Microscopic.text: Gram-positive bacilli highlighted by Gram and silver stains
CNS: Meningitis, encephalitis, and abscess
Liver: Granulomas and abscesses
Placenta: Acute villitis, abscesses and granulomas, and necrotizing acute chorioamnionitis

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Other causes of bacterial abscess and meningitis (e.g.,StreptococcuspneumoniaeandEscherichia coli): Differentiate by morphology on special stains, cultures, or molecular diagnosis

Definitions.text: Named after English surgeon Joseph Lister (1827-1912)

Infectious Agents.text: Infection withListeria monocytogenesandListeria ivanovii, gram-positive bacilli widely present in environment as saprophytic organisms
Most infections are foodborne, associated with fruits and vegetables, deli meats, smoked meats, and unpasteurized milk and cheese; can multiply at refrigeration temperatures
Invades CNS by transport across blood brain barrier within host immune cells, direct invasion of endothelial cells, and retrograde movement up axons of involved nerves
Virulence factors include large number of stress-response genes, allowing for survival in wide variety of environments

Facultative intracellular pathogen employing several virulence factors allowing it to escape from phagosome, replicate within host cell cytoplasm, and invade neighboring cellsListeriolysin O: Hemolytic and cytotoxic toxin, allows for survival within phagocytesInternalin: Cell surface protein, induces phagocytosisAct A: Induces actin polymerization to facilitate cell-to-cell spread
sub_points: Listeriolysin O: Hemolytic and cytotoxic toxin, allows for survival within phagocytes
Internalin: Cell surface protein, induces phagocytosis
Act A: Induces actin polymerization to facilitate cell-to-cell spread

Epidemiology.text: Disease is most severe at extremes of age, in immunosuppressed patients, and in pregnant women
Causes 1,600 illnesses and 260 deaths annually in USA
83 outbreaks reported in National Outbreak Reporting System (NORS) from 2012-2021

Presentation.text: Febrile gastroenteritis typically occurs in immunocompetent patients after 5-49 hour incubation

Maternal-fetal/neonatal listeriosis generally presents as bacteremia in mother, and may result in stillbirth or abortion in ~ 20% of pregnancies, preterm deliveryEarly disease (before delivery) disseminated microabscesses (granulomatosis infantiseptica) is typically fatal; pneumonia, meningitis, or bacteremiaLate disease (at time of delivery from uncomplicated pregnancy) manifests as meningitis
sub_points: Early disease (before delivery) disseminated microabscesses (granulomatosis infantiseptica) is typically fatal; pneumonia, meningitis, or bacteremia
Late disease (at time of delivery from uncomplicated pregnancy) manifests as meningitis

Presentation.text: Bacteremia ± CNS involvement in ~ 50% of patients: Meningitis, meningoencephalitis, rhomboencephalitis, and brain abscess
Cutaneous listeriosis may result from contact with infected animals (generally occupational) or, rarely, from hematogenous spread

Laboratory Tests.text: CSF analysis: With meningitis/meningoencephalitis, Gram stain is positive in < 30% of cases, but cultures are positive in 80%; with abscess, culture is positive in < 50%
Cervix, amniotic fluid, and placental cultures may reveal organism in maternal listeriosis
Multiplex PCR: CSF and positive blood culture bottles

Treatment.text: Gastroenteritis is self-limited and should subside in 3-4 days
For invasive disease, ampicillin or penicillin plus trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or gentamicin
Imipenem, meropenem, and linezolid are also active

Prognosis.text: Mortality averages 36% with CNS involvement

MR Findings.text: Rhomboencephalitis involving dorsal brainstem and cerebellum

Morphologic and Biochemical Characterist.text: Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, facultative anaerobe shaped as short rods arranged as singles or short chains; characteristic tumbling motility, particularly at 20-28 °C due to temperature-regulated flagella
Positive assays include catalase, Voges-Proskauer (acetoin production), methyl red (acidic fermentation products), and esculin hydrolysis

Culture and Identification.text: Nonfastidious organisms that grow in wide temperature range (0-50 °C), typically isolated on blood agar, with small zone of β-hemolysis (due to hemolysin production)
Classified to species level by automated platforms and MALDI TOF MS

Selective and differential agars include LPM (colonies are blue), Oxford and PALCAM (colonies are black), and several chromogenic agars (i.e., Oxoid Brilliance, can differentiate betweenL. monocytogenesandL. ivanovii)

Definitions.text: Nocardiafrom Edmond Nocard (French veterinarian)

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infection withNeisseriameningitidis,Neisseriagonorrhoeae, andMoraxella catarrhalis; humans are only known host

Clinical Issues.text: N.meningitidis(meningococcus): Bacteremia ± shock and meningitis

N.gonorrhoeae(gonococcus): Acute urethritis, epididymitis, rectal involvement, prostatitis (males); endocervicitis, urethritis, anal involvement, pelvic inflammatory disease (females); pharyngitis, conjunctivitis, disseminated gonococcal infection with arthritis-dermatitis syndrome
M.catarrhalis:Otitis media, sinusitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation
Meningococcal conjugate (MenACWY) and serogroup B meningococcal (MenB) vaccines available

Microscopic.text: Gram and silver stains highlight clumps of gram-negative cocci (including within neutrophils)
N. meningitidis: Dense neutrophilic leptomeningitis; dermal vessel microthrombi, suppurative or sterile arthritis
N. gonorrhoeae: Suppurative epididymitis, chronic endometritis, purulent cervicitis, acute salpingitis, tuboovarian abscess
Arthritis-dermatitis syndrome: Suppurative or sterile arthritis; skin pustule surrounded by erythema, pustular vasculitis with abscesses
M. catarrhalis: Acute sinusitis, otitis media, and COPD exacerbations rarely biopsied

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Other causes of bacterial meningitis: e.g.,Group B Streptococcus,S. pneumoniae,Escherichia coli
Other causes of infectious arthritis: e.g.,Staphylococcus aureus,Pseudomonas aeruginosa, polymicrobial
Other causes of pelvic inflammatory disease: e.g.,Chlamydia trachomatis
Differentiate by Gram stain, culture, PCR

Definitions.text: Neisseria: From Albert Neisser, who discovered etiologic agent of gonorrhea
Greek: "Gonorrhoeae" (seminal flux)

Infectious Agents.text: Infection withNeisseriameningitidis,Neisseriagonorrhoeae, andMoraxella catarrhalis; humans are only known host

Infectious Agents.text: M.catarrhalisHistorically described as commensal organism of nasopharynx, now considered pathogenColonizes respiratory epithelia and induces uptakePredilection for damaged epithelium [e.g., in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients]Virulence factors include type IV pili, multiple adhesions, and host immunomodulator, such as UspA1, UspA2, OMP CD, OMP J, etc. and LOS as well as mechanisms to scavenge nutrients (i.e., iron) in limited environmentsModulation of host immune response includes complement resistance and inhibition of TLR2 signalingSpread by inhalation of droplets or other contact with respiratory secretionsDisease often caused by spread of colonizing organisms to other sites (e.g., middle ear, lower respiratory tract)

Epidemiology.text: M. catarrhaliscolonizes large percentage of infants and 1-5% of healthy adults

Presentation.text: N. meningitidisInvasive disease usually consists of bacteremia ± shock and meningitisLess common manifestations: Pneumonia, septic arthritis, purulent pericarditis, conjunctivitis, epiglottitis, sinusitis, otitis, urethritis, and proctitisOnset is usually abrupt, and signs and symptoms progress rapidly [fever, weakness, cold and pallor of extremities, organ failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)]Additional symptoms of meningitis include headache, photophobia, altered mental status, irritability, and neck stiffnessOften characteristic purpuric or petechial rashComplications can include Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (adrenal hemorrhage) and myocarditis (seen in < 1/2 of patients at autopsy)
sub_points: Invasive disease usually consists of bacteremia ± shock and meningitis
Less common manifestations: Pneumonia, septic arthritis, purulent pericarditis, conjunctivitis, epiglottitis, sinusitis, otitis, urethritis, and proctitis
Onset is usually abrupt, and signs and symptoms progress rapidly [fever, weakness, cold and pallor of extremities, organ failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)]
Additional symptoms of meningitis include headache, photophobia, altered mental status, irritability, and neck stiffness
Often characteristic purpuric or petechial rash
Complications can include Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (adrenal hemorrhage) and myocarditis (seen in < 1/2 of patients at autopsy)

Presentation.text: N. gonorrhoeaeMale patients: Acute urethritis with purulent discharge and dysuria; epididymitis and rectal involvement ± prostatitis may be presentFemale patients: Predominant site is endocervix, but urethra and anus may also be involvedVaginal discharge, dysuria, and vaginal bleeding~ 10-20% of women develop infection of upper genital tract [pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)]Signs and symptoms of PID include abdominal tenderness, fever, nausea, and vomiting; exam findings include adnexal tenderness and pain with cervical movementComplications of PID include infertility, ovarian abscess, and perihepatitis (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome)Other manifestations in both men and women include pharyngitis, conjunctivitis, and disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) presenting as arthritis-dermatitis syndromeArthritis is usually asymmetric polyarthritis and can progress to septic arthritisDermatitis is usually confined to extremities and consists of multiple papules and pustules, some with evidence of hemorrhage or necrosisInfection in pregnancy can result in spontaneous abortion or premature labor with increased infant mortality
sub_points: Male patients: Acute urethritis with purulent discharge and dysuria; epididymitis and rectal involvement ± prostatitis may be present

Female patients: Predominant site is endocervix, but urethra and anus may also be involvedVaginal discharge, dysuria, and vaginal bleeding~ 10-20% of women develop infection of upper genital tract [pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)]Signs and symptoms of PID include abdominal tenderness, fever, nausea, and vomiting; exam findings include adnexal tenderness and pain with cervical movementComplications of PID include infertility, ovarian abscess, and perihepatitis (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome)
Vaginal discharge, dysuria, and vaginal bleeding
~ 10-20% of women develop infection of upper genital tract [pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)]
Signs and symptoms of PID include abdominal tenderness, fever, nausea, and vomiting; exam findings include adnexal tenderness and pain with cervical movement
Complications of PID include infertility, ovarian abscess, and perihepatitis (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome)

Other manifestations in both men and women include pharyngitis, conjunctivitis, and disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) presenting as arthritis-dermatitis syndromeArthritis is usually asymmetric polyarthritis and can progress to septic arthritisDermatitis is usually confined to extremities and consists of multiple papules and pustules, some with evidence of hemorrhage or necrosis

Infection in pregnancy can result in spontaneous abortion or premature labor with increased infant mortality

Treatment.text: Meningococcal conjugate (MenACWY) vaccination recommended for 11-12 year olds with booster at age 16 as well as other individuals with increased risk for disease
Serogroup B meningococcal (MenB) vaccination may be given to 16-23 year olds as well as > 10 year olds with increased risk for disease

AntibioticsN. meningitidis: Preferred treatment is 3rd-generation cephalosporinN. gonorrhoeae: Ceftriaxone is mainstay of treatmentM. catarrhalis: Several drugs are routinely used (cephalosporins, tetracycline, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, etc.); most strains are resistant to penicillin, ampicillin, vancomycin, and clindamycin
sub_points: N. meningitidis: Preferred treatment is 3rd-generation cephalosporin
N. gonorrhoeae: Ceftriaxone is mainstay of treatment
M. catarrhalis: Several drugs are routinely used (cephalosporins, tetracycline, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, etc.); most strains are resistant to penicillin, ampicillin, vancomycin, and clindamycin

Treatment.text: Surgical treatment may be required for survivors of fulminant meningococcemia (e.g., limb and digit amputations)

Prognosis.text: Meningococcal meningitis has mortality of 5-18%; long-term complications include loss of digits or limbs, neurologic impairment, and disruption/asymmetry of growth
Mortality is rare with gonococcal infection; long-term complications vary from blindness in neonates to infertility in women with PID
Mortality and long-term complications are rare withMoraxellainfection

Culture and Identification.text: N. meningitidisandN. gonorrhoeaecommonly isolated on modified Thayer-Martin media;Moraxellaspp. grow on wide variety of agar types
Colonies can be differentiated from commensalNeisseriaspp. by their appearance (larger and pinker) and hockey-puck sign (can be easily pushed along agar surface)
Carbohydrate utilization patterns for differentiation:N. meningitidisutilizes both glucose and maltose, andN. gonorrhoeaeutilizes only glucose
Platforms for identification include MALDI-TOF MS,Neisseria-Haemophilus(NH) ID card for VITEK 2 and API-NH or CarbFerm strips

Histologic Features.text: N. meningitidisMeningitis: Sheets of neutrophils in leptomeninges; bacteria are often observable (usually within neutrophils); death associated with cerebral edema and impingement of midbrainMeningococcemia: Skin with microthrombi in dermal vessels, necrotizing vasculitisInterstitial pneumonitis (mononuclear inflammation mainly confined to alveolar septa), adrenal hemorrhage and necrosis, myocarditis, and glomerular fibrin thrombiMeningococcal arthritis: Joints with sterile arthritis; suppurative inflammation or mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate
sub_points: Meningitis: Sheets of neutrophils in leptomeninges; bacteria are often observable (usually within neutrophils); death associated with cerebral edema and impingement of midbrain
Meningococcemia: Skin with microthrombi in dermal vessels, necrotizing vasculitis
Interstitial pneumonitis (mononuclear inflammation mainly confined to alveolar septa), adrenal hemorrhage and necrosis, myocarditis, and glomerular fibrin thrombi
Meningococcal arthritis: Joints with sterile arthritis; suppurative inflammation or mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate

Spectrum of Disease.text: Otitis media
Sinusitis
Pneumonia
Systemic infections or meningitis (rare)

Epidemiology.text: Normal human flora of upper respiratory tract; may colonize female genital tract
Infection caused by spread of endogenous strain to normally sterile sites (common) or by person-to-person via contaminated respiratory droplets (rare)

Treatment.text: β-Lactams, cephalosporins, macrolides, quinolones, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are effective antibiotics
Commonly produces β-lactamases that mediate resistance to ampicillin
Testing to guide therapy not routinely needed

Differential Diagnosis.text: If seen in endocervical samples, may be mistaken forNeisseria gonorrhoeae
Clinical disease: All viral and bacterial causes of otitis media, sinusitis, or pneumonia

Culture Methods.text: Grows well on 5% sheep blood and chocolate agar and almost any broth media

Biochemical Tests.text: Glucose, maltose, and lactose not used (asaccharolytic)

Microscopy.text: Gram stain: Gram-negative diplococci with flattened adjacent edges (“kidney bean” shaped)

Morphology.text: Colony morphology: Large, nonpigmented or gray, opaque, smooth colonies with “hockey puck” consistency (colony may be moved intact over surface of agar)

Overview.text: 3 species (Escherichia coli,Klebsiella pneumoniae, andProteus mirabilis) make up 80-95% of all clinical infections caused by Enterobacterales
Biochemical testing has historically been mainstay of identification for Enterobacterales

Laboratory Methods.text: Lactose fermentation pattern on MacConkey agar can be key finding for identification of Enterobacterales

Enterobacterales.text: Members of Enterobacterales family are ubiquitous in nature and often colonize human intestinal tract
