Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infection with obligate intracellular gram-negative bacteria inRickettsiaceaefamily, spread via arthropod bites
Spotted fever group includesRickettsia rickettsii(Rocky Mountain spotted fever), transmitted by ticks
Typus group includes louse-borneR. prowazekii(epidemic typhus) and flea-borneR. typhi(Murine typhus)
Scrub typus group consists ofOrientia tsutsugamushitransmitted by mites/chiggers

Clinical Issues.text: Diagnosis is mainly clinical &/or serologic
RMSF: 7-day incubation followed by fever, myalgias, gastrointestinal distress, and headache; characteristic petechial maculopapular rash (90% of patients)
PCR can be done on primary specimens (targets: 17-kDa lipoprotein, OmpA, etc.)
Culture is rarely performed by clinical laboratories
Doxycycline is mainstay of treatment

Microscopic.text: Endothelial injury with increased permeability/edema, hemorrhage, thrombi, perivascular inflammation (usually lymphohistiocytic), and vasculitis in any organ system
Organisms are best visualized in tissue using immunohistochemistry in infected endothelial cells

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Other tick-borne infections in differential
Lyme (Borrelia burgdorferi): Erythema migrans (bull's-eye rash): Confirm with PCR, IHC, Warthin-Starry stain, serology
Anaplasmosis and ehrlichiosis: Rash less common; morulae present in peripheral blood monocytes and granulocytes; confirm with PCR, serology
Babesiosis (Babesiaspp.): RBCs infected with pear-shaped and cross forms
Heartland virus infection: Similar symptoms to ehrlichiosis in tick-exposed patient from affected area, nonresponsive to doxycycline

Definitions.text: Rickettsiafrom Howard Taylor Ricketts: Studied rickettsial disease and died from typhus
Greek: "Typhos" (smoky or hazy for mental status of patients)

Infectious Agents.text: Infection withRickettsiaspp. orOrientiaspp.,obligate intracellular gram-negative bacteria inRickettsiaceaefamily, spread via arthropod bites
After introduction into skin, organisms spread rapidly, targeting vascular endothelium; endothelial cell injury results in increased permeability, edema, hypovolemia, hypotension, and hypoalbuminemia

Spotted Fever Group.text: Transmitted predominantly by ticks, includingDermacentorspp. (e.g.,D. variabilis,D. similis,D. andersoni),Amblyommaspp., andRhipicephalusspp.
R. rickettsii(Rocky Mountain spotted fever; RMSF): North, Central, and South America
R. aeschlimannii(Rickettsiosis): South Africa, Morocco, Mediterranean
R. africae(African tick-bite fever): Sub-Saharan Africa, West Indies
R. akari(Rickettsialpox): South Africa, North and South America, Korea, southern and eastern Europe; transmitted byLiponyssoides sanguineus(mouse mite)
R. australis(Queensland tick typhus): Australia, Tasmania
R. conoriisubsp.caspiae(Astrakhan spotted fever): North Caspian region of Russia
R. conoriisubsp.conorii(Mediterranean spotted fever/Boutonneuse fever): Africa, southern Europe, southern and western Asia (India)
R. conoriisubsp.indica(Indian tick typhus): South Asia
R. conoriisubsp.israelensis(Israeli tick typhus): Southern Europe, Middle East
R. felis(Cat flea rickettsiosis): Africa, North and South America, Asia, Europe; transmitted by fleas
R. heilongjiangensis(Far eastern spotted fever): East Asia, northern China, far east Russia
R. helvetica(aneruptive fever): Asia, central and northern Europe
R. honeiincluding strain "marmionii" (Flinders Island spotted fever/Thai tick typhus): Australia, Thailand
R. japonica(Japanese spotted fever): Japan
R. massiliae(Mediterranean spotted fever-like illness): Central Africa, North America, Europe
R. monacensis(Mediterranean spotted fever-like illness): North Africa, Europe
R. parkeri(Maculatum infection): North and South America
R. raoultii(Tick-borne lymphadenopathy): Asia, Europe
R. sibirica(North Asian tick typhus/Siberian tick typhus): China, Mongolia, Russia
R. sibiricamongolotimonae(Lymphangitis-associated rickettsiosis): Africa, Asia, Europe
R. slovaca(Tick-borne lymphadenopathy): Asia, southern and eastern Europe

Typhus Group.text: R. prowazekii(Epidemic typhus; Sylvatic typhus): Central Africa, North, Central, and South America, Asia
R. typhi(Murine typhus): Temperate, tropical, and subtropical areas, worldwide

Scrub Typus Group.text: Transmitted by Trombiculid mites and chiggers
Orientia tsutsugamushi(Scrub typhus): Asia-Pacific region, Middle East
O. chuto(Scrub typhus): United Arab Emirates

Epidemiology.text: RMSF is most prevalent in late spring/summer in children, adults > 60 years, and with increased exposure to ticks
Epidemic typhus is most often diagnosed in developing countries in crowded conditions, which favor spread of lice
Scrub typhus is most prevalent in Tsutsugamushi Triangle connecting Japan, NW Australia, and central Russia; most common in autumn

Presentation.text: RMSF: 7-day incubation followed by fever, myalgias, gastrointestinal distress, and headache; petechial maculopapular rash (90% of patients) starting on wrists and ankles; meningeal symptoms, abnormal EEG, ocular pathology, renal failure, and pulmonary compromise

Epidemic typhus: 11-day incubation followed by rigors, malaise, mental status changes, and headache; petechial/maculopapular rash sparing palms, soles, and face; can reactivate later in life with milder clinical course (Brill-Zinsser disease)

Murine typhus (more mild disease than epidemic typhus): 1- to 2-week incubation period followed by acute onset of fever, headache, nausea and vomiting, headache, and rash that is predominantly maculopapular sparing palms and soles; progression of disease can include worsening gastrointestinal distress, pulmonary involvement, hepatosplenomegaly, and neurologic manifestations
Scrub typhus: Fever, headaches, and myalgia ~ 10 days after bite (indicated by erythematous papule/eschar); pulmonary involvement is common and can progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome

Laboratory Tests.text: Serology is used for retrospective confirmation (look for 4x rise in titer over course of disease); cross reactivity across rickettsial spp.
PCR assays are available for blood and tissue (offered by national reference/public health laboratories); targets include 17-kDa lipoprotein, OmpA, etc.

Treatment.text: Doxycycline is mainstay of treatment for both RMSF and typhus

Prognosis.text: Untreated RMSF and typhus can be rapidly fatal, but with treatment, mortality is usually < 5% in healthy individuals

Morphologic and Biochemical Characterist.text: Small, gram-negative, pleomorphic, obligate intracellular organisms
Stained by Gimenez method or acridine orange

Culture and Microbiologic Identification.text: Must be cultured in eukaryotic cell lines, guinea pigs, or embryonated hen's eggs
Rarely done in clinical laboratory; culture is generally followed by molecular methods for identification

Histologic Features.text: Overall pathology is connected with endothelial injury and subsequent increased permeability/edema, hemorrhage, thrombi, perivascular inflammation (usually lymphohistiocytic), and vasculitis (present in any organ system)

RMSFCutaneous: Lymphohistiocytic capillaritis and venulitis with extravasation of erythrocytes, edema, and perivascular and interstitial infiltrates; leukocytoclastic vasculitis with neutrophilic infiltrate, basal layer vacuolar degeneration, and dermoepidermal interface lymphocytic exocytosisPulmonary: Diffuse interstitial mononuclear (including numerous lymphoblasts) inflammatory infiltrate, pulmonary edema and intraalveolar hemorrhage, vasculitis of arterioles and venulesLiver: Marked portal mixed inflammation, spotty lobular necrosisKidney: Mixed inflammatory infiltrate of vessels and interstitium, acute tubular necrosis, focal segmental tuft necrosis (less common)Brain: Parenchymal lesions often restricted to white matter and consist of microinfarcts
sub_points: Cutaneous: Lymphohistiocytic capillaritis and venulitis with extravasation of erythrocytes, edema, and perivascular and interstitial infiltrates; leukocytoclastic vasculitis with neutrophilic infiltrate, basal layer vacuolar degeneration, and dermoepidermal interface lymphocytic exocytosis
Pulmonary: Diffuse interstitial mononuclear (including numerous lymphoblasts) inflammatory infiltrate, pulmonary edema and intraalveolar hemorrhage, vasculitis of arterioles and venules
Liver: Marked portal mixed inflammation, spotty lobular necrosis
Kidney: Mixed inflammatory infiltrate of vessels and interstitium, acute tubular necrosis, focal segmental tuft necrosis (less common)
Brain: Parenchymal lesions often restricted to white matter and consist of microinfarcts

Histologic Features.text: Epidemic typhus and murine typhus have similar histopathologic presentation to RMSF

Scrub typhusCutaneous: Eschars characterized by leukocytoclastic vasculitis and neutrophil infiltration; perieschar region has epidermal exocytosis of mononuclear cells and basal vacuolar changesand dermal perivascular, interstitial, and perineural mononuclear cell infiltration, thrombosis, atypical lymphocyte infiltration, and mitotic figures in dermisCardiac: Myocarditis, mixed inflammatory infiltratePulmonary: Interstitial pneumonitis (more pronounced/common than in RMSF), bacterial bronchopneumoniaLiver: Spotty lobular necrosis, typically associated with less of granulocytic infiltrate than in RMSF; periportal steatosis, erythrophagocytosis, sinusoidal infiltrate with activated Kupffer cells and lymphocytesLymph nodes: Hyperplasia and necrosis (more so than with RMSF)Kidney: Glomerulonephritis, foci of interstitial nephritisBrain: Mononuclear cell meningitis, typhus nodules (predominantly oligodendroglial cells), perivascular cuffing of arteries, focal hemorrhages in parenchyma and meninges, degeneration of ganglion cells
sub_points: Cutaneous: Eschars characterized by leukocytoclastic vasculitis and neutrophil infiltration; perieschar region has epidermal exocytosis of mononuclear cells and basal vacuolar changesand dermal perivascular, interstitial, and perineural mononuclear cell infiltration, thrombosis, atypical lymphocyte infiltration, and mitotic figures in dermis
Cardiac: Myocarditis, mixed inflammatory infiltrate
Pulmonary: Interstitial pneumonitis (more pronounced/common than in RMSF), bacterial bronchopneumonia

Liver: Spotty lobular necrosis, typically associated with less of granulocytic infiltrate than in RMSF; periportal steatosis, erythrophagocytosis, sinusoidal infiltrate with activated Kupffer cells and lymphocytes
Lymph nodes: Hyperplasia and necrosis (more so than with RMSF)
Kidney: Glomerulonephritis, foci of interstitial nephritis

Brain: Mononuclear cell meningitis, typhus nodules (predominantly oligodendroglial cells), perivascular cuffing of arteries, focal hemorrhages in parenchyma and meninges, degeneration of ganglion cells

Immunohistochemistry/Immunofluorescence.text: Rickettsial antigens present in endothelial cells

Electron Microscopy.text: Membrane-bound bacilli (1-2 μm) in cytoplasm and nucleus

Lyme (Borrelia burgdorferi).text: Erythema migrans (bull's-eye rash) should warrant investigation for Lyme
Lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with spirochetes; confirm with PCR, IHC, Warthin-Starry stain, serology

Anaplasmosis and Ehrlichiosis.text: Rash less common in anaplasmosis (10%) and ehrlichiosis (< 40%)
Morulae present in peripheral blood monocytes and granulocytes; confirm with PCR, serology

Babesiosis (Babesiaspp.).text: Babesiaspp. infect RBCs with diagnostic pear-shaped and cross forms

Heartland Virus Infection.text: Clinical signs/symptoms similar to ehrlichiosis with tick exposure (Missouri and Tennessee)
Patients fail to respond to doxycycline, but there is no current clinical test or therapy available

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infection withAnaplasmaphagocytophilum,Ehrlichiachaffeensis,Ehrlichiaewingii,andEhrlichiamuris eauclairensis,small obligate gram-negative intracellular bacteria transmitted by tick bites, blood transfusions, and organ transplantation

Clinical Issues.text: Symptoms (1-2 weeks after tick bite) include fever, headache, muscle pain, malaise, GI symptoms, cough, confusion; maculopapular petechiae rash (< 30%)
PCR (blood): Highest sensitivity within 1 week of illness; decreased by doxycycline
Indirect immunofluorescence assay: 4x rise in IgG between acute and convalescent stages is > 90% sensitive

Microscopic.text: Morulae (intracytoplasmic microcolonies) can be seen in peripheral blood cells, but presence in particular cell type is not sufficiently specific to differentiate between spp.
A. phagocytophilumandE. ewingiimorulae most commonly identified in granulocytes;E. chaffeensisin monocytes; no target cell identified forE. muris eauclairensis
Morulae seen in bone marrow aspirates/biopsies and in autopsy tissue sections from most organs, highlighted by IHC and ISH

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Other tick-borne infections/coinfections in differential
Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii): Rash more common; confirm with PCR, IHC, serology
Babesiosis (Babesiaspp.): RBC infected with pear-shaped and cross forms
Lyme (Borrelia burgdorferi): Erythema migrans (bull's-eye rash): Confirm with PCR, IHC, Warthin-Starry stain, serology
Heartland virus infection: Similar symptoms to ehrlichiosis in tick-exposed patient from affected area, nonresponsive to doxycycline

Definitions.text: Anaplasmaphagocytophilumderived from Greek (without plasma + loving phagocytes)
Ehrlichia(after Paul Ehrlich)chaffeensis[after Fort Chaffee (1st patient identified)];ewingii[after Sidney A. Ewing (pioneer of agent)]

Infectious Agents.text: Infection withAnaplasmaspp. andEhrlichiaspp., small obligate gram-negative intracellular bacteria transmitted by tick bites, blood transfusions, and organ transplantation
Organisms reside in hematopoietic or endothelial cells and multiply in cytoplasmic membrane-bound vacuoles as microcolonies called morulae
A.phagocytophilum(human granulocytic anaplasmosis) transmitted byIxodes scapularisin Northeast and upper Midwest andI. pacificusin Northern California; also reported in Central Europe and Scandinavia

E. chaffeensisehrlichiosis (human monocytic ehrlichiosis): Transmitted byAmblyomma americanum; endemic in Southeast, South Central, and mid-Atlantic USA; also in Mexico, Central and South America, East Asia, Europe, and central Africa
E. ewingiiehrlichiosis: Transmitted byA. americanumin South Central and Southeast USA
E. muris eauclairensisehrlichiosis (formerlyE. muris-like agent) transmitted byI.scapularisin Minnesota/Wisconsin

Epidemiology.text: A.phagocytophilum: 1,764-5,762 cases/year reported in USA (2010-2019); 5-10% of healthy people in high-prevalence areas have serologic evidence of prior exposure
E. chaffeensis: 946-2,093 cases/year reported in USA (2010-2019)
E. ewingii: Total of 261 cases reported in USA (2008-2019)
E. muris eauclairensis:115 cases reported (2009-2019)
Highest in summer months with most nymphal ticks

Presentation.text: Acute symptoms 1-2 weeks after painless tick bite
Anaplasmosis: Fever, headache, muscle pain, malaise, chills, nausea, abdominal pain, cough, confusion; maculopapular ± petechiae rash (10% of patients)
Ehrlichiosis: Malaise, headache, chills/fever, GI symptoms, mental status changes, stiff neck, clonus; maculopapular petechial rash in 1/3 of cases (predominantlyE. chaffeensis)

Laboratory Tests.text: Mild anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, transaminitis
PCR (blood): 60-70% sensitive forAnaplasmaspp., and 52-87% sensitive forEhrlichiaspp. within 1 week of illness; decreased by doxycycline treatment

Serology: Indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) on paired serum samples to demonstrate 4x rise in IgG titers in first 4 weeks (> 90% sensitive); antibody titers are frequently negative in 1st week of illness
IgM titers can remain elevated for years and are not reliable for acute infection

Treatment.text: Doxycycline is 1st-line treatment

Prognosis.text: Anaplasmosis rarely fatal (< 1%); complications, including renal failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome, toxic shock-like syndrome, hemophagocytosis, rhabdomyolysis, pancreatitis, and opportunistic infections

Ehrlichiosis rarely fatal (3%; no fatalities reported withE. ewingiiorE. muris eauclairensis); complications include renal failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome, coagulopathy, myocarditis, encephalopathy
Severity increased in immunosuppression, HIV infection

Bacterial Features.text: Cultures require specialized systems involving human promyelocytic leukemia cells and are not routinely performed for diagnosis

Peripheral Blood Smear (Direct Exam Stai.text: A. phagocytophilummorulae (intracytoplasmic microcolonies) present most commonly in granulocytes (20-80% of patients within 1st week of illness)
E. chaffeensismorulae present most commonly in monocytes (1-20% of patients)
E. ewingiimorulae more commonly present in granulocytes
E. muris eauclairensismorulae have not yet been observed in peripheral blood cells
Presence of morulae in particular cell type is not sufficiently specific to differentiate betweenAnaplasmaandEhrlichiaspp.
Ehrlichiosis may also show atypical lymphocytes with large, hyperchromatic nuclei, abundant basophilic cytoplasm, and prominent cytoplasmic granules
Evidence of mixed infections may be identified, e.g., intraerythrocytic rings and "Maltese cross," suggestive of Babesiosis

Histopathology.text: Bone marrow aspirate/biopsy: Normocellular or hypercellular marrow with rare morulae in monocytes or granulocytes

Fatal cases ofE. chaffeensisehrlichiosis show systemic, multiorgan involvement; bacteria most abundant in spleen, lymph nodes, and bone marrow, less frequently in liver and lung, and occasionally in other organs; direct vasculitis and endothelial injury are rare

Immunohistochemistry/In Situ Hybridizati.text: Morulae may be highlighted by IHC and ISH in granulocytes or monocytes within spleen, lymph nodes, and bone marrow

Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (Rickettsia.text: Endothelial injury and vasculitis can affect any organ system; confirm with PCR, IHC

Babesiosis (Babesiaspp.).text: Mixed infections can occur due to shared vectors (Ixodesspp. ticks)
Babesiaspp. infect RBCs with diagnostic pear-shaped and cross forms

Lyme (Borrelia burgdorferi).text: Mixed infections can occur due to shared vectors (Ixodesspp. ticks)
Erythema migrans (bull's-eye rash) should warrant investigation for Lyme
Lymphoplasmacytic to mixed inflammation; confirm with PCR, IHC, Warthin-Starry stain, serology

Heartland Virus Infection.text: Clinical signs/symptoms similar to ehrlichiosis with tick exposure (Missouri and Tennessee)
Patients fail to respond to doxycycline, but there is no current clinical test or therapy available

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Zoonotic infection (Q fever) withCoxiella burnetii, Gram-negative intracellular bacteria, spread primarily through inhalation of aerosols

Clinical Issues.text: Acute Q fever: Febrile syndrome/flu-like illness, pneumonia, hepatitis, cardiac and neurologic manifestations
Persistent infection: Endocarditis, vascular involvement, liver involvement, osteoarticular infection
Pregnancy: May result in miscarriage, fetal death, malformations, growth retardation, or premature delivery
Serology is mainstay of diagnosis; PCR from blood or tissue

Microscopic.text: Endocarditis: Fibrosis and calcifications, limited inflammation, small or absent vegetations; bacteria present as coarse granular material within macrophages
Liver: Mononuclear inflammation, fibrin ring granulomas, Kupffer cells, fatty change, eosinophilia, cirrhosis
Pulmonary: Interstitial edema, mixed inflammation, intraalveolar histiocytes and focal necrosis, hemorrhage
Skeletal: Osteomyelitis (often multifocal), spondylodiscitis, prosthetic joint infection

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Whipple disease: Culture-negative endocarditis with foamy macrophages filled with PAS-positive, acid fast-negative bacilli; confirm with PCR, IHC/ISH
Bartonellaspp. infection: Culture-negative endocarditis associated with gram-negative coccobacilli highlighted by Warthin-Starry stain; confirm with IHC, PCR, serology
Other causes of fibrin-ring granuloma: CMV, EBV, allopurinol toxicity, leishmaniasis, boutonneuse fever, salmonella, and toxoplasmosis

Definitions.text: Q fever; so-called "Query fever" in 1935, when syndrome was suspected to be new disease
Coxiellaburnetiiafter Herald Rea Cox (American bacteriologist) and McFarlane Burnet (Australian virologist)

Infectious Agents.text: Zoonotic infection withCoxiella burnetii, gram-negative intracellular bacteria, spread via inhalation of aerosols as well as through tick bites, ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products, blood transfusion, transplacentally, or sexual contact
Associated with exposure to sheep, goats, and cattle; highest concentration of organism in birth products but also present in urine, feces, and milk
Lipopolysaccharide: Phase I, full-length (smooth) infective form, and phase II, truncated (rough) avirulent form
Biphasic life cycle: Replicating large cell variant and small cell nonreplicating variant (extremely stable in environment)
Classified as potential agent of bioterrorism due to combination of virulence with environmental stability

Epidemiology.text: Worldwide distribution; seroprevalence up to 30% in Africa
Pooled estimate of seroprevalence is > 20% among slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians
USA: 109-179 cases/year of acute and 23-40 cases/year of chronic Q fever (2010-2019); ~ 24% of soil samples PCR positive forC.burnetii

Presentation.text: Acute Q fever (50% of infections; 2-3 week incubation): Febrile syndrome/flu-like illness, pneumonia, hepatitis; cardiac and neurologic manifestations rare
Endocarditis associated with acute Q fever is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (elevated anticardiolipin levels) and is likely autoimmune in nature

Persistent infection (< 5%; weeks to years after acute infection) causes ~ 10% of culture-negative endocarditis; vascular involvement with aortoduodenal fistula, spondylodiscitis with psoas abscess, graft or aneurysm rupture; osteoarticular infections and lymphadenitis rare
In utero infection may result in miscarriage, fetal death, malformations, growth restriction, premature delivery

Laboratory Tests.text: PCR detection from blood/serum, fresh or FFPE tissue

Serology is mainstay of diagnosisAcute infection: Phase II antibodies directed against common protein antigens are present 7-15 days after symptom onset and decrease after 3-6 months; > 200 IgG or 4x rise over 3-6-weeks or > 50 IgMPersistent infection: Phase I antibodies directed against full-length LPS; > 800 IgG
sub_points: Acute infection: Phase II antibodies directed against common protein antigens are present 7-15 days after symptom onset and decrease after 3-6 months; > 200 IgG or 4x rise over 3-6-weeks or > 50 IgM
Persistent infection: Phase I antibodies directed against full-length LPS; > 800 IgG

Laboratory Tests.text: Cultures: Not cultured on clinical media; require biosafety level 3 containment

Treatment.text: Depends on manifestation, i.e., tetracycline for pneumonia, doxycycline with ciprofloxacin, or rifampin for endocarditis

Prognosis.text: Endocarditis: 5-9% mortality
Vascular involvement: 18-26% mortality

Histologic Features.text: Endocarditis: Extensive fibrosis and calcifications, limited lymphohistiocytic inflammation, vascularization, small or absent vegetations, absence of microabscesses or granulomata; bacteria present as coarse granular material within macrophages
Liver: Mononuclear cell infiltration of portal tracts, granulomas (fibrin ring or "doughnut"), prominent sinusoidal Kupffer cells, fatty change, sinusoidal wall eosinophilia, cirrhosis
Pulmonary: Interstitial edema, mixed inflammatory infiltrate, intraalveolar histiocytes and focal necrosis, hemorrhage; microorganisms rarely apparent
Skeletal: Osteomyelitis (often multifocal), spondylodiscitis, prosthetic joint infection

Histochemistry.text: Gimenez stain to detect organisms; does not stain with Gram

Immunohistochemistry.text: Antibodies for detection ofC. burnetiiare available though not widely used clinically

Whipple Disease (Tropheryma whipplei).text: Culture-negative endocarditis associated with abundant foamy macrophages filled with PAS-positive, acid fast-negative bacilli; confirm with PCR, IHC/ISH

Bartonellaspp. Infection.text: Culture-negative endocarditis associated with gram-negative coccobacilli highlighted by Warthin-Starry stains; confirm with IHC, PCR, serology

Other Causes of Fibrin-Ring Granulomas.text: CMV, EBV, allopurinol toxicity, leishmaniasis, boutonneuse fever, salmonella, and toxoplasmosis

Clinical Correlates.text: Most common in middle-aged white males of European ancestry
Classic Whipple disease characterized by arthralgias, weight loss, diarrhea, and abdominal distention/pain
Fatal without treatment (ceftriaxone and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole)

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: T. whippleinot easily cultured in laboratory
Diagnosis based on gastrointestinal biopsy, which demonstrates PAS-positive, AFB-negative macrophages in lamina propria and submucosa
Confirmation with PCR on affected tissues is gold standard for diagnosis (may not be available in all cases)

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infections withMycoplasmaandUreaplasmaspp., bacteria in class Mollicutes, smallest free-living organisms (0.2-0.3 µm in diameter), which lack cell wall

Clinical Issues.text: M.pneumoniae: "Walking" pneumonia, tracheobronchitis, pharyngitis; disseminated disease, hemolytic anemia, skin rash, myocarditis, encephalitis
M. hominis, M. genitalium: Bacterial vaginitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, pyelonephritis, neonatal infection; disseminated disease (immunocompromised)
Ureaplasmaspp.: Urogenital infections, urethritis, renal calculi; preterm birth with pulmonary/CNS disease; hyperammonemia syndrome
Laboratory: PCR testing (including multiplex panels) is preferred method of detection; may reflect colonization
Culture and susceptibility testing requires specialized media (typically performed at reference labs)
Treatment: Fluoroquinolones, tetracyclines, macrolides

Microscopic.text: Organisms not visualized by Gram stain, but antigen can be highlighted by targeted IHC
M. pneumoniae: Nonspecific lymphocytic/neutrophilic bronchiolitis, epithelial injury, sloughing, intraalveolar mucus/proteinaceous material; DAD in severe cases
M. hominis-associated chorioamnionitis, vaginal abscess

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Other atypical pneumonias (e.g.,Legionellaspp.,Chlamydiaspp.,Coxiella burnetii, Bordetellaspp.) confirmed by IHC, molecular, or serology testing
Pulmonary viral infections (e.g., RSV, adenovirus, and influenzas A and B) confirmed by viral inclusions, IHC, PCR, antigen testing, or culture
Other urogenital bacterial infections (e.g.,Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhea,Gardnerella vaginalis) confirmed by IHC, molecular testing or culture

Definitions.text: Greek: "Mykes" (fungus), "plasma" (formed)

Infectious Agents.text: Infections with bacteria inMycoplasmaandUreaplasmagenera, members of class Mollicutes, which are smallest free-living organisms (0.2-0.3 µm in diameter), known for lacking cell wall around their cell membrane
Mycoplasmaspp. demonstrate high variation in cell surface proteins allowing for evasion of host immune system
M. pneumoniaeP1 adhesion protein interacts with sialylated glycoprotein receptors on epithelial cells, destroying cilia, resulting in respiratory illness
Ureaplasmaspp. produce IgA protease to degrade immunoglobulins, release urea, and form urinary calculi

Epidemiology.text: M. pneumoniaespreads in crowded environmentsMore common children and young adults, lower prevalence in adults likely due to prior immunity
sub_points: More common children and young adults, lower prevalence in adults likely due to prior immunity

sub_points: Preterm birth, postpartum fever, pulmonary and CNS infection in neonates

Presentation.text: Ureaplasmaspp. cause urogenital infections, nongonococcal urethritis, renal calculi; preterm birth, postpartum fever, pulmonary, CNS infection in neonates; hyperammonemia syndrome after lung transplantation

Laboratory Tests.text: PCR testing (including multiplex panels) is preferred method of detection, although may reflect colonization
EIA antibodies lack sensitivity and specificity
Complement fixation titers peak in 4 weeks and persists 6-12 months
Overall cold agglutinin testing has poor sensitivity and specificity, may cross react with other respiratory pathogens (e.g., EBC, CMV)
Patients with hemolytic anemia and high-titer cold agglutinin (> 1:64) in setting of community acquired pneumonia have high likelihood of mycoplasma

Radiographic Findings.text: M. pneumoniaepulmonary infection with bilateral diffuse patchy, reticulonodular opacities, severity out of proportion to clinical status

Culture, Morphology, and Biochemical Fea.text: Slow-growing (2-6 weeks), facultative anaerobes (M. pneumoniaeis strict aerobe)

M. pneumoniae,Ureaplasmaspp. form small punctate colonies that require dissection scope for visualization

Overview.text: Glycopeptides inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis and are considered bactericidal
Active against gram-positive but not gram-negative bacteria

Biologic Concepts.text: Disrupt cell wall synthesis by binding to D-alanine-D-alanine terminus causing steric inhibition of peptidoglycan chain elongation

Glycopeptide Antibiotics.text: Vancomycin and teicoplanin are main glycopeptide antibiotics
Active against gram-positive but not gram-negative bacteria

Mechanism of Action.text: Binds to D-alanine-D-alanine terminus causing steric inhibition of peptidoglycan chain elongation
Leads to cell death by osmotic lysis or autolysis

Bacterial Resistance to Glycopeptides.text: Intrinsic resistanceGlycopeptide molecules cannot penetrate outer membrane pores of gram-negative bacteria because of their large sizeSome organisms contain D-alanine-D-serine (glycopeptides bind only D-alanine-D-alanine)
sub_points: Glycopeptide molecules cannot penetrate outer membrane pores of gram-negative bacteria because of their large size
Some organisms contain D-alanine-D-serine (glycopeptides bind only D-alanine-D-alanine)

Bacterial Resistance to Glycopeptides.text: Acquired resistanceIn some vancomycin-resistant ﻿enterococci,vanAandvanBgenes mediate changes in peptidoglycan terminus blocking glycopeptide bindingPlasmids containing these resistance genes may recombine with other resistance plasmids, leading to extensive resistanceStaphylococcus aureushas been identified in Michigan with resistance to β-lactams, vancomycin, and aminoglycosides (among others)
sub_points: In some vancomycin-resistant ﻿enterococci,vanAandvanBgenes mediate changes in peptidoglycan terminus blocking glycopeptide binding

Overview.text: Target DNA/RNA metabolism
Bactericidal

Biologic Concepts.text: Quinolones inhibit bacterial DNA topoisomerase
Metronidazole produces oxidative free radicals under anaerobic conditions
Rifamycins bind to and inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase

Clinical Applications.text: Quinolones have broad spectrum of activity but are associated with tendinitis in older patients
Metronidazole is used to treatTrichomonas,Giardia,Entamoeba histolyticaas well as anaerobic infections

sub_points: Chromosomal mutations in genes for topoisomerases

Requires anaerobic conditions for activation

Metronidazole.text: Resistance occurs via elimination of cytotoxic compounds as they are produced

Cannot penetrate outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria

Metronidazole.text: Used to treatTrichomonas,Giardia,Entamoeba histolyticaas well as anaerobic infections

Overview.text: Bacteriostatic

sub_points: Trimethoprim inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
Sulfonamides inhibit dihydropteroate synthase

Clinical Applications.text: Trimethoprim and sulfonamides are active against many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria
Associated with limited range of side effects, although sulfonamides induce cytochrome P-450 system, which can affect metabolism of other drugs

Antimetabolite Antibiotics.text: Trimethoprim and sulfonamides are main antimetabolite antibiotics
Block bacterial processes required for survival but do not kill bacteria (considered bacteriostatic)
Often combined (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) to provide synergistic inhibition of folate metabolism

Spectrum of Activity.text: Trimethoprim and sulfonamides are active against many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is drug of choice for empiric treatment of uncomplicated urinary tract infection andPneumocystis jirovecipneumonia

Allergic skin rash

Terminology.text: MIC is minimum antimicrobial concentration that completely inhibits visible bacterial growth
Breakpoints are specific antibiotic concentrations that determine whether results will be reported as "susceptible," "intermediate," or "resistant"

Laboratory Methods.text: Broth microdilution: Inoculate organism into wells containing liquid medium with range of antimicrobial concentrations to determine lowest antimicrobial concentrations that will inhibit growth (MIC)

Agar dilution: Inoculate organism onto plates of solid medium impregnated with increasing range of antimicrobial concentrations to determine lowest antimicrobial concentrations that will inhibit growth (MIC)
Disc diffusion: Inoculate organism onto solid medium and place disc impregnated with standard concentration of antibiotics to determine size of zone of inhibition surrounding disc

Definitions.text: MIC: Minimum antimicrobial concentration that completely inhibits visible bacterial growth
MBC: Minimum antimicrobial concentration that results in killing of 99.9% of inoculum compared with control
Breakpoints: Specific antibiotic concentrations that determine whether results will be reported as "susceptible," "intermediate," or "resistant"
Sensitive: Antimicrobial agent may be appropriate choiceBacterial resistance is clinically insignificant
sub_points: Bacterial resistance is clinically insignificant

Definitions.text: Intermediate: Indicates possible susceptibility of isolate to antimicrobial
Resistant: Antimicrobial agent may not be appropriate choiceBacterial resistance is clinically significant
sub_points: Bacterial resistance is clinically significant

Broth Dilution.text: Involves inoculating organism into several wells containing liquid medium with increasing range of antimicrobial concentrationsConcentrations of antimicrobial vary for different drugs (determined by therapeutic range in humans and concentrations required to detect resistance in given organism)
sub_points: Concentrations of antimicrobial vary for different drugs (determined by therapeutic range in humans and concentrations required to detect resistance in given organism)

Broth Dilution.text: MIC is determined by locating well with lowest antimicrobial concentration that inhibits growth of organism
MIC is reported and compared with established breakpoints for organism in question to report as "sensitive," "intermediate," or "resistant"
Separated into microdilution or macrodilution types based on volume of broth in which test is performed

Agar Dilution.text: Involves inoculating organism onto several plates of solid medium impregnated with increasing range of antimicrobial concentrations
MIC is determined by locating agar with lowest antimicrobial concentration that inhibits growth of organism
MIC is then compared with established breakpoints
Some organisms cannot grow in liquid media because they require supplementation for growthSusceptibility testing may be best performed using agar dilution
sub_points: Susceptibility testing may be best performed using agar dilution

Disc Diffusion.text: Involves streaking organism onto solid medium and placing disc impregnated with standard concentration of antibiotic (or several antibiotic discs) onto agar
After incubation, diameter of zone of inhibition surrounding disc is measured and compared with reference values that have been correlated with MICs
Because MIC is not directly established, it is not reportedEssentially, disc diffusion provides only qualitative "sensitive" or "resistant" determination, without quantitative MIC data
sub_points: Essentially, disc diffusion provides only qualitative "sensitive" or "resistant" determination, without quantitative MIC data

Disc Diffusion.text: Etest can be used to overcome above limitationInvolves placing synthetic strip with increasing antimicrobial concentration on culture plate inoculated with organism being testedMIC is determined by locating intersection of growth/inhibition zones and reading concentration that is just higher than this point
sub_points: Involves placing synthetic strip with increasing antimicrobial concentration on culture plate inoculated with organism being tested
MIC is determined by locating intersection of growth/inhibition zones and reading concentration that is just higher than this point

Standardization.text: Reporting resistance requires elimination of possible environmental influences that could affect antibiotic activity

Standardization serves toOptimize bacterial growth conditions so that inhibition of growth can be attributed to antibiotic testedOptimize conditions for maintaining antimicrobial integrity and activityMaintain reproducibility and consistency in resistance profile of given organism within and between laboratories
sub_points: Optimize bacterial growth conditions so that inhibition of growth can be attributed to antibiotic tested
Optimize conditions for maintaining antimicrobial integrity and activity
Maintain reproducibility and consistency in resistance profile of given organism within and between laboratories

Standardization.text: Standardized laboratory environment cannot mimic in vivo environment at infection site

Inoculum Preparation.text: Inconsistencies in inoculum preparation may lead to inconsistent or inaccurate susceptibility testing results
Important considerations for inoculum preparationUse of pure cultureUse of standard-sized inoculum
sub_points: Use of pure culture
Use of standard-sized inoculum

Fastidious Organisms.text: Some organisms do not grow well on standard Mueller Hinton agarThese require special media for antibiotic susceptibility testing
sub_points: These require special media for antibiotic susceptibility testing

Fastidious Organisms.text: Use of nonstandard media may hinder interpretation of breakpoints for organisms

Organisms With Subpopulations.text: Some organisms (e.g.,Staphylococcus aureus) may harbor subpopulations that are antibiotic intermediate or resistant
Subpopulations may be observed as colonies within zone of inhibition in disc diffusion testing

Depending on proportion of population that is resistant, these subpopulations may be missed by broth microdilution testingOnly 5 x 10⁵ organisms are testedSome populations harbor resistant organisms in 1 x 10⁷ cells
sub_points: Only 5 x 10⁵ organisms are tested
Some populations harbor resistant organisms in 1 x 10⁷ cells

Clinical and Laboratory Standards Instit.text: CLSI determines procedures, guidelines, and recommendations for antimicrobial testing in different bacterial organisms

Procedures and guidelines are continually updated and include information aboutBacterial inoculum sizeGrowth mediumIncubation atmosphereIncubation temperatureIncubation durationAntimicrobial concentrations

Growth medium

Incubation temperature
Incubation duration

McFarland Turbidity Standards.text: Standards by which turbidity of organism suspension is compared to ensure standardized inocula
Created by mixing 1% sulfuric acid with 1.175% barium chloride to obtain solution with specific optical density
0.5 McFarland standard is equal to bacterial suspension of 1.5 x 10⁸ CFU/mLStandard most commonly used for antimicrobial testing
sub_points: Standard most commonly used for antimicrobial testing

Terminology.text: Biologic resistance: Observable evidence of organism's reduced susceptibility to drug
Clinical resistance: Reduced susceptibility to point at which the drug is no longer useful for therapy
Intrinsic resistance: Result of normal (baseline) genetic, structural, or physiologic state of organism
Acquired resistance: Result of altered gene expression that leads to changes in structure or physiology of organism

Biologic Concepts.text: Environmentally mediated resistance: Ability of pH, oxygen tension, cation concentration, and other variables to reduce effect of antimicrobial, independent of microorganism being treated
Microorganism-mediated resistance: Ability of specific microorganism to develop genetically encoded resistance to antimicrobialIncludes both intrinsic and acquired resistance mechanisms
sub_points: Includes both intrinsic and acquired resistance mechanisms

Definitions.text: Environmentally-mediated resistance: Direct result of environment's physical or chemical characteristics that lead to changes in antimicrobial agent or organism's response to drug
Microorganism-mediated resistance: Resistance due to genetically encoded characteristics of organism

Emergence and Dissemination of Antibioti.text: Gene sharing occurs between different bacterial strains, between species of different genera, and even between distantly related bacteria

Single organism may acquire multiple antibiotic resistance genes, either in its genome or on plasmidExample of genome-encoded resistanceAmp-C mediated β-lactam resistance in Enterobacteriaceae (also present in plasmid form)Example of plasmid resistanceCarbapenem resistance in Enterobacteriaceae via carbapenemasesGene product capable of hydrolyzing almost all known β-lactamsCarbapenemase gene within these plasmids may be flanked by insertion sequences or small transposons that facilitate movement between organisms

Terminology.text: Urinary tract infection (UTI)
Acute uncomplicated UTI: Acute onset of dysuria, urgency, or frequency in patient without known functional or anatomical abnormalities of urinary tract
Complicated UTI: Onset of urinary symptoms associated with factors that compromise urinary tract or host defense

Biologic Concepts.text: Escherichia coliis most common causative agent for both uncomplicated and complicated UTIs
Proteuscan hydrolyze urea via urease production, resulting in increased urine pH that is directly toxic to kidney cells and stimulates formation of kidney stones

Laboratory Methods.text: Presence of ≥ 8 PMN/mm³ suggests infection, but pyuria may also be seen with urologic surgery, interstitial nephritis, or indwelling urinary devices
Dipsticks combine testing for nitrate reductase and leukocyte esteraseRapid, inexpensive, and easy to perform, but have limited sensitivity
sub_points: Rapid, inexpensive, and easy to perform, but have limited sensitivity

Definitions.text: Acute uncomplicated UTI: Acute onset of dysuria, urgency, or frequency in patient without known functional or anatomical abnormalities of urinary tract
Complicated UTI: Onset of urinary symptoms associated with factors that compromise urinary tract or host defense
Asymptomatic bacteriuria: Isolation of bacteria in appropriately collected urine specimen from patient without symptoms or signs of urinary infection

UTIs can also be defined by site of infectionUrethritis: Infection of urethraCystitis: Infection of urinary bladderUreteritis: Infection within ureters, indicating that organisms are ascending into kidneysPyelonephritis: Infection of kidneys

Overview.text: Higher rates of infectious diarrhea occur in immunocompromised patients, patients taking proton-pump inhibitors, and patients taking antibiotics that alter intestinal flora and gut homeostasis
Hospital-associatedC. difficileis most prevalent cause of fatal diarrheal illness

Protozoal and parasitic causes of diarrhea includeG. lamblia,E. histolytica,Cryptosporidium,Cyclospora,Isospora, andTrichinella

Serology.text: Blood serology tests are available forChlamydia pneumoniae,Mycoplasma pneumoniae, andLegionellaspp.; however, their clinical utility is limited by delay in results and difficulty in interpretation

Molecular Techniques.text: Real-time and multiplex-panel PCR assays are available for bacterial causes of community-acquired pneumonia includingMycoplasma,Chlamydia,Streptococcus, andLegionellaspp.

Commercially available PCR assays can detect most important respiratory viruses, including influenza A and B viruses, respiratory syncytial virus, parainfluenza viruses, human metapneumovirus, human rhinoviruses, enteroviruses, adenoviruses, human bocavirus, and several coronavirusesPCR testing demonstrates respiratory virus in 20-40% of adults with community-acquired pneumoniaInterpretation of PCR results for respiratory viruses must be taken with caution, since respiratory viruses may also predispose patients to bacterial pneumonia, and positive PCR result for viral etiology does not exclude possibility that bacterial pneumonia is present
sub_points: PCR testing demonstrates respiratory virus in 20-40% of adults with community-acquired pneumonia

Interpretation of PCR results for respiratory viruses must be taken with caution, since respiratory viruses may also predispose patients to bacterial pneumonia, and positive PCR result for viral etiology does not exclude possibility that bacterial pneumonia is present

Overview.text: Highest rates of infective endocarditis occur in patients with prosthetic valves, intracardiac devices, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart diseases, or history of infective endocarditis
Right-sided endocarditis (5-10% of endocarditis cases) is associated with intravenous drug use, cardiac device infection, central venous catheters, HIV, or congenital heart disease

Biologic Concepts.text: S. aureusis most frequently isolated microorganism associated with infective endocarditis in developed countries
Most common infectious causes of culture-negative endocarditis includeBartonellaspp.,Brucellaspp.,Coxiella burnetii(Q fever), HACEK, andTropheryma whipplei

Laboratory Methods.text: 3 sets of blood cultures (anaerobic and aerobic, with interval of at least 1 hour) should be drawn before administration of antibiotics and will establish diagnosis in ~ 90% of cases

Molecular analysis has higher sensitivity than blood and tissue culture and can detect fastidious organisms, noncultivable pathogens, such asT. whipplei, and organisms in patients who received prior antibiotic administration but is limited by contamination by background bacterial DNA

Epidemiology.text: Infective endocarditis is rare (yearly incidence ~ 3-10 per 100,000)

At least 1/3 of cases of infective endocarditis in United States in recent years are health care associatedProsthetic valve endocarditis occurs in 3-4% of patients within 5 years of index surgery and has high mortality
sub_points: Prosthetic valve endocarditis occurs in 3-4% of patients within 5 years of index surgery and has high mortality

Epidemiology.text: Rheumatic heart disease is key risk factor for infective endocarditis in developing countries
In industrialized countries, endocarditis very rarely occurs in childrenMay occur in children with cardiac defects, such as cyanotic congenital heart disease or ventricular septal defects
sub_points: May occur in children with cardiac defects, such as cyanotic congenital heart disease or ventricular septal defects

Epidemiology.text: Highest rates of infective endocarditis occur in patients with prosthetic valves, intracardiac devices, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart diseases, or history of infective endocarditis
Right-sided endocarditis (5-10% of endocarditis cases) is associated with intravenous drug use, cardiac device infection, central venous catheters, HIV, or congenital heart disease

Pathophysiology.text: Bacteremia results from poor dental hygiene, invasive procedures, or indwelling venous catheters

Endothelial damage leads to deposition of platelet-fibrin thrombus, which can subsequently be colonized by circulating bacteria to form infected vegetationEndothelial damage may result from valve sclerosis, rheumatic valvulitis, turbulent blood flow, catheters, or injections of solid particles in intravenous drug usersEndothelium can also be damaged by direct bacterial activityInflamed endothelium with associated fibronectin expression leads to formation of platelet-fibrin thrombus
sub_points: Endothelial damage may result from valve sclerosis, rheumatic valvulitis, turbulent blood flow, catheters, or injections of solid particles in intravenous drug users
Endothelium can also be damaged by direct bacterial activity
Inflamed endothelium with associated fibronectin expression leads to formation of platelet-fibrin thrombus

Pathophysiology.text: Vegetations that are large, mobile, or in mitral position are associated with increased risk of symptomatic embolism

Diagnosis of fastidious organisms may require special growth conditionsIn suspected cases of infective endocarditis in which blood cultures are initially negative, microbiology laboratory should be asked to retain blood cultures for at least 2 weeksHACEK organisms can be isolated on enriched or chocolate agarA. actinomycetemcomitansmay take 30 days to growLegionellaspp. require buffered charcoal yeast extract for optimal growthBrucellaspp. are fastidious intracellular parasites that require Brucella broth or trypticase soy brothShell vial assays may improve sensitivity for intracellular organisms such asBartonellaspp.

Other Laboratory Findings.text: ~ 50% of patients may have normocytic-normochromic anemia and leukocytosis
Elevated inflammatory markers are present in 2/3 of cases
Rheumatoid factor, antinuclear antibodies, and anti-DNA antibodies may be considered in culture-negative endocarditis to rule out noninfectious causes of endocarditis
Urinalysis may show microscopic hematuria, red cell casts, or pyuria

Clinical Diagnosis.text: ECG is used to identify alterations in conduction, such as 1st-degree atrioventricular block or bundle branch block, which can occur with paravalvular or myocardial extension of infection

Terminology.text: Meningitis: Inflammation of meninges caused by viral, bacterial, or fungal infectionAssociated with headache, fever, sensitivity to light, and nuchal rigidity
sub_points: Associated with headache, fever, sensitivity to light, and nuchal rigidity

Clinical Applications.text: Streptococcus agalactiae(group B streptococcus),Listeria monocytogenes, andEscherichia coliare most common causes in infants < 1 month old
Streptococcus pneumoniaeis most common cause of bacterial meningitis worldwide (~ 70% of isolates)
Neisseria meningitidisis common cause of bacterial meningitis in young adults; associated with crowded conditions (e.g., dormitories, military barracks)
Most common causes of aseptic meningitis are enterovirus (~ 70%), herpes simplex virus (HSV), andBorrelia burgdorferiinfections

Clinical Importance of Meningitis Diagno.text: Infection of central nervous system (CNS) can be rapidly fatal
Diagnosis of CNS infection is critical for initiation of appropriate antibiotics

Definitions.text: Meningitis: Inflammation of meninges caused by viral, bacterial, or fungal infectionAssociated with headache, fever, sensitivity to light, and nuchal rigidity
sub_points: Associated with headache, fever, sensitivity to light, and nuchal rigidity

Definitions.text: Aseptic meningitis: Meningitis without positive bacterial or fungal culture
Meninges: Inner coverings of brain and spinal cord (i.e., dura mater, arachnoid, and pia mater)
Encephalitis: Inflammation of brain parenchymaAssociated with altered mental status
sub_points: Associated with altered mental status

Definitions.text: Brudzinski sign: Bending of hips and knees when neck is flexed due to nuchal rigidity
Kernig sign: Pain and inability to straighten leg when hip is flexed to 90°, caused by muscle rigidity

Host Factors.text: Neonates at risk for meningitis due to immature immune system, higher permeability of blood-brain barrier, and colonizing bacteria in female vaginal tract
Meningitis due toCryptococcusorMycobacterium tuberculosisshould be considered very likely in patients with advanced HIV disease

sub_points: Due to spleen's critical role in removing pathogens that are intracellular or covered in polysaccharide capsule

Clinical Presentation.text: Chronic meningitisOften occurs in immunocompromised patientsPresents with insidious onset of fever, headache, stiff neck, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, confusion, and mental deteriorationSymptoms may exist for a month or longer before medical attention is sought

Clinical Presentation.text: CT and MR may be considered as adjunctive diagnostics tests but results are generally nonspecific and show meningeal enhancement

Cerebrospinal Fluid Interpretation.text: Lumbar puncture is often 1st step in diagnosis of patient with suspected CNS infection
Total protein and white blood cell (WBC) counts reflect inflammation in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Decreased glucose CSF/blood ratio is sign of glucose consumption by active infection
Up to 40% of persons withCryptococcusmay have unremarkable CSF WBC < 5 cells/μL

Gram Stain and Culture.text: Gram stain (40% and 70% sensitivity) and CSF culture (60-90% sensitivity) are most common tests used to diagnose bacterial meningitis andCryptococcusGram stain should be prepared by cytocentrifugationIf > 1 mL of CSF is submitted, it should be centrifuged and sediment used for culture media inoculation
sub_points: Gram stain should be prepared by cytocentrifugation
If > 1 mL of CSF is submitted, it should be centrifuged and sediment used for culture media inoculation

Gram Stain and Culture.text: Routine bacteriologic media should include chocolate agar plate, 5% sheep blood agar plate, and enrichment broth

Traditional acid-fast bacteria (AFB) staining has poor sensitivity forM. tuberculosis(3.3%), while culture is too slow to direct treatment; tuberculosis (TB) therapy will usually be empirically initiated if clinical suspicion after exclusion of other treatable conditions

Latex Agglutination Tests.text: Used for diagnosis ofS. pneumoniae,N. meningitidis, group BStreptococcus,H. influenzaetype B,Escherichia coli, andCryptococcus
Agglutination assays may contain either polyclonal or monoclonal antibody or antigen from infectious agent

Lateral Flow Immunochromatographic Assay.text: LFA is rapid and cheap surrogate for CSF culture ofCryptococcus(sensitivity 99.3%, specificity 99.1%)Also available for meningococcal and pneumococcal meningitis
sub_points: Also available for meningococcal and pneumococcal meningitis

Molecular Diagnostics.text: PCR testing for herpes simplex virus (HSV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), Cytomegalovirus (CMV), and enterovirus in CNS infections has sensitivity nearing 100%RT-PCR multiplex assays can target several DNA fragments simultaneously to test panel of pathogens
sub_points: RT-PCR multiplex assays can target several DNA fragments simultaneously to test panel of pathogens

Molecular Diagnostics.text: 16s rRNA PCR can also be used to detect bacterial pathogens in presumed culture-negative bacterial meningitis

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Specimens for viral culture should be collected in acute phase of infection before virus ceases to shed
Contamination of specimens by bacteria or fungi may prevent viral cultivation
Potentially contaminated specimens must be treated in viral transport medium to kill bacteria and fungi
Sterile specimens can be directly inoculated into cell culture

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Identification of viruses in cell culture requires identification of CPE in inoculated cell culture

Pattern of CPE, rate of progression, and type of cells affected may give clue to type of virus present, but confirmation using fluorescently labeled antisera, acid lability, neutralization, or hemadsorption may be necessary
Cell types routinely used for viral detection include primary monkey kidney cells, human diploid fibroblasts, and HEp-2 cells
Shell vial culture is more rapid than conventional culture but can detect only 1 type of virus per vial

sub_points: They may infect some cell types and not others

Clinical Correlates.text: Serology is primarily used to diagnose infections when virus cannot be cultivated in cell culture or detected readily by immunoassay or molecular methods
Viral serologies are often used to determine whether previous infection or vaccination has produced lasting immune response

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Diagnosis of active viral disease can be accomplished by detection of virus-specific IgM in acute-phase specimen or by detection of 4x IgG antibody titer rise between acute and convalescent sera
Single, very high convalescent IgG titer may be sufficient to suggest infection
Serologic methods to detect antibodies include complement fixation, ELISA, Western blotting, neutralization, hemagglutination inhibition

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Viral infection transmitted by respiratory droplets and contact with contaminated surfaces

Clinical Issues.text: Majority of children infected by 2 years of age; hospitalization rare in healthy patients
Lower respiratory symptoms in 25-40% of cases; upper respiratory less common
Laboratory: RT-PCR, antigen testing
Treatment: Supportive; palivizumab for high-risk infants

Macroscopic.text: Heavy congested lungs with areas of consolidation and expansion, and plugging of small airways

Microscopic.text: Airway epithelium with inflammation, ulceration, necrosis, and sloughing/obstruction, diffuse alveolar damage, and regenerative changes (e.g., squamous metaplasia)
Multinucleated syncytial giant cells with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions lining bronchi, bronchioles, and alveoli

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Human parainfluenza virus infection: Multinucleated giant cells with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions; confirm by PCR, antigen testing
Human metapneumovirus infection: Eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions; confirm by PCR, antigen testing
Measles virus infection: Eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions, intranuclear inclusions with clear halo; Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells; confirm by PCR, culture, serology
Influenza virus infection: No specific viral cytopathic effects; confirm by PCR, IHC, antigen testing
Asthma: Detached epithelium, eosinophilic plugging, smooth muscle hyperplasia, marked inflammatory infiltrate

Definitions.text: Syncytial: Derived from Latin "syn" (together) and "cyt" (cell)
Pneumoviridaefamily: Derived from "pneumo" (lung)

Infectious Agents.text: Viral infection transmitted by respiratory droplets and contact with contaminated surfaces; incubation period: 2-8 days; infectious period: 5 days to 3 weeks
Infection of respiratory epithelium results in inflammation/necrosis and formation of "plugs" of mucus, fibrin, and necrotic material in smaller airways
F proteins cause cell membrane fusion to form syncytia

Epidemiology.text: Worldwide: ~ 64 million infections/year (160,000 deaths)
Most common in fall, winter, and spring in temperate climates but can vary annually
Affects 70% of infants by 1 year of age and ~ 100% of infants by 2 years of age (peak infection: 2-3 months)

Presentation.text: Lower respiratory tract infections (bronchiolitis or pneumonia) occur in 25-40% of cases
Upper respiratory tract infections (croup, otitis media, rhinitis, tracheobronchitis, fever) are less common
Secondary asthma exacerbations and coinfections with bacteria, fungi, or other viruses also occur
High-risk factors: HIV infection, stem cell transplantation, prematurity, and congenital heart disease

Laboratory Tests.text: RT-PCR (individual or multiplex assay)
Antigen testing in nasopharyngeal specimens 80-90% sensitive in young children but lower for adults
Serology and cell culture less commonly used

Treatment.text: No FDA-approved vaccines or specific antiviral treatments
Palivizumab (monoclonal anti-RSV protein F antibody) for high-risk infants (5 monthly injections)
Supportive treatment ± ribavirin for severe cases

Prognosis.text: Low mortality in previously healthy patients (0.3-1.0%)
Up to 40% mortality in very young infants, preterm infants, and patients with HIV or other immunodeficiency or underlying pulmonary or cardiac disease
Repeated infections may increase risk for asthma

Radiographic Findings.text: Hyperinflation, diffuse interstitial markings, and peribronchial thickening

Viral Features.text: 15.2 kb nucleotide genome; 10 genes (NS1,NS2,N,P,M,SH,G,F,M2, andL) (11 proteins)

Culture.text: Grows in HEp-2 cells; syncytia formation after 3-7 days

General Features.text: Heavy congested lungs with areas of consolidation and expansion and plugging of small airways

Histologic Features.text: Airway epithelium with inflammation, ulceration, necrosis, and sloughing/obstruction, diffuse alveolar damage, and regenerative changes (e.g., squamous metaplasia)

Cytologic Features.text: Multinucleated giant syncytial cells with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions lining airways

Immunohistochemistry.text: anti-RSV antibodies highlight cytoplasm of infected epithelial cells

Human Parainfluenza Virus Infection.text: Multinucleated giant cells with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions; confirm by PCR, antigen testing

Human Metapneumovirus Infection.text: Eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions; confirm by PCR, antigen testing

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Principle of vaccination: Produce long-lasting immunity against disease by mimicking immune reaction to infection with that pathogen, but without inducing disease
Development of effective vaccine requires fundamental knowledge of immune response associated with exposure to specific pathogen

Overview.text: Principle of vaccination: Produce long-lasting immunity against disease by mimicking immune reaction to infection with that pathogen, but without inducing disease
In most cases, vaccines are developed to protect community of people and so are designed to elicit responses in majority of exposed individuals despite differences in immunogenetics
Vaccines developed from highly purified antigens may elicit stronger immune response, but may also be ineffective in individuals who lack immune repertoire to respond to that antigen
Vaccines developed from whole organisms are most antigenically diverse and ensure immune response in heterogeneous population
Development of effective vaccine requires fundamental knowledge of immune response associated with exposure to specific pathogen
In general, immune response to viruses involvesT-cell-mediated immunityInterferon responseHumoral immunity with either IgG or IgA

History of Antiviral Vaccines.text: 1st antiviral vaccine was to yellow fever; developed in late 1930s
Influenza vaccine was next; developed in 1939
Polio, measles, mumps, and rubella vaccines were developed ~ 15 years later
Since 1990, vaccines for varicella, rotavirus, hepatitis A, influenza, HPV, and herpes zoster have been brought to market

Live-Attenuated Vaccines.text: Developed by proliferating virus ex vivo until it was incapable of infecting human cells, presumably by mutations in viral genome
Includes vaccines to polio (oral), measles, mumps, rubella, varicella, cold-adapted influenza, rotavirus, and zoster (shingles)

Recombinant Vaccines.text: Like killed (whole organism) vaccines, recombinant vaccines are unable to replicate in host, cannot be transmitted to another person, and are generally less immunogenic than live-attenuated vaccines

DNA Vaccines.text: Plasmid containing antigen-coding gene and reporter is introduced into cells, causing high-level expression of antigen in cells
This mimics natural infection of cells and immune response to such infection

Adjuvants.text: Adjuvant systems combine traditional adjuvants with immunostimulatory molecules

Reverse Vaccinology.text: Classic vaccine development has relied on using proteins or oligosaccharides purified from pathogen without predetermination of which antigen to use
Modern vaccine development uses knowledge of genome and proteins of pathogen to rationally design potential vaccines
Using genomes of multiple strains of same pathogen allows researchers to choose potential targets that will be recognized in most (or all) strains and increases vaccine efficacy

Microarray- or proteome-based studies allow researchers to identify proteins that are highly expressed during infection, which may be better vaccine targets than traditional or genome-identified antigens
Structural biology may enhance vaccine development by allowing rational choice of protein or oligosaccharide antigens that will be most immunogenic

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Viral infections transmitted by respiratory droplets
Mutations in hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) result in antigenic drift
Reassortment ofHAandNAgenes (antigenic shift) can lead to pandemics

Clinical Issues.text: Millions hospitalized yearly with seasonal influenza A and B
Abrupt onset of fever, myalgia, headache, malaise, nonproductive cough, sore throat, and rhinitis
Complications include viral pneumonia or secondary bacterial pneumonia, encephalopathy, transverse myelitis, myositis, myocarditis, and pericarditis
Annual vaccine recommended for influenza; antivirals can decrease symptoms
Laboratory testing includes rapid antigen testing, viral culture, direct or indirect fluorescent antibody staining, and nucleic acid amplification testing (single or multiplex assay)

Microscopic.text: Seasonal influenza A and B: Diffuse, superficial, necrotizing tracheobronchitis with sloughing of ciliated respiratory epithelium
Pandemic influenza A (H1N1): Inflammation of large airways and diffuse alveolar damage and hemorrhage
No viral inclusions detectable by light microscopy

Ancillary Tests.text: Antiinfluenza A/B antibodies available at some reference laboratories

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Other respiratory viral or bacterial infections, including respiratory syncytial virus, human metapneumovirus, parainfluenza viruses, rhinoviruses, coronaviruses,Mycoplasma pneumoniae, andLegionellaspecies
Noninfectious causes of diffuse alveolar damage, including drugs, inhaled toxins, shock, sepsis, and collagen vascular disease

Definitions.text: Orthomyxoviridaefamily: Derived from "ortho" (straight) and "myxo" (mucus)

Infectious Agents.text: Viral infections transmitted person to person via respiratory droplets; incubation period is 1-4 days, and infectious period is 1 day before until 5 days after onset of symptoms

Virus hemagglutinin (HA) binds sialic acids on cell surface, causing viral uptake into host cells, while neuraminidase (NA) enzymatically removes sialic acids, promoting viral release from infected cells
Antigenic drift: Production of new viral strains by mutations inHAandNAgenes
Antigenic shift: Development of new combinations ofHAandNAgenes due to reassortment of viral genome subunits; can result in pandemics

Presentation.text: Abrupt onset of fever, myalgia, headache, malaise, nonproductive cough, sore throat, and rhinitis

Laboratory Tests.text: Best samples: Nasopharyngeal or nasal swab, nasal aspirate or wash (collect with 4 days of onset of illness)
Rapid antigen assays (≤ 15 minutes ); 50-70% sensitive and > 90% specific; no subtype information
Viral culture (3-10 days); essential for strain determination and surveillance
Immunofluorescence, direct or indirect fluorescent antibody staining (1-4 hours)
RT-PCR (1-6 hours); single or multiplexed assays with other respiratory virus panels (e.g., respiratory syncytial virus, parainfluenza viruses, and adenovirus)

Natural History.text: Self-limited infection that resolves after 3-7 days (cough and malaise can last for > 2 weeks)
Complications include viral pneumonia or secondary bacterial pneumonia, encephalopathy, transverse myelitis, myositis, myocarditis, and pericarditis

Treatment.text: Influenza vaccine: Recommended annually for all persons > 6 months oldTraditionally produced by egg-based methods; cell-based and recombinant vaccines approved by FDA in 2012 and 2013Quadrivalent formulations containing HA antigen of 2 influenza A strains (i.e., H1N1 and H3N2) and 2 influenza B strains (Victoria and Yamagata)Formulations are updated yearly to match antigenically circulating strains according to WHO predictions; estimated yearly effectiveness ranged 19-60% from 2009-2022Universal influenza vaccines currently under development
sub_points: Traditionally produced by egg-based methods; cell-based and recombinant vaccines approved by FDA in 2012 and 2013
Quadrivalent formulations containing HA antigen of 2 influenza A strains (i.e., H1N1 and H3N2) and 2 influenza B strains (Victoria and Yamagata)
Formulations are updated yearly to match antigenically circulating strains according to WHO predictions; estimated yearly effectiveness ranged 19-60% from 2009-2022
Universal influenza vaccines currently under development

Highest risk at age > 65, children, pregnant women, and those with underlying health conditions (morbid obesity, diabetes, underlying respiratory illness)

Pleural effusions are suggestive of bacterial coinfection

Detectable by immunofluorescence after 4-8 days

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Ubiquitous DNA viruses spread via respiratory droplets
Most adults have seropositivity to several serotypes; commonly found in respiratory tract and stools of children

Clinical Issues.text: Range of clinical infections (mild to life threatening): Keratoconjunctivitis, tonsillitis, bronchiolitis, pneumonia, laryngotracheobronchitis, myocarditis, gastroenteritis, colitis, appendicitis, hepatitis, meningitis/encephalitis, nephritis, hemorrhagic cystitis
Severe, life-threatening disease in immunosuppressed
PCR on tissue sample, fluid, or blood; rising viral load correlates with risk of severe disease

Microscopic.text: Classic viral cytopathic effects include glassy to smudged basophilic nuclear inclusions that must be differentiated from reactive cells by antiadenovirus IHC
Lungs: Minimal inflammation to DAD
Liver: Focal to extensive necrosis with limited inflammation
Gastrointestinal tract: Ulceration, inflammation, cell sloughing, and apoptosis
Brain: Minimal inflammation to perivascular cuffing
Heart: Limited mononuclear to dense inflammation with necrosis
Kidneys: Acute necrotizing tubulointerstitial nephritis

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: HSV-1/2, VZV: Multinucleation, margination of chromatin, and nuclear molding
CMV: 2-4x size of adjacent cells, large "owl eye" nuclear inclusion
Polyomavirus: Demyelinating (polyoma) vs. meningoencephalitis (adenovirus)
DAD: Reactive, degenerative cells may be suspicious for viral cytopathic effect; any condition leading to DAD can mimic adenoviral infection (and vice versa)

Definitions.text: Mastadenovirusgenus andAdenoviridaefamily: Derived from "mastos" (breast/mammal) and "adeno" (for adenoids where first isolated)
Adenovirus (serovar #) = Ad#

Infectious Agents.text: Ubiquitous DNA viruses present in most vertebrates and able to infect many cell types; spread primarily via respiratory droplets as well as fecal routes and aerosols

During initial infection (2-14 days incubation), virus enters epithelial cell via binding to CD46 or CAR adhesion receptor, replicates through entire lytic cycle, produces cytolysis ± inflammatory response (depending on patient)
Chronic infection and reactivation of latency via unknown process occurring in various lymphoid tissues
Oncogenic in animal models but not, to date, in humans
Common tool for vaccine vectors and for development of novel cancer virotherapies

Epidemiology.text: Ubiquitous viral family affecting all age groups
Most adults have seropositivity to several serotypes
Commonly found in respiratory tract and stool of children

Site.text: Lungs, gastrointestinal tract, liver, heart, kidneys, brain, conjunctiva

Presentation.text: Range of clinical infections (mild to life threatening)
Keratoconjunctivitis (pink eye) &/or tonsillitis (Ad3, 4, 7, 8, 19, 37, 53, 54)
Bronchiolitis &/or pneumonia (Ad3, 4, 7, 14, 21, 30)
Laryngotracheobronchitis (Ad1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 14)
Myocarditis (chronic, leading to cardiomyopathy)
Gastroenteritis, colitis, appendicitis (Ad40, 41)
Hepatitis (Ad1-5, 7, 31): Fulminant, similar to herpesvirus
Meningitis/encephalitis (Ad2, 7)
Nephritis, hemorrhagic cystitis (Ad11, 21)

Laboratory Tests.text: Serology is challenging to interpret unless serovar matched to symptoms
Culture from direct tissue sample > blood
Antigen detection: Stool for enteric (Ad40, Ad41)
Direct fluorescence antigen detection &/or PCR on nasal swabs

PCR: Molecular detection of virus DNA or RNABroad panels available for screening and diagnosisDirectly on tissue sample, fluid, or blood; most commonly used for enteric infection (stool) and CNS infection (CSF)Qualitative or quantitative: Rising viral load correlates with risk of severe diseaseShould be used with caution due to ubiquitous nature of virus
sub_points: Broad panels available for screening and diagnosis
Directly on tissue sample, fluid, or blood; most commonly used for enteric infection (stool) and CNS infection (CSF)
Qualitative or quantitative: Rising viral load correlates with risk of severe disease
Should be used with caution due to ubiquitous nature of virus

Treatment.text: FDA-approved vaccine for Ad4/Ad7 (military use only)
Supportive treatment for mild disease
No specific antivirals available: IV ribavirin and cidofovir used in severe cases

Prognosis.text: Most serovars: Self-limited infection, particularly in immunocompetent
Immunocompromised (e.g., solid organ and bone marrow transplant recipients) at highest risk for severe disease: Mortality 50-80% in children and up to 70% in adults

Radiographic Findings.text: Lungs: Pneumonia, bronchial wall thickening, hyperaeration
Liver: Hypodense lesions on CT

Virus Features.text: 70-90 nm in size with icosahedral capsid
88 human serotypes divided into 7 species (groups A-G)

Culture.text: Grows in cell culture [e.g., HEK, HEp-2, A549 (laboratory diagnosis), Graham 293 (enteric adenovirus)] in 1-3 weeks
Confirmed by cytopathic effect with positive direct antigen visualization

General Features.text: Lungs: Heavy/edematous, congested mucosa, necrotic foci
Liver: Hepatomegaly with foci of necrosis
Gastrointestinal tract: Extensive mucosal ulcerations

Histologic Features.text: Classic viral cytopathic effects include glassy to smudged basophilic nuclear inclusions that must be differentiated from reactive cells; nonspecific viral cytopathic effects are also common
Lungs: Minimal inflammation to necrotizing bronchitis/bronchiolitis or acute necrotizing alveolitis resembling diffuse alveolar damage (DAD)
Liver: Focal to extensive necrosis with limited inflammation

Gastrointestinal tract: Increased lymphoplasmacytic and neutrophilic infiltrates in lamina propria; blunting and flattening of villous architecture; loss of nuclear orientation, sloughing, and apoptotic epithelial cells
Brain: Minimal inflammation to perivascular cuffing and increased cellularity; necrosis is not a usually feature
Heart: Limited mononuclear to dense lymphohistiocytic interstitial inflammation with necrosis
Kidneys: Acute tubular injury and interstitial nephritis, focal necrosis of tubules, interstitial hemorrhage, edema, granulomas

Cytologic Features.text: Medium to large cells with variable nuclear changes, nucleoli, smudged chromatin; background milieu may show necrosis or limited inflammation

Immunohistochemistry.text: Antibodies targeting adenovirus antigens show nuclear and cytoplasmic staining
Should always be considered in concert with herpesviruses without prior diagnosis

Immunofluorescence.text: Performed on fresh, frozen, or FFPE tissue sections for confirmatory diagnosis

In Situ Hybridization.text: Specific DNA probes for adenovirus target (available in reference laboratories)
Use with caution due to ubiquitous nature of virus

PCR.text: Molecular detection of virus DNA or RNA can be performed on tissue samples

Electron Microscopy.text: Demonstration of icosahedral particles consistent with adenovirus

Herpesvirus Family (All Sites).text: HSV-1/2, varicella-zoster virus (VZV): Multinucleation, margination of chromatin, and nuclear molding
Cytomegalovirus (CMV): 2-4x size of adjacent cells, large "owl's-eye" nuclear inclusion; smaller cytoplasmic inclusions
When viral cytopathic effect is suspected in immunosuppressed patients, panel of HSV, VZV, CMV, and adenovirus IHC is advised

Polyomavirus (Cerebral Cortex, Kidney/Bl.text: Demyelinating (polyoma) vs. meningoencephalitis (adenovirus); IHC for both agents is confirmatory

Other Viral Infections (All Sites).text: RNA viruses and others resulting in necrosis without inflammation; exclude adenovirus by IHC; reference tissue testing for confirmation of other viral infections is recommended

Bacterial Infection (All Sites).text: Destructive, necrotic lesions; demonstration of bacteria on Gram or silver staining with positive cultures

Diffuse Alveolar Damage (Lung).text: Reactive, degenerative cells may be suspicious for viral cytopathic effect
Any condition leading to DAD can mimic adenoviral infection (and vice versa); clinical history, culture, and IHC can exclude DAD of other causes

Laboratory: RT-PCR (respiratory secretions), viral culture, antigen detection, serology

Definitions.text: Paramyxoviridaefamily: Derived from "para" (beyond) and "myxo" (mucus)

Viral culture

Mortality rare in immunocompetent

Rhinoviruses,Human Metapneumovirus, and.name: Rhinoviruses,Human Metapneumovirus, and Other Respiratory Virus Infections

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Viral infections spread person to person via respiratory droplets [rhinoviruses andHuman metapneumovirus(HMPV)] or via aerosolized droplets from infected rodents (hantaviruses)

Clinical Issues.text: Rhinoviruses cause mild upper respiratory tract infections; lower tract disease increasingly recognized
HMPV affects both upper and lower respiratory tracts; severe disease in premature infants/older adults
Hantaviruses can cause hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS) with high mortality
Laboratory: RT-PCR, antigen detection, serology

Microscopic.text: Rhinoviruses: Minimal damage to nasal epithelium, mild inflammatory infiltrate; bronchiolitis
HMPV: Intraluminal, sloughed epithelial cells and debris, interstitial edema/inflammation, alveolitis, and eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions
Hantaviruses: Fibrinous pulmonary edema, hyaline membranes, immunoblastic proliferation involving reticuloendothelial system

Ancillary Tests.text: IHC positive in nasal/airway epithelium (rhinoviruses, HMPV) or endothelial cells (hantaviruses)

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Other viral causes of tracheobronchitis, pneumonia, and giant cell pneumonia (e.g., measles, influenza, adenoviruses, coxsackieviruses, respiratory syncytial virus, varicella-zoster virus, herpes simplex virus): Detection virus by culture, PCR, IHC, etc.
Allergic rhinitis: Associated with specific allergens; may be seasonal or perennial; improves with steroids and allergen avoidance
