Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infection via ingestion or inhalation of microsporidia resistant spores, obligate intracellular pathogens (currently classified as fungi)

Clinical Issues.text: Opportunistic disease that affects immunocompromised patients (e.g., AIDS and transplant patients)
GI microsporidiosis: Chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss
Extraintestinal: Ocular, musculoskeletal, CNS, and skin
Albendazole; topical fumagillin for keratoconjunctivitis
Organisms (ovoid, refractile spores 0.7-4 μm) identified in stool and other tissues by modified trichrome, rapid Gram chromotrope, and fluorochrome stains

Microscopic.text: Mild to severe villous blunting with mild lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate
Organisms (2- to 3-μm spores and larger plasmodia) identified as clusters within supranuclear cytoplasm of epithelial cells
Organisms poorly staining on H&E but may be birefringent or polarize and highlighted by Gram, Warthin-Starry, Giemsa, and modified trichrome stains
Electron microscopy or PCR required for speciation

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Cryptosporidiosis: Larger oocysts (2-5 μm) present at surface of small intestine villi
Cyclosporiasis: Larger round (2- to 3-μm) and crescentic (5- to 6-μm) forms in cytoplasm parasitophorous vacuoles
Cystoisosporiasis: Schizonts and merozoites with crescentic or banana-shaped forms (25-30 µm) located in cytoplasm
Cytomegalovirus infection: Enlarged cells with nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions; confirm with IHC, PCR, or serology
Giardiasis: Trophozoites (leaf-shaped with 2 nuclei and 4 pairs of flagella) in small intestine lumen

Definitions.text: Greek: "Mikros" (small) + "sporos" (seed)

Infectious Agents.text: Infection with microsporidia, ubiquitous obligate intracellular pathogens via ingestion or inhalation of resistant spores

Spores extrude polar tubule to infect host cell; sporoplasm then undergoes extensive multiplication by merogony and maturation by sporogony until host cell cytoplasm is filled; cell membrane disruption releases spores shed in feces
Microsporidia are classified in fungi kingdom (previously thought to be protozoa); they lack mitochondria and flagella, instead possessing mitosomes

1,500 species identified; human pathogens includeAnncaliia(formerlyBrachiola)algerae,A. connori,A. vesicularum,Encephalitozoon cuniculi,E. hellem,E. intestinalis,Enterocytozoon bieneusi,Microsporidium ceylonensis,M. africanum,Nosema ocularum,Pleistophoraspp.,Trachipleistophora hominis,T. anthropophthera,Vittaforma corneae, andTubulinosema acridophagus

Epidemiology.text: Opportunistic disease that affects immunocompromised patients (e.g., AIDS and transplant patients); generally occurs when CD4(+) T-cell counts fall below 150 in HIV patients
Cases have been reported in immunocompetent individuals

Presentation.text: GI microsporidiosis: Chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss
Ocular microsporidiosis: Blurred vision, foreign body sensation, pain, redness, and tearing
Disseminated microsporidiosis: Musculoskeletal (myalgia, weakness), CNS (headache, seizure), dermatologic (nodular lesions)
Early diagnosis is essential for preventing significantly associated morbidity and mortality of extraintestinal microsporidiosis

Treatment.text: Albendazole
Topical fumagillin for keratoconjunctivitis
Thalidomide (unresponsive chronic diarrhea)

Stool Examination.text: Modified trichrome stain shows ovoid, refractile spores (0.7-4 μm in diameter) with bright red wall
Rapid Gram chromotrope shows spores that stain dark violet with enhanced equatorial stripe
Fluorochrome stains can be used in stool as well as urine, mucus, and tissue sections

Histologic Features.text: Mild to severe villous blunting with mild lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate
Organisms (2- to 3-μm spores and larger plasmodia) identified as clusters within supranuclear cytoplasm of epithelial cells
Organisms are poorly staining on H&E but may be birefringent or polarize

Histochemistry.text: Gram, Warthin-Starry, Giemsa, and modified trichrome stains highlight organisms

PCR.text: Species and genus targeted assays available; greater sensitivity and specificity than histology and stool examination

Electron Microscopy.text: Can confirm diagnosis and distinguish between organisms

Cryptosporidiosis.text: Small, round, bluish-purple bodies (2-5 μm) present at luminal tips and surfaces of villi of small intestine

Cyclosporiasis.text: Round forms (2-3 μm) and crescentic merozoites (5-6 μm) located toward luminal surface of small bowel epithelium within parasitophorous vacuole ("halo") in cytoplasm

Cystoisosporiasis.text: Schizonts and merozoites with crescentic or banana-shaped forms (25-30 µm) located toward luminal surfaces of epithelial cells but within cytoplasm

Cytomegalovirus Infection.text: Intracellular inclusions surrounded by clear halo in tissue biopsy; positive IHC, PCR, or antibody tests

Giardiasis.text: Stool examination for trophozoites (leaf-shaped with 2 nuclei and 4 pairs of flagella) or cysts (smooth walled and oval with curved median bodies, axonemes, and nuclei)
Stool antigen ELISA when 3 O&P tests are negative

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infection withAscaris lumbricoides, largest nematode (roundworm) infecting humans via ingestion of embryonated eggs

Clinical Issues.text: Worldwide distribution and more common in areas of poverty with increased soil exposure
Mostly asymptomatic; can cause malnutrition and stunted growth, Loeffler syndrome, intestinal obstruction with bowel infarction, and liver abscess

Macroscopic.text: Adult worms (males 15-30 cm, females 20-35 cm) in lumen of small bowel; seen on colonoscopy or passed in stool

Microscopic.text: Adult worms: Thick acellular cuticle, thin hypodermis, tall polymyarian muscle cells, and pair of lateral cords; coiled ovary and gravid uterus (females)
Fertilized eggs are rounded (45-75 µm in length) with thick shell and external mammillated layer (may be decorticated)
Unfertilized eggs are elongated (90 µm) have thinner shell and variable outer layer
Lung: Eosinophils ± larval forms
Gastrointestinal tract: Normal or ischemic with necrosis
Liver: Adult worms and eggs, neutrophilic abscesses, eosinophils, and giant cells

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Trematode infection of liver: Limited inflammation; size and shape of eggs with opercula for speciation
Echinococcosis of liver: Contain multiple protoscolices with birefringent hooklets
Loeffler syndrome: Also caused byStrongyloidesspp., hookworm; other sources of pulmonary eosinophilia lack larvae/adult worms

Definitions.text: Greek: "Askaris" (intestinal worm)
Latin: "Lumbricus" (earthworm)

Infectious Agents.text: Infection withAscaris lumbricoides(soil-transmitted helminth), largest nematode (roundworm) infecting humans
Unembryonated eggs pass out of stool into environment, mature into embryonated eggs in soil, and are ingested by next host
Larvae hatch in intestinal tract, migrate through tissues/bloodstream to lungs where they mature into adults and are coughed up and swallowed
Adult worms reside in small bowel, copulate, and release eggs
Worms secrete molecules to protect against immune clearance, includingAscariscarboxypeptidase inhibitor (ACI)
Links to asthma and allergy through IL13 and STAT6
Ascarisderived from pigs is referred to asA. suum,but there is lack of consensus as separate species

Epidemiology.text: Estimated 800 million to 1.2 billion people infected
Worldwide distribution and more common in areas of poverty with increased soil exposure

Presentation.text: Vast majority of infections are asymptomatic
Chronic infection can lead to malnutrition and stunted growth
Loeffler syndrome: Pulmonary alveolar space eosinophilia in response to larval passage
Large burden: Abdominal pain, swollen abdomen, intestinal obstruction, bowel infarction, and nausea/vomiting
Adult worms pass through ampulla of Vater, become trapped in liver, causing right upper quadrant pain, transaminitis, cholestasis, and abscess formation

Laboratory Tests.text: Stool exam for ova and parasites is almost always positive if gravid female worms are in patient due to large burden of eggs per day produced (200,000 per female)Presence of only male worms will not produce positive stool examsPresence of only female worms will produce unfertilized eggs at lower numbers than gravid females
sub_points: Presence of only male worms will not produce positive stool exams
Presence of only female worms will produce unfertilized eggs at lower numbers than gravid females

Treatment.text: Gastrointestinal obstruction/infarction may require surgical decompression/resection
Liver abscess may require surgical drainage
Albendazole or mebendazole for intestinal infection

Prognosis.text: Most patients return to normal health after treatment
Obstruction may lead to infarction, sepsis, and death without treatment
Liver masses may progress to frank hepatitis or lead to scarring

Parasite Features.text: Adult female worms are 20-35 cm with straight tails, and adult males are 15-30 cm with curved tails; both have 3 "lips" at anterior end of body without teeth/hooklets; inhabit lumen of small intestine, and can migrate elsewhere
Unfertilized eggs: Elongated (up to 90 µm in length), thinner shell, and variable mammillated layer; mass of retractile granules
Fertilized eggs: Rounded (45-75 µm in length), thick shell with external mammillated layer; decorticated eggs are fertilized eggs with absent outer layer
2nd-stage larvae: 300 µm in length, prominent single lateral alae, intestine with lumen and 3 cells, small excretory columns
3rd-stage larvae: 1.6 mm in length, larger excretory columns, prominent alae, and patent gut lined with microvilli

Culture.text: No role for culture in diagnosis

Colonoscopy.text: Ascarisworms are very large and easily identified on visual inspection of colon

Stool.text: These large worms may be passed in stool with high burden, after treatment, or spontaneously, and patients may attest to presence of "common earthworms"

Sputum or Expectorated.text: Through lung passage stage, worms may mature into adults and expire in respiratory system to be coughed up whole or in fragments

Histologic Features.text: Adult worm sections contain thick acellular outer cuticle, thin hypodermis, tall polymyarian muscle cells, and pair of prominent lateral cords; short muscular esophagus, simple intestinal tube with columnar cells; paired coiled genital tubes/uteri with developing eggs (in females)
Eggs (± external mammillated layer) seen in tissue sections with abundant mixed inflammation, including neutrophilic abscesses, eosinophils, and giant cells
Lung: Eosinophils in alveolar spaces or in interstitium ± larval forms
Gastrointestinal tract: Resected tissue may appear normal (mechanical obstruction) or ischemic with necrosis
Liver: Cross sections of adult worms and eggs admixed with inflammation

Trematode Infection of Liver.text: Limited inflammation (natural habitat); size and shape of eggs with opercula aid in speciation

Echinococcosis of Liver.text: Larval stage ofEchinococcusspp. cestodes; cystic (E. granulosus) and alveolar (E. multilocularis) forms
Contain multiple protoscolices with birefringent hooklets

Loeffler Syndrome.text: Other sources of pulmonary eosinophilia occur

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Standard for diagnosis is microscopic examination of intestinal specimens for helminth eggs, larvae, or adult worms
Culture, serologic testing, and histology may be useful methods for diagnosis of intestinal helminth infections if ova and parasite examination is unrevealing

Microscopy.text: Standard for diagnosis: Ova and parasite examination for eggs, larvae, &/or adult worms in intestinal specimens
Specimen types for identification of intestinal helminthsStoolDuodenal aspirates or drainageSigmoidoscopy materialMucus collected by string test method (a.k.a. entero-test)

Culture.text: Fecal culture on agar plates can be used to increase number of larvae inStrongyloidesor hookworm infections
Allows for better recovery of larvae for differentiation of species

Serology.text: Serologic testing is available and useful for certain intestinal helminth infections where eggs, larvae, or adult worms are not detected by ova and parasite examinationThese include schistosomiasis, strongyloidiasis, paragonimiasis, and fascioliasis
sub_points: These include schistosomiasis, strongyloidiasis, paragonimiasis, and fascioliasis

Serology.text: Serologic methodology for helminth infectionsImmunoblotsEnzyme immunoassays (EIA)Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA)
sub_points: Immunoblots
Enzyme immunoassays (EIA)
Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA)

Serology.text: Antibody testing typically cannot differentiate current vs. past infection
Cross-reactivity is often observed with other helminth infections

Histology.text: Histologic examination of intestinal tissue biopsies stained with H&E may reveal helminth eggs, larvae, or adult worms

Clinical Correlates.text: Clonorchis sinensis: Liver trematode endemic in Asia
Acquired by eating raw, undercooked, pickled, or dried fish containingC. sinensismetacercaria
In humans, adult worms live in biliary ducts; cause liver disease when in high numbers
Treatment of choice: Praziquantel
Prevention: Thorough cooking of freshwater fish prior to consumption

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Ova and parasite examination of concentrated wet preparation (stool or duodenal aspirate) for helminth eggs is standard for diagnosis
C. sinensiseggs are classically ovoid in shape with prominent opercular shoulders and abopercular knob

Epidemiology.text: Clonorchis sinensis: Liver trematode (a.k.a. Chinese or oriental liver fluke)
Endemic in China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Vietnam~ 15 million people infected in these regions
sub_points: ~ 15 million people infected in these regions

Epidemiology.text: In United States, found in Asian immigrants or those who have eaten imported, undercooked fish containingC. sinensismetacercaria
Definitive hosts ofC. sinensisare fish-eating mammals, including humans, dogs, and cats

Transmission.text: Ingestion of raw, undercooked, dried, or pickled fish infected withC. sinensismetacercaria

Life Cycle.text: Embryonated eggs are deposited in biliary ducts and passed via stool into environment
Eggs are then ingested by freshwater snail host where hatched miracidia (1 per egg) develop into cercariaSubsequently released back into freshwater environment
sub_points: Subsequently released back into freshwater environment

Life Cycle.text: Cercaria then penetrate flesh of freshwater fish and encyst into metacercaria
Metacercaria excyst in duodenum and travel to bile ducts, where adult worms take ~ 1 month to mature
Humans and other mammals are infected by eating raw, undercooked or pickled fish
Adult worms live in biliary ducts and can survive for up to 20-25 years

Classic Clinical Findings.text: Symptoms are dependent on organism burdenInfections are most commonly asymptomatic when organism burden is lowWhen organism burden is high, symptoms are result of inflammation and intermittent obstruction of biliary ductsSymptoms include fever, nausea, abdominal pain, and jaundice
sub_points: Infections are most commonly asymptomatic when organism burden is low
When organism burden is high, symptoms are result of inflammation and intermittent obstruction of biliary ductsSymptoms include fever, nausea, abdominal pain, and jaundice
Symptoms include fever, nausea, abdominal pain, and jaundice

Classic Clinical Findings.text: Eosinophilia and higher IgE serum levels may be observed
In severe infections, biliary duct obstruction may result in liver enlargement, cirrhosis, cholecystitis, and cholangiocarcinoma

Treatment.text: Praziquantel is treatment of choice
Albendazole may be used as alternate treatment

Prevention.text: Thorough cooking of freshwater fish prior to consumption

Microscopy.text: Ova and parasite examination of stool or duodenal aspirates for helminth eggs is standard for diagnosis
Eggs are most commonly seen in concentrated wet preparationC. sinensiseggs are ovoid in shape measuring 28-30 μm by 14-18 μmProminent opercular shoulders and small abopercular knob at opposite end
sub_points: C. sinensiseggs are ovoid in shape measuring 28-30 μm by 14-18 μmProminent opercular shoulders and small abopercular knob at opposite end

sub_points: Transparent reddish-yellow color

Clinical Correlates.text: Enterobiasis is most common helminthic infection in United States and mostly affects young children
Transmission is by fecal-oral route
Most common symptoms of infection are perianal itching, restless sleep, irritability, and abdominal pain
Antihelmintic therapies are gold standard for treatment
Prevention is through proper sanitation practices

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Eggs are ovoid and smooth with characteristic flattened edge on 1 side

Adult females migrate from gastrointestinal tract to perianal folds to lay eggs; therefore, best method to collect eggs or worms for visualization is by using pinworm paddle or preparing scotch tape prep
Stool is not considered specimen of choice for diagnosis

Epidemiology.text: Enterobiasis (a.k.a. pinworm infection) is most common helminthic infection in United States~ 40 million people infected
sub_points: ~ 40 million people infected

Epidemiology.text: Enterobiasis occurs worldwide and commonly occurs in children 5-10 years of age in group environments (day cares and schools) and crowded situations
Women more commonly infected than men
Reinfection is common

Transmission.text: Transmission ofEnterobius vermicularisinfection is by fecal-oral route
Self-infection occurs by scratching of perianal region and transferring eggs to mouth
Person-to-person transmission occurs when eggs contaminate environmentClothes, bed linens, toys and other surfaces
sub_points: Clothes, bed linens, toys and other surfaces

Transmission.text: Less frequently, eggs may also be inhaled

Life Cycle.text: Infection occurs when infective eggs are ingested
Larvae hatch in small intestine; adult worms reside in colon
Adult females migrate to anus at night and deposit eggs in perianal folds
Eggs become infective within 4-6 hours of deposition
Some hatched larvae may return to rectum to mature
Lifespan of adult worms is 2 months

Classic Clinical Findings.text: Most infections are asymptomatic
Most common symptom is perianal itching at nighttime, resulting in restless sleep
Other symptoms include irritability and abdominal pain
Though infrequent, larvae can migrate into nearby tissues (e.g., vagina, uterus, pelvis), causing granulomas

Treatment.text: Treatment is with anthelmintic medicationsAlbendazoleMebendazolePyrantel pamoateIvermectin
sub_points: Albendazole
Mebendazole
Pyrantel pamoate
Ivermectin

Treatment.text: 2 treatments given 2 weeks apart are used to eliminate infectionReinfection is common, particularly if source has not been addressed
sub_points: Reinfection is common, particularly if source has not been addressed

Prevention.text: Practicing proper hygiene is primary method to prevent infection

Microscopy.text: Diagnosis is made through microscopic visualization of helminth eggs &/or adult wormsE.vermiculariseggs are smooth, elongated, and ovoid, with characteristic flattening on 1 sideFemale worms measure 8-13 mm; male worms measure 2-5 mmEggs measure 50-60 uM by 20-30 uM
sub_points: E.vermiculariseggs are smooth, elongated, and ovoid, with characteristic flattening on 1 side
Female worms measure 8-13 mm; male worms measure 2-5 mm
Eggs measure 50-60 uM by 20-30 uM

Microscopy.text: Because adult female worms migrate to perianal region of host to lay eggs, pinworm paddles or scotch tape preps are preferred method for collecting eggs and adult worms
Eggs are not typically seen in stool; therefore, stool is not specimen of choice

Clinical Correlates.text: Paragonimus westermani: Lung trematode found primarily in southeast Asia and Japan
Transmission via ingestion of raw or undercooked crab or crayfish infected withP. westermanimetacercariae
Pulmonary infection is primary manifestation; however, extrapulmonary infection can result in severe disease and outcomes
Praziquantel is treatment of choice

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Examination of stool and sputum for eggs is standard for diagnosis
Eggs are ovoid and asymmetrical with opercular shoulders and thickened abopercular end
Serologic testing may help determine cause of infection when eggs are not observed on stool or sputum examination

Epidemiology.text: Paragonimusincludes 10 species that infect humansP. westermani(oriental lung fluke) is most common
sub_points: P. westermani(oriental lung fluke) is most common

Epidemiology.text: Distributed mainly in southeast Asia and Japan; other species can be found in parts of Asia, the Americas, and Africa
Reservoir hosts include dogs, cats, and other crab- or crayfish-eating animals

Transmission.text: Infection transmitted primarily through ingestion of raw or undercooked freshwater crab and crayfish

Life Cycle.text: P. westermanimetacercariae are ingested by consumption of infected raw or undercooked crab or crayfish

Excystation occurs in duodenum, followed by migration through intestinal wall and diaphragm to lungs where metacercariae encapsulate and mature into adultsAdult worms may also travel to striated muscle or brain, but life cycle will terminate because eggs cannot leave these sites
sub_points: Adult worms may also travel to striated muscle or brain, but life cycle will terminate because eggs cannot leave these sites

Life Cycle.text: Oviposition occurs 65-90 days after infection, and eggs leave lung via bronchioles
Eggs are either excreted in sputum or swallowed by human host and excreted in feces
Eggs become embryonated in the environment and release miracidia
Miracidia enter freshwater snail (intermediate host) and develop into cercariae
Cercariae are released from snail and enter crab or crayfish (2nd intermediate host) and develop into metacercariae (infective human stage)

Adult worms are ovoid and reddish-brown, measuring 7.5-12 mm by 4-6 mm
Eggs and adult worms may be visible in biopsy specimens

Serology.text: Can take 2-3 months for eggs to be deposited; thus, serologic testing forP. westermaniantibodies can be useful
Reference laboratories (including CDC) perform an IgG enzyme immunoassay (EIA) and immunoblot
Antibody levels decrease slowly over time with chemotherapeutic treatment
Cross-reactivity may occur with other trematode species

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Parasitic trematode worms (flukes) ofSchistosomagenus
3 major species causing human infections:S. mansoni,S. haematobium,S. japonicum
Host tissue reaction against egg antigens induces Th-2-predominant immune response

Clinical Issues.text: Worldwide distribution; prevalence is highest in sub-Saharan Africa
Mortality related to schistosomiasis is low
Likelihood of complications and morbidity correlate with parasite burden, duration of infection, site(s) of infection
Migratory infection or immediate manifestations occur
Acute infection (Katayama fever) is symptomatic
Chronic infection: Intestine, liver, spleen, urinary tract, genital systems, lungs, CNS

Microscopic.text: Inflammatory granulomatous reaction and eosinophilic infiltration resulting in local tissue destruction and fibrosis
S. mansoni(140 x 66 µm): Oval egg, lateral spine
S. haematobium(143 x 60 µm): Oval egg, terminal spine
S. japonicum(90 x 70 µm): Round egg, small lateral spine
Adults worms rarely seen; in transverse sections, larger males surround more slender females

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Strongyloidiasis: Located in intestinal crypts and mucosa, more exuberant eosinophilic infiltration
Tuberculosis: Positive for acid-fast stain, lacks ova and eosinophilic inflammation
Coccidioidomycosis: Lacks ova and shows spherules with endospores
Neoplasms, sarcoidosis: Lacks ova or significant eosinophilic inflammation

Definitions.text: Greek: "Skhistos" (divided, cloven) + "soma" (body)

Infectious Agents.text: Life cycleSchistosomaeggs, seeded into fresh water through urine or feces from infected humans or animals, release miracidia, which penetrate into snails (specific snail species determines geographic distribution) and produce cercariae (infectious larvae form), which are released into waterCercariae penetrate human skin, become schistosomulae, and migrate through circulation until they reach liver, where they mature into adult worms and reside in bowel/rectum venules (S. mansoniandS. japonicum) or venous plexus in bladder (S. haematobium)Eggs are deposited in tissue and move toward lumen of intestine or bladder and ureters and are then eliminated in feces or urine, respectively, but may embolize to liver, spleen, lungs, brain, or spinal cord, and, less commonly, skin and peritoneal surfaces
sub_points: Schistosomaeggs, seeded into fresh water through urine or feces from infected humans or animals, release miracidia, which penetrate into snails (specific snail species determines geographic distribution) and produce cercariae (infectious larvae form), which are released into water

Cercariae penetrate human skin, become schistosomulae, and migrate through circulation until they reach liver, where they mature into adult worms and reside in bowel/rectum venules (S. mansoniandS. japonicum) or venous plexus in bladder (S. haematobium)

Eggs are deposited in tissue and move toward lumen of intestine or bladder and ureters and are then eliminated in feces or urine, respectively, but may embolize to liver, spleen, lungs, brain, or spinal cord, and, less commonly, skin and peritoneal surfaces

General Features.text: Schistosoma adults typically found in copula
Specific morphologic features vary with species
Males are robust, 6-20 mm long, with ventral folding to form gynecophoral canal, grossly tuberculate tegument (most species), 2 small anterior suckers, and 4-9 testes posterior to ventral suckers
Female are slender, 7-26 mm long, lack tegument tuberculation, and have single ovary near ventral sucker; uterus contains variable number of eggs

Strongyloidiasis.text: Strongyloidesworms and larvae are seen in intestinal crypts and mucosa, often associated with exuberant eosinophilic infiltration

In intestinal infection, egg-layingSchistosomaworms are present in microvasculature, while ova are mainly in submucosa, associated with granulomatous reaction with less intense eosinophilic infiltrate

Coccidioidomycosis.text: Lacks ova and shows spherules with endospores

Tuberculosis.text: Positive for acid-fast stain and lacks ova and eosinophilic inflammation

Sarcoidosis.text: Lacks presence of ova and eosinophilic inflammation

Neoplasms.text: Lack ova and exhibit histologic morphologies consistent with malignant or benign neoplasms

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infectious disease caused byStrongyloides stercoralis, intestinal nematode that infects humans through contact with soil that contains larvae

Clinical Issues.text: Common in tropics, subtropics, and warm regions; affects ~ 30-100 million people worldwide
Presence of rhabditiform larvae in stool examination is diagnostic (gold standard)
Frequently asymptomatic; however, hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis occur in immunosuppressed patients

Endoscopy.text: Worms are not visualized during endoscopy due to small size of adults and localization within cells of small intestinal crypts but may produce discrete lesions (red, raised lesions), which are biopsied for diagnosis

Cytopathology.text: Larvae can be seen by simple wet mount in fluid from bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) or in other body fluids during hyperinfection

Microscopic.text: Duodenal or jejunal biopsy may show no inflammatory reaction, eosinophilic microabscess, mixed cellular infiltrate of acute and chronic inflammation, or granulomatous inflammation to dead worms
Adult females, eggs, rhabditiform larvae, and filarial larvae may be seen in small intestine

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Schistosomiasis (Katayama fever), amebiasis, balantidiasis, or infections byAncylostoma duodenaleorNecator americanus
Ulcerative colitis and polyarteritis nodosa

Definitions.text: From Greek terms, "strongylos" (round) + "eidos" (form)

Infectious Agents.text: Infectious disease caused predominantly byStrongyloides stercoralis, intestinal nematode that infects humans through contact with soil that contains larvae
ZoonoticStrongyloidesfuellebornisubspeciesfuelleborniandS. fuellebornisubspecieskellyiare rare causes of human infection

Filariform larvae directly penetrate skin, migrate via bloodstream/lungs and other routes to small intestine, where they mature and reside as adult females, which produce eggs via parthenogenesis, which hatch rhabditiform larvae
Rhabditiform larvae can mature into filariform larvae in humans causing autoinfection

Epidemiology.text: Common in tropics, subtropics, and warm regions; affects 30-100 million people worldwide

Presentation.text: Frequently asymptomatic
Acute infection shows cutaneous reaction "ground itch" as larvae penetrate skin, most commonly in foot

Chronic infection larvae can migrate intradermally, which results in intense itchy red tracts, usually in perianal areaLarvae migration can cause respiratory symptomsLoeffler syndrome: Fever, dyspnea, wheeze, pulmonary infiltrates with blood eosinophilia may be seen (rare)Migration of larvae to gastrointestinal system can cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and anorexiaUp to 75% of people with chronic form have mild peripheral eosinophilia or elevated IgE levelsUpper thighs with larva migration (larvae currens) are pathognomic for strongyloidiasis
sub_points: Larvae migration can cause respiratory symptoms
Loeffler syndrome: Fever, dyspnea, wheeze, pulmonary infiltrates with blood eosinophilia may be seen (rare)
Migration of larvae to gastrointestinal system can cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and anorexia
Up to 75% of people with chronic form have mild peripheral eosinophilia or elevated IgE levels
Upper thighs with larva migration (larvae currens) are pathognomic for strongyloidiasis

Presentation.text: Hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis occur in immunosuppressed patientsInfection with human T-cell leukemia/lymphoma virus type I (HTLV-I) is also major risk factor forStrongyloideshyperinfection syndrome, along with organ transplant and prolonged steroid therapySerologic testing prior to start of steroid therapy is strongly suggested for any patient with remote risk
sub_points: Infection with human T-cell leukemia/lymphoma virus type I (HTLV-I) is also major risk factor forStrongyloideshyperinfection syndrome, along with organ transplant and prolonged steroid therapy

Presentation.text: Strongyloidiasis and COVID-19Chronic strongyloidiasis and COVID-19 could become commonplace, especially in endemic low- and middle-income countriesClinicians should evaluate underlying chronic strongyloidiasis infection independent of signs and symptoms, epidemiology, and other behavioral risk factors prior to corticosteroid initiationPrompt investigation with stool microscopy, respiratory samples examination, or culture should be undertaken ifStrongyloideshyperinfection is suspected
sub_points: Chronic strongyloidiasis and COVID-19 could become commonplace, especially in endemic low- and middle-income countries
Clinicians should evaluate underlying chronic strongyloidiasis infection independent of signs and symptoms, epidemiology, and other behavioral risk factors prior to corticosteroid initiation
Prompt investigation with stool microscopy, respiratory samples examination, or culture should be undertaken ifStrongyloideshyperinfection is suspected

Laboratory Tests.text: Gold standard for diagnosis: Serial stool examination; presence of rhabditiform larvae is diagnostic
Stool concentration techniques, such as Baermann technique and modified agar plate method, can be used to improve sensitivity
Duodenal aspirates for identification of organisms
Serologic testing for antibodiesFor patients with potential exposure who are being placed on immunosuppression, serology should be used to determine pretreatment requirements
sub_points: For patients with potential exposure who are being placed on immunosuppression, serology should be used to determine pretreatment requirements

Laboratory Tests.text: Diagnostic sensitivity of qPCR is similar to conventional parasitology methods

Treatment.text: Ivermectin or albendazole
Moxidectin is veterinary antiparasitic drug that has FDA approval for treatment of human onchocerciasis and is in line for clinical trials in strongyloidiasis
Apart from antiparasitic treatment, key management of complicated strongyloidiasis is restoring host immunity

Prognosis.text: Acute symptomatic disease resolves with treatment
Chronic disease with dissemination and immunosuppression (hyperinfection) has 80% mortality

Parasite Characteristics.text: Parasitic adult female worms are 2-3 mm long x 30-40 μm in diameter; free-living females 1 mm longLong cylindrical esophagus in anterior 1/3 of body cavityIntestine and reproductive organs posterior 2/3
sub_points: Long cylindrical esophagus in anterior 1/3 of body cavity
Intestine and reproductive organs posterior 2/3

Parasite Characteristics.text: Parasitic adult male worms do not exist; free-living male worms measure up to 0.75 mm long
Eggs are 50-60 μm x 30-40 μmS. stercoraliseggs hatch in epithelium and absent in stoolS. fuellebornieggs routinely shed in stool
sub_points: S. stercoraliseggs hatch in epithelium and absent in stool
S. fuellebornieggs routinely shed in stool

Parasite Characteristics.text: Rhabditiform larvae (L1) are 180-400 μm long x 15-20 μm in diameter and have short buccal canal, rhabditoid esophagus extending 1/3 of body length, and prominent genital primordium
Filariform larvae (L3) are 500-600 μm long x 15-20 μm in diameter and have esophagus:intestine ratio of 1:1 and notched tail

Endoscopic Features.text: Because of small size of adults and larvae, as well as localization within cells of small intestinal crypts, worms are not visualized during endoscopy but may produce discrete lesions (red, raised lesions), which are biopsied for diagnosis

Histologic Features.text: Duodenal or jejunal biopsy may show no inflammatory reaction, eosinophilic microabscess, mixed cellular infiltrate of acute and chronic inflammation, or granulomatous inflammation to dead worms
Hyperinfection: Larvae may be found in many tissues and fluids, including sputum, bronchial washings, cerebrospinal fluid, skin, and urine

Adult females (30-40 μm in diameter) are present within small intestine submucosa; transverse sections show esophagus (anterior) or collapsed intestine with ovary or uterus often containing eggs (posterior)

Oval embryonated eggs (60 μm in length) with thin shells are present in epithelium adjacent to adult females and rapidly hatch rhabditoid larvae (20 μm in diameter), which typically show intestine in transverse sections
Filariform larvae (20 μm in diameter) show esophagus or intestine in transverse sections and double lateral alae (not always observed)

Cytologic Features.text: Larvae can be seen by simple wet mount in fluid from bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) or in other body fluids during hyperinfection

Other Parasitic Conditions.text: Schistosomiasis (Katayama fever), amebiasis, balantidiasis, or infections byAncylostoma duodenaleorNecator americanus
Trichinella spiralislarvae are more minute and primitive in structure; generally not seen in intestinal mucosa
Capillaria philippinensiscontains stichosome; eggs in uterus and adjacent tissue has distinctive morphologic features, including plugs
Negative biopsy &/or serology/stool exam can differentiate strongyloidiasis from other parasitic infections

Ulcerative Colitis.text: MimicsStrongyloidescolitis, but obtaining travel and residence history is important
Biopsy shows absence of larva or eggs with low eosinophilic infiltrates

Polyarteritis Nodosa.text: Involvement of capillaries and venules in addition to arteriolar involvement seen in polyarteritis nodosa is major point of distinction

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Soil transmitted nematode infection in setting of poor hygiene or lack of clean water
Ingested eggs mature to adult worms and reside in colon

Clinical Issues.text: Global prevalence of 17% with 800 million infections
Worms are large and easily seen on endoscopy (single or multiple) but may mimic polyps (local inflammation)
Heavy infestation in rectum leads to rectal prolapse
Albendazole and mebendazole are 1st-line therapy

Microbiology.text: Eggs are barrel-shaped (50-55 x 20-25 μm), thick shelled, and possess pair of polar "plugs" at each end; unembryonated when passed in stool

Macroscopic.text: Worms visible (1.0-2.0 x 0.3-cm) adherent to mucosa ± colonic hyperemia and hyperplasia

Microscopic.text: Colonic mucosa may show active colitis or hyperplasia of goblet cells (polyp-like hyperplasia)
Narrow anterior head of worm contains stichosome and may be found between intestinal epithelial cells
Posterior end of worm in lumen contains uterus with characteristic eggs (in females)
Presence of spicule indicates specimen is male

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Hookworm infection: Attached directly to mucosa via cutting plates without burrowing, minimal inflammatory response
Strongyloidiasis: Very small (not grossly visible) with raised red patches; microscopically shows collections of eosinophils with adult and larval forms within mucosal wall
Capillariasis: Small nematode (< 5 mm) that produces eggs similar toTrichuriseggs and causes life-threatening, dysentery-like syndrome

Definitions.text: Greek: "Tricho" (hair) + "oura" (tail)

Infectious Agents.text: Soil transmitted nematode infection withTrichuris trichiuravia ingestion of eggs in setting of poor hygiene or lack of clean water
Unembryonated eggs are excreted by host in stool where they mature to infective forms over 3-week period; ingested eggs hatch in small intestine, and worms mature and reside in colon
Females lay up to 20,000 eggs per day (~ 65 days after infection), and adult worms survive in colon for 1 year
Heavy infestation in rectum leads to rectal prolapse

Trichurisspp. As Therapeutic Agents.text: Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis have responded with remission to iatrogenic infection withT. trichiura;parasite promotes (via Th2 cytokines and IL-22) goblet cell hyperplasia and mucus production
Trichuris suisinfection (zoonosis): Immunomodulatory therapy for multiple sclerosis, inflammatory bowel disease, seasonal allergic rhinitis, specific allergens

Epidemiology.text: Global prevalence: 17% with 800 million infections at any given time
Specific community prevalence can be 30-40% and as high as 80% in subgroups (school-aged children)

Presentation.text: Vast majority of patients are asymptomatic
Symptomatic presentations include mild abdominal pain, rectal prolapse (young children), and dysentery-like syndrome with mucoid diarrhea, rectal prolapse, and anemia

Endoscopic Findings.text: Adult worms are large and easily seen on endoscopy (single or multiple) but may mimic polyps (local inflammation)

Laboratory Tests.text: Stool examination for ova and parasites reveals eggs
In pregnant women and some other populations, anemia is related to intensity of egg burden

Treatment.text: Albendazole and mebendazole are 1st-line therapy

Prognosis.text: Chronic infection in childhood can lead to growth stunting and mental delays

Parasite Features.text: Adult males are 30-45 mm long with coiled posterior end, and females are 35-50 mm with straight posterior end; both have long, whip-like anterior end; reside in large intestine, cecum, and appendix
Eggs are barrel-shaped (50-55 x 20-25 μm), thick shelled, and possess pair of polar "plugs" at each end; unembryonated when passed in stool

Culture.text: No role in diagnosis of whipworm

Colonic Resection.text: Either as rare indication or, more likely, when found incidentally, worms are visible as 1.0-2.0 x 0.3 cm white worms adherent to mucosa ± colonic hyperemia and hyperplasia

Histologic Features.text: Sections from anterior end of adult worm shows stichosome with centrally located nucleus and subcuticle basal band; may be seen burrowed between intestinal epithelial cells

Posterior sections of adult worms show thick cuticle with annulations, thin hypodermis, and layers of polymyarian muscle cells; presence of spicule indicates specimen is male; females are identified by egg-filled uterus
Colonic mucosa may be benign or show active colitis or hyperplasia of goblet cells (polyp-like hyperplasia)

Hookworm Infection.text: Attached directly to mucosa via cutting plates without burrowing, and they produce little (if any) inflammatory response

Strongyloidiasis.text: Adults are very small (not grossly visible); produce raised red patches that microscopically show collections of eosinophils with adult and larval forms within mucosal wall (between intestinal epithelial cells)

Capillariasis.text: Small nematode (< 5 mm) that produces eggs similar toTrichuriseggs and causes life-threatening, dysentery-like syndrome

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infection withEchinococcusspecies cestodes (tapeworms) incidentally found in humans through contact with infected animals

Clinical Issues.text: Cystic echinococcosis: Abdominal pain, pleurisy, shortness of breath, bone pain, "tumor," headaches, or seizures
Alveolar echinococcosis: Asymptomatic slow-growing, fibrotic mass with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, or hepatic failure
Polycystic echinococcosis (rare): Asymptomatic slow-growing, fibrotic mass (liver > pleura > mesentery)

Imaging.text: Radiograph: Chest or abdomen with solitary or multiple fluid-filled spaces in involved organs
CT: Daughter cysts within larger cysts or reactive surrounding inflammation

Microscopic.text: Cystic echinococcosis and polycystic echinococcosis: Thin to thick, fibrous response from human host, germinal matrix, and daughter cysts that contain protoscolices
Rupture echinococcal disease: Fibrous response with varying amounts of identifiable necrotic helminth fragments
Alveolar echinococcosis: Fibrous response with varying amounts of identifiable daughter cysts
Fine-needle aspiration of solitary cysts should yield diagnostic hydatid sand/protoscolices

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Cysticercosis:Taenia soliumlarvae are small (1-2 cm) and contain single protoscolex with hooklets
Coenurosis: Coenurus, or larval bladder, contains multiple protoscolices with hooklets within single lesion
Noninfectious cystic/polycystic lesions

Epidemiology.text: Prevalence of neurocysticercosis is decreasing in developing countries due to improved sanitation and widespread use of antihelminthic drugs
Patients < 30 years of age are more likely to present with single, enhancing nodules of neurocysticercosis, whereas older patients are more likely to present with subarachnoid neurocysticercosis

Classic Clinical Findings.text: Patients withTaeniainfection may pass proglottids in stools
Subcutaneous and visceral cysts may cause local mass and may occasionally cause pain
Ophthalmic cysticercosis may cause deviation in gaze, block visual fields, and affect visual acuity

Neurocysticercosis results from entrance of cysticerci into central nervous system and is major cause of neurological disease in many developing countriesDisease severity and clinical manifestations are determined by location of parasites in brain parenchyma or in extraparenchymal spaces, as well as number and size of parasites, and subsequent immune responseEpilepsy is most common reported symptom (up to 80% of symptomatic patients)Other symptomsHeadaches (~ 27% of cases)Focal neurological signsMeningeal signsGait abnormalitiesAltered mental stateEarly-onset dementiaPsychiatric symptomsExtraparenchymal neurocysticercosis results from parasites within ventricular or subarachnoid space and may cause acute intracranial hypertension or hydrocephalusMortality rates from extraparenchymal neurocysticercosis can reach up to 20% without treatmentCysticercal encephalitis is induction of diffuse brain edema due to host immune response
sub_points: Disease severity and clinical manifestations are determined by location of parasites in brain parenchyma or in extraparenchymal spaces, as well as number and size of parasites, and subsequent immune response
Epilepsy is most common reported symptom (up to 80% of symptomatic patients)
Other symptomsHeadaches (~ 27% of cases)Focal neurological signsMeningeal signsGait abnormalitiesAltered mental stateEarly-onset dementiaPsychiatric symptoms

Focal neurological signs

Patients may have increased serum IgE level

Microscopy.text: Taeniainfection can be diagnosed via wet mount examination of stool samples for tapeworm eggsEggs are round or slightly oval (31-43 µm in diameter) and yellow-brown, with thick striated shell containing 6-hooked oncosphereT. soliumandTaenia saginatacannot be differentiated on basis of egg morphologyStool specimens should be collected on 3 different daysMicroscopic examination of stool for eggs has low sensitivity
sub_points: Eggs are round or slightly oval (31-43 µm in diameter) and yellow-brown, with thick striated shell containing 6-hooked oncosphere
T. soliumandTaenia saginatacannot be differentiated on basis of egg morphology
Stool specimens should be collected on 3 different days
Microscopic examination of stool for eggs has low sensitivity

Microscopy.text: Examination of gravid proglottids or scolices can allow for speciation betweenT. soliumandT. saginataT. soliumcontains 7-13 lateral uterine branches along proglottid
sub_points: T. soliumcontains 7-13 lateral uterine branches along proglottid

Microscopy.text: Microscopic techniques require specialist knowledge and skills

Molecular and Cytogenetic Tests.text: PCR can be used to distinguishT. soliumfrom otherTaeniaspecies
Combination of both microscopy and PCR improves diagnostic sensitivity (up to 77% positive detection rate)

Coproantigen Detection Assays.text: Coproantigen detection assays test for parasitic products released in feces ofTaeniacarriers using antibodies against excreted or somatic parasitic antigensSensitivity is greater than microscopyCoproantigen testing uses antisera raised againstT. soliumadult excretory-secretory antigensUse of polyclonal antisera can result in different spectrum of antigen specificities
sub_points: Sensitivity is greater than microscopy
Coproantigen testing uses antisera raised againstT. soliumadult excretory-secretory antigens
Use of polyclonal antisera can result in different spectrum of antigen specificities

Coproantigen Detection Assays.text: Circulating antigens are only present in serum of patients with viable parasites and will rapidly decrease after treatment
Sensitivity is lower for patients with parenchymal neurocysticercosis

Serology.text: Enzyme-linked immunoelectrotransfer blot (EITB) assay uses lentil lectin purified glycoprotein antigens to detect antibodies toT. soliumin serumEITB assay has 98% sensitivity for patients with 2 or more live parasites in nervous systemSensitivity is lower in patients with calcified cysticerci and is less sensitive when performed on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) than on serum samplesPositive serologies can also indicate exposure, past asymptomatic infection, or muscular/subcutaneous cysticercosis
sub_points: EITB assay has 98% sensitivity for patients with 2 or more live parasites in nervous system
Sensitivity is lower in patients with calcified cysticerci and is less sensitive when performed on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) than on serum samples
Positive serologies can also indicate exposure, past asymptomatic infection, or muscular/subcutaneous cysticercosis

Serology.text: ELISA has higher sensitivity (89%) and specificity (93%) in CSF than EITBDecreased sensitivity in patients with calcified cysticerciMay be cross-reactive in patients with other helminthic infectionsSerial serum ELISA assays can be used to assess response to treatment of subarachnoid neurocysticercosis
sub_points: Decreased sensitivity in patients with calcified cysticerci
May be cross-reactive in patients with other helminthic infections
Serial serum ELISA assays can be used to assess response to treatment of subarachnoid neurocysticercosis

CSF analysis.text: CSF analysis may demonstrate mononuclear pleocytosis and mild increase in CSF protein concentrations
Low CSF concentrations of glucose have been associated with poor prognosis
CSF can be used to distinguish cysticercosis from other forms of intracranial infections, although CSF in patients with intraparenchymal neurocysticercosis may be unremarkable

Clinical Correlates.text: Wuchereria bancrofti: Filarial nematode with humans as definitive host and reservoirHas symbiotic relationship with obligate intracellular bacteriaWolbachia, which is required for larval development
sub_points: Has symbiotic relationship with obligate intracellular bacteriaWolbachia, which is required for larval development

Clinical Correlates.text: Lymphatic filariasis is characterized by thickening of skin and underlying tissues of extremities, genitalia, and breasts due to presence of adult worms in lymphatic system

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Thick films: Prepared by dropping blood into small area and allowing to dry at room temperature, leading to higher concentration of blood and therefore increasing chance of detecting parasites
Immunochromatography card test (ICT): Semi-quantitative assay that detects circulating parasite antigen using monoclonal antibodies to antigens released by adult filarial worms

Pathophysiology.text: W. bancrofti: Filarial nematode with humans as definitive host and reservoirFilarial nematode: Arthropod-transmitted roundworm that infects subcutaneous tissues, deep connective tissues, body cavities, and lymphatic systemVectors includeCulex,Aedes, andAnophelesmosquitoesLarvae reside in insect vector and are injected into bloodstream during arthropod feedingLarvae then migrate to lymphatic vessels, mature into gravid worm in human host, and produce microfilariae larvae
sub_points: Filarial nematode: Arthropod-transmitted roundworm that infects subcutaneous tissues, deep connective tissues, body cavities, and lymphatic system
Vectors includeCulex,Aedes, andAnophelesmosquitoes
Larvae reside in insect vector and are injected into bloodstream during arthropod feeding
Larvae then migrate to lymphatic vessels, mature into gravid worm in human host, and produce microfilariae larvae

Pathophysiology.text: Adult male and female worms are long and slender, measuring up to 100 mm in lengthCan reside in host for many years
sub_points: Can reside in host for many years

Pathophysiology.text: Parasite has 2 forms with different periodicities when found in peripheral bloodNocturnal periodic form: Found between 10 PM and 4 AMPacific Island form: Found at all times
sub_points: Nocturnal periodic form: Found between 10 PM and 4 AM
Pacific Island form: Found at all times

Pathophysiology.text: W. bancroftihas symbiotic relationship with obligate intracellular bacteriaWolbachia, which is required for larval developmentWolbachiahas also been implicated in pathogenicity of host lymphatic damage
sub_points: Wolbachiahas also been implicated in pathogenicity of host lymphatic damage

Epidemiology.text: Widely distributed in at least 76 countries (tropical and subtropical) including Africa, South America, Asia, Pacific Islands, and Caribbean
Infects 120 million people worldwide (~ 2% of world's population), with 44 million who are symptomatic
Risk factors include regions with overburdened sewage/waste-water systems or irrigation projectsLead to pools of stagnant water, creating vector breeding grounds
sub_points: Lead to pools of stagnant water, creating vector breeding grounds

Classic Clinical Findings.text: Lymphatic filariasis is characterized by thickening of skin and underlying tissues of extremities, genitalia, and breasts due to presence of adult worms in lymphatic systemAcute filarial lymphangitis results from destruction of worms in lymph vessels or lymph nodes, causing small, tender nodulesLymphangitis can progress to lymphedema and obstructive fibrosisAcute adenolymphangitis results from immune-mediated response to dying adult wormsPresents as episodic fevers, lymphadenitis in groin and axillae, and localized swelling and painHydrocele formation within scrotum may result due to blockage of retroperitoneal or subdiaphragmatic lymphatic vesselsElephantiasis: Severe swelling and skin-thickening of lower extremities and genitalia resulting from severe recurrent lymphatic disease
sub_points: Acute filarial lymphangitis results from destruction of worms in lymph vessels or lymph nodes, causing small, tender nodules
Lymphangitis can progress to lymphedema and obstructive fibrosis
Acute adenolymphangitis results from immune-mediated response to dying adult wormsPresents as episodic fevers, lymphadenitis in groin and axillae, and localized swelling and pain
Presents as episodic fevers, lymphadenitis in groin and axillae, and localized swelling and pain
Hydrocele formation within scrotum may result due to blockage of retroperitoneal or subdiaphragmatic lymphatic vessels
Elephantiasis: Severe swelling and skin-thickening of lower extremities and genitalia resulting from severe recurrent lymphatic disease

Classic Clinical Findings.text: Lymphatic filariasis is caused by 3 species of tissue-dwelling filaroid nematodesW. bancroftiis responsible for 90% of cases
sub_points: W. bancroftiis responsible for 90% of cases

Antigen Testing.text: Immunochromatography card test (ICT): Semiquantitative assay that detects circulating parasite antigen using monoclonal antibodies to antigens released by adult filarial wormsMore convenient/mobile in endemic regions than molecular techniques, which usually require reference laboratoryPresence of circulating antigen may be indicator of active infection

Molecular and Cytogenetic Tests.text: PCR assays allow rapid diagnosis ofW. bancroftiwith high sensitivity
Multiplex PCR has been developed to distinguishW. bancroftiandBrugia malayi

Serology.text: Serologic assays for antibodies against BmR1 or Wb123 are useful for population monitoring
Serology is less useful for diagnostic purposes due to high level of cross-reactivity with other parasitic worms, and inability to discriminate between past and current infections

Clinical Correlates.text: Diphyllobothrium latum: Largest human cestode; can measure up to 30 feet long with as many as 4,000 segmentsOnly cestode with aquatic life cycle, using several intermediate hosts (including copepods, freshwater crustaceans, and freshwater fish) and humans as definitive host
sub_points: Only cestode with aquatic life cycle, using several intermediate hosts (including copepods, freshwater crustaceans, and freshwater fish) and humans as definitive host

Microbiology.text: Cestodes (tapeworms): Helminths that live in intestinal tract of vertebrates as adults and have various intermediate hosts as larvae

Pathophysiology.text: D. latum: Only cestode with aquatic life cycle, using several intermediate hosts (including copepods, freshwater crustaceans, and freshwater fish), and humans as definitive hostFish-eating mammalian hosts (including humans) pass immature, operculated eggs in feces, which hatch into motile coracidium in waterCoracidium penetrates intestinal wall of copepod and develops into procercoid, which has posterior appendage with 6 embryonic hooksLarvae migrate into fish flesh and develop into sparganum, which is infective for humansHumans are usually infected by consuming raw or larger fish that have ingested 2nd intermediate hostsSparganum develops into adult tapeworm that attaches to intestinal mucosaAdult worms mature and initiate egg production in ~ 1 month

Diagnosis of tickborne illness requires knowledge of geographic area in which patient was exposed, identification of characteristic clinical features, report or identification of tick, &/or identification of pathogen &/or antibodies to pathogen from blood of infected patient

Overview of Ticks.text: Ticks are bloodsucking ectoparasites of most species, including humans

Ticks are separated into hard ticks (family Ixodidae) and soft ticks (family Argasidae)Hard ticks have hard dorsal plate (scutum) with mouthparts clearly visible from aboveSoft ticks have leathery body that lacks scutum and mouthparts that are not visible from aboveHard ticks feed over 7-9 daysSoft ticks feed over minutes to hoursMost human diseases that are tick-associated are carried by hard ticks
sub_points: Hard ticks have hard dorsal plate (scutum) with mouthparts clearly visible from above
Soft ticks have leathery body that lacks scutum and mouthparts that are not visible from above
Hard ticks feed over 7-9 days
Soft ticks feed over minutes to hours
Most human diseases that are tick-associated are carried by hard ticks

Prevention.text: Preventing tickborne illnesses requires avoiding tick bites

Tick bites can be avoidedAvoiding direct contact with ticksRepelling ticks with DEET or permethrinWashing within 2 hours of being outdoors in tick-infested areasPerforming full-body tick checksTumble drying clothes for 10 minutes after coming inside to kill ticks on clothes
sub_points: Avoiding direct contact with ticks

Treatment.text: Removal of ticks is 1st step in treatmentTo remove tick, grasp tick as close to skin as possible with pair of tweezersPull upward with steady, even pressure, and do not twist or jerkClean bite area with rubbing alcohol, iodine scrub, or soap and waterKill any live tick by drowning in rubbing alcohol, putting it in sealed container, wrapping it tightly in tape, or flushing it down toiletMouthparts often remain after tick is removed; it is unnecessary to remove these partsAntibiotic therapy may be necessary to treat secondary infections of tick bite site
sub_points: To remove tick, grasp tick as close to skin as possible with pair of tweezers
Pull upward with steady, even pressure, and do not twist or jerk
Clean bite area with rubbing alcohol, iodine scrub, or soap and water
Kill any live tick by drowning in rubbing alcohol, putting it in sealed container, wrapping it tightly in tape, or flushing it down toilet
Mouthparts often remain after tick is removed; it is unnecessary to remove these parts
Antibiotic therapy may be necessary to treat secondary infections of tick bite site

Treatment.text: Tick removal is crucial for treatment of tick bite paralysis; symptom resolution usually occurs within 48 hours of removing tick

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Acquired skin infestation ofSarcoptes scabieivar.hominismites via direct skin to skin contact or, less frequently, via fomites, such as bedding or clothing

Clinical Issues.text: 100 million affected worldwide (most common in children)
Intense pruritus with nocturnal worsening
Skin scrapings to detect mites, eggs, or mite fecal matter
Treatment with topical permethrin or oral ivermectin
With appropriate treatment, resolves with little scarring

Macroscopic.text: Mites are 0.5 mm in length and appear as white spots
Skin: Linear or curved burrows appear red and possibly excoriated

Microscopic.text: Identification of scabies mites, eggs, or feces (scybala) in subcorneum or superficial epidermis is pathognomonic
Classic scabiesOvoid mite containing chitinous exoskeleton, dorsal spines, and 4 pairs of legsSpongiotic epidermis with exocytosis of eosinophils
sub_points: Ovoid mite containing chitinous exoskeleton, dorsal spines, and 4 pairs of legs
Spongiotic epidermis with exocytosis of eosinophils

Microscopic.text: Nodular scabies: Identification of mites is less common
Norwegian/crusted scabies: Innumerable mites and keratotic scale

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Demodex: Mites associated with hair follicles; typically involves face
Arthropod bite: Rarely, insect mouthparts are identified in dermis; more prominent perivascular distribution with eosinophils
Eczematous dermatitis: Similar appearance but absence of scabies mites, eggs, or scybala
Cutaneous larva migrans: Nematode larval rarely identified; similar eosinophilic spongiotic and perivascular chronic dermatitis

Definitions.text: Latin: "Scabere" (to scratch)

Infectious Agents.text: Acquired skin infestation ofSarcoptes scabieivar.hominismites via direct skin to skin contact or, less frequently, via fomites, such as bedding or clothing
Primary infection induces clinical symptoms only 4-8 weeks after inoculation
Considered water-washed disease due to lack of proper sanitation and hygiene

Epidemiology.text: Incidence: 100 million affected worldwide (most common in children)

Laboratory Tests.text: Skin scrapings to detect mites, eggs, or mite fecal matter

Treatment.text: Drugs: Topical permethrin or oral ivermectin

Prognosis.text: With appropriate treatment, resolves with little scarring
Recurrence may occur from close contacts (requires treatment)
Crusted scabies requires prolonged course of therapy and may be difficult to eradicate without thorough environmental cleaning

General Features.text: Mites are 0.5 mm in length and appear as white spots
Skin: Linear or curved burrows appear red and possibly excoriated

Histologic Features.text: Epidermal intracorneal presence of female scabies mite, eggs, or feces (scybala) is pathognomonic
Ovoid mite containing chitinous exoskeleton, dorsal spines, and 4 pairs of legs

Demodex.text: Mites associated with hair follicles and typically involve face

Arthropod Bite.text: Rarely, insect mouthparts are identified in dermis
Dermatitis with eosinophils more prominent perivascular distribution at early stages
Older lesions may show diffuse or nodular inflammation

Eczematous Dermatitis.text: Exuberant dermatitis may be difficult to differentiate in absence of scabies mites, eggs, or scybala

Cutaneous Larva Migrans.text: Similar spongiotic and perivascular chronic dermatitis with numerous eosinophils
Rarely identified nematode larval forms 0.5 mm thick and up to 10 mm long in deep dermis

Clinical Correlates.text: Human pediculosis: Caused by head lice (Pediculus humanus capitus), body lice, (Pediculus humanus humanus),and pubic lice (Phthirus pubis)
Lice cause symptoms in human host by injecting saliva into body during ingestion of blood, which causes itching

Body lice can transmit at least 3 intracellular pathogenic bacteria:Rickettsia prowazekii(cause of epidemic typhus),Bartonella quintana(cause of trench fever), andBorrelia recurrentis(cause of relapsing fever)
Treatment of lice involves removal of lice from hair or clothes, treatment of skin with topical or oral therapy, and vigorous cleaning of clothing, bedding, and other possibly infected surfaces

Laboratory Diagnosis.text: Head and pubic lice: Visual inspection of hair &/or skin by dry/wet combing
Body lice: Examination of clothing for nits &/or lice

Pathophysiology.text: Human pediculosis: Caused by head lice (Pediculus humanus capitus), body lice, (Pediculus humanus humanus),and pubic lice (Phthirus pubis)

Pediculusspecies: Flat, elongated, and wingless insects with mouthpieces adapted for piercing flesh and sucking bloodPhthirus pubis: Short, wingless insects with crab-like 2nd and 3rd legs (origin of common name "crabs")

Epidemiology.text: All lice are spread by physical contact or contact with infected surfaces (e.g., hairbrushes, clothing, toilet seats)
Epidemics of head lice are common, especially among schoolchildren
Infestation most commonly occurs in crowded environments, especially when hygienic standards are lacking (as often occurs in homeless shelters, refugee camps, or jails)
Spread of head lice in population depends on average time host remains infected, number of susceptible individuals in host population, and type and frequency of hair-to-hair contact
Population-based studies of head lice prevalences are highly divergent, showing infection rates of 1-20% among different European populations
Seasonal variation in infection may occur due to spatiotemporal changes in human contact
Girls are more frequently infected by head lice than boys, possibly representing differences in culturally accepted behaviors between sexes

sub_points: Intense itching of scalp with pruritic red papules around ears, face, neck or shoulders and visible eggs (nits) or insects in hair

Treatment.text: Synchronized treatment of all infested individuals (or individuals suspected to be infested) should be undertaken to reduce likelihood of reinfection
Effective treatment requires washing of all clothing, bedding, and other surfaces that may harbor lice or nits (e.g., hairbrushes)
Evaluation for cure should be done after at least 14 days

Morphology.text: Pubic lice are shorter than head lice, with crab-like 2nd and 3rd legs

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Infestation of human or animal tissue by Diptera "2-winged true fly" larvae (maggots) that are attracted to preexisting suppurative lesions

Clinical Issues.text: Among 5 most common dermatologic conditions in travelers, representing 7.3-11.0% of cases
Cutaneous and wound myiasis are most common forms
Tissue invasion by maggots is generally well-recognized complication of neglected wounds
Cavitary myiasis corresponds to infection of body cavities
Orbital myiasis, or ophthalmomyiasis profunda, is infection of any anatomic structure of eye

Macroscopic.text: Larvae ~ 15 mm long; subclassification relies on examination anterior and posterior spiracles, mouthparts and cephalopharyngeal skeleton, and cuticular spines

Microscopic.text: Ulcerated epidermis ± hyperkeratosis; dermis contains mixed acute and chronic inflammatory infiltrate
Dipteran larva is seen in cross section but may not be possible to subclassify
Cuticular spines, spiracles, striated muscle, and other internal organs may be identified

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Cellulitis, furunculosis, ruptured epidermoid cyst: Absence of larvae parts in tissue can rule out myiasis
Leishmaniasis: Amastigotes (1-5 μm) with prominent kinetoplast within macrophages
Onchocerciasis: Microfilariae (300-315 µm long), lack striated muscle, cuticular spines
Tungiasis: Flea that resides at dermal-epidermal junction; contains numerous eosinophilic eggs

Definitions.text: Greek: "Myia" (fly)

Infectious Agents.text: Infestation of human or animal tissue by Diptera "2-winged true fly" larvae (maggots) that are attracted to preexisting suppurative lesions
Some species lay eggs on surface of blood-sucking vector (e.g., mosquitoes), which then enter host after blood meal
Dermatobia hominis, bot fly, American warble fly (torsalo): Southeastern Mexico to northern Argentina, Chile, Uruguay
Chrysomyaspecies, screwworm, Old World screwworm: Asia, Africa, India, Papua New Guinea
Cochliomyia hominivorax, blowflies, New World screwworm fly: Central and South America
Cordylobiaanthropophaga, tumbu fly, mango fly, putzi fly: East and Central Africa
Sarcophagidae (e.g.,Wohlfahrtiaspecies), flesh flies: Worldwide; cause myiasis in sheep but also carry leprosy and cause intestinal pseudomyiasis if ingested by humans
Species of maggots that feed only on dead tissue do not typically cause myiasis (e.g., common house fly)

Epidemiology.text: Risk factors include poor hygiene and low socioeconomic status and travel to endemic regions without proper precautions
Myiasis is among 5 most common dermatologic conditions in travelers, representing 7.3-11.0% of cases
Leprosy is endemic in countries where myiasis-causing flies are highly prevalent
Head and neck cancer patients represent risk group for development of myiasis in neoplastic wounds

Presentation.text: Migratory myiasis occurs when dipteran maggot burrows in skin, producing migratory creeping patternLarvae ofGasterophilus(horse botfly) andHypoderma(cattle botfly) cause this pattern in humans
sub_points: Larvae ofGasterophilus(horse botfly) andHypoderma(cattle botfly) cause this pattern in humans

Presentation.text: Wound myiasis occurs when fly larvae infest open woundsC. hominivorax,Chrysomya bezziana, andW. magnificaare most common flies for wound myiasis
sub_points: C. hominivorax,Chrysomya bezziana, andW. magnificaare most common flies for wound myiasis

Presentation.text: Cavitary myiasis corresponds to infection of body cavities
Orbital myiasis, or ophthalmomyiasis profunda, is infection of any anatomic structure of eye
Other uncommon forms include ENT myiasis, urogenital myiasis, intestinal myiasis, cerebral myiasis, tracheopulmonary myiasis, and umbilical cord myiasis
Recent report of extranodal NK-/T-cell lymphoma case presented as extensive myiasis

Treatment.text: Surgical removal/debridement required for wound myiasis but not for simple cutaneous myiasis (requested by patient)
Occlusion/oxygen depletions: Nonrestrictive cover (oil, animal fat, meat, petroleum jelly) forces larvae to migrate for oxygen supply after few hours; reduces scarring from surgical removal
Alternative therapy (especially for oral or orbital) includes oral or topical ivermectin

Prognosis.text: Self-limited disease in simple form (5-7 weeks)
Wound with debridement and management of secondary infections is excellent

General Features.text: Larvae are ~ 15 mm long, and identification to genus or species level relies on examination of features, including anterior and posterior spiracles, mouthparts and cephalopharyngeal skeleton, and cuticular spines

Histologic Features.text: Ulcerated epidermis ± hyperkeratosis; dermis contains mixed acute and chronic inflammatory infiltrate
Dipteran larva is seen in cross section but may not be possible to subclassify
Cuticular spines, spiracles, striated muscle, and other internal organs may be identified

Cellulitis, Furunculosis, Ruptured Epide.text: Absence of larvae parts in tissue can rule out myiasis

Leishmaniasis.text: Amastigotes (1-5 μm) with prominent kinetoplast present in macrophages in skin

Onchocerciasis.text: Microfilariae (300-315 µm long) frequently present in skin; lack striated muscle, cuticular spines

Tungiasis.text: Flea that resides at dermal-epidermal junction; contains numerous eosinophilic eggs
